PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Discrimination

To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And WHEREAS the terms of the United Nations Convention on the elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological, disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 11 citizens), Boswell (from 201 citizens) and Walters ( from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the implementation of the recommendations of the Davidson Committee report into telecommunications services in Australia will have the effect of:

Increasing telephone rentals and call charges, particularly for rural and domestic subscribers and therefore putting telephone services beyond the economic reach of the isolated, frail and disabled who depend on the telephone for social contact;
Reducing service standards;
Increasing taxation by using Telecom services as a taxing medium;
Increasing unemployment in both Telecom and the Electronics Manufacturing Industry;
Destroying the security and sovereignty of telecommunications services in Australia;

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government rejects the recommendations of the Davidson report and preserves and develops Telecom as the sole provider of an integrated national telecommunications system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That Australia, as a sparsely populated continent, requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communications.
(2) That the Australian postal service truly meets the needs of all Australians .
(3) That any proposal that Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward be diminished will destroy the concept of the national postal service.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the powers of the postal commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the pensioner and health care cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners do not want a uranium enrichment plant constructed in south-east Queensland because:
(a) there is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) there has not been an environment impact study conducted into the effects of such a uranium enrichment plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) the risks to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) the products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) the local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) the investment in such a uranium enrichment plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of products from uranium enrichment plants;
(b) reject all applications for the export of products from uranium enrichment plants;
(c) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in uranium enrichment plants;
(d) reject all applications for foreign investment in uranium enrichment plants ;
(e) do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a uranium enrichment plant in south-east Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

I will speak very briefly to the Australian Heritage Commission annual report for 1981-82. Like many honourable senators, I think that to some extent I take this report on the run. I would like to make just a couple of brief remarks. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the Commission on an excellent report. As distinct from many reports that we receive in this place, this is a thoughtful report which outlines ideas as well as action taken. I note that some important actions have been taken and reported on by the Commission in the previous year. The Commission underlines the fact that the World Heritage Committee met in Australia and has included three Australian places on the World Heritage List. It takes this as pointing to a growing interest in conservation of our heritage in Australia.

An area of the report which I think needs to be brought out is the emphasis the report gives to Aboriginal sites. It specifically refers to the placing on the World Heritage List by the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation of Kakadu National Park and the Willandra Lakes Region and says a number of things about those areas, on which I will not speak much further. I think honourable senators can read what it says in the report. I do, however, want to bring to the Senate's attention a concern expressed by the Commission at the very few nominations of Aboriginal sites which have been received for inclusion in the Register and the moves the Commission is taking to stimulate those bodies that are in a position to make some judgment on Aboriginal sites and their inclusion in the List.

The report contains a picture of Moreton Island and makes a comment, there alone as far as I can discover, as to the heritage significance of Moreton Island, which it describes as a large sand mass with important Aboriginal middens in what is thought to be the highest sand dune in the world. It makes a statement that the island is under threat from sandmining operations. As I understand it, very recently a decision has been handed down in Queensland which would seem to indicate that sandmining is unlikely to take place on Moreton Island. I bring this to the attention of the Senate because I think the potential for Moreton Island as a place of great cultural significance to Australia is only just starting to be realised. In very recent years-within the last three to four years-the University of Queensland has had an archeological project running on Moreton Island. It has made some fascinating and extremely significant discoveries in relation to Aboriginal life on the island in previous years.

So far as I am aware Moreton Island is the only discrete area in Australia which has the potential to show to us the total pattern of life of an Aboriginal tribe. As far as we know, the Moreton Island tribe resided only there, except for making some visits to neighbouring islands. Further archeological work on Moreton Island will give us the opportunity to define in a unique way the total system of living and culture of this particular Aboriginal tribe. Therefore, because it is relatively undisturbed it has the potential for not only giving to us very important information about Aboriginal culture but also, because it is so close to Brisbane, a major city, making available to Australians generally-if this is treated properly-access to a very important part of our heritage. I congratulate the Australian Heritage Commission for its interest in stimulating the view that Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal heritage are very much part of the Australian national heritage, that we have much to learn and that we have something worth preserving.

The Commission in its report devotes some time to the built environment and to the fact that buildings of some historical significance now are still being demolished at a considerable rate. It lists a number of items-not only buildings but also trees such as the fig in Wickham Terrace-that have been destroyed since it last reported. This should sadden all of us. However, I think it is equally significant that we of European descent in Australia realise that in fact Australians' agriculture and heritage go back some 30,000 years. It is important that we recognise that that is as significant a part of our heritage as is the built environment or natural features such as areas of scenic beauty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to mention in particular those comments in the annual report of the Australian Heritage Commission which relate to the Gordon below Franklin Dam and, indeed, the issue of South West Tasmania generally. Page 3 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt in the mind of the Commission that this river and its surrounds constitutes a place which has ' . . . aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance or other special value for future generations as well as for the present community'. The Commission is of the view that there are ' feasible and prudent' alternatives to the project and that these should be investigated . . .
The discovery of yet more significant archaeological sites in the area only enhances the significance of South West Tasmania and the Franklin River valley in particular.

I want to raise this matter at this time for two reasons. The first is my sense of despair that in spite of statements like this and in spite of the clearest possible indications of an international community view and an Australian view-a responsible view-work is still proceeding in this great Australian natural heritage in Tasmania. I say that it is an Australian heritage; it is not simply a Tasmanian heritage. I have been concerned about statements in the Senate, questions that have been asked and issues that have arisen since this session of the Parliament began which would seem to indicate that in some way Tasmania is not part of Australia and that there is some particular magic about a State which gives it authority and force to do anything it likes within its own territory. Certainly that may well have been the case before 1901, but one would have thought that we had learnt something since then. The whole concept of the federation of this nation was to provide for a common view of what is of national importance, what is Australian, as against what is a State issue and perhaps what is the third area of government, that is, local government. Time and again areas of local government have to give way to State considerations. It happens every day. Nobody jumps up and down about it and says that the sovereignty of Parramatta or the sovereignty of Blacktown or somewhere else has been usurped because that would emerge as complete rubbish.

A week or two ago in the Senate I heard an honourable senator utter the words ' the sovereign State of Tasmania'. I suggest to that ex-Minister that that was either an inadvertent slip of the tongue or showed on his part a degree of ignorance which I do not believe he possesses. There is no issue of sovereignty; we are one nation.

The second point I want to make is to give an update-I think it is very important in this context in view of what the Australian Heritage Commission has said on this subject-of the state of affairs in South West Tasmania. Information I have is that the Hydro-Electric Commission has now established at Warners Landing what is called a temporary camp which is housing 40 men and that is the working base for the road construction crew that is building the road from Warners Landing to the dam site. Beyond that, two new adits are being cut into the banks of the Gordon River. These are tunnels which the HEC can use to investigate the layering of the rock. So construction has gone beyond the stage of mere access roads to getting stuck into the area by digging larger and more major holes and actually tunnelling into the banks of the Gordon River.

I understand that the road from Warners Landing to the dam site is almost complete, with only half a kilometre or so to go. In places the road is constructed in two or three tiers of 25 metres due to a steep traverse. This leaves the bedrock exposed. When winter comes we expect large-scale erosion in that area. Drilling continues above the dam site and a new drill site was started last week. There still seems to be a large amount of activity to find a solid base for the dam. This is another story altogether. Apparently there is no real indication that this is the right place to build the dam. I think a matter which has been largely overlooked in the political consideration is whether it is a sensible or economic proposition to go ahead with this. A new survey transect is being cut through the forest, 10 kilometres long, down the side of the Franklin River to the dam site.

The machinery has been equipped with heated cabins. Apparently the Commission expects to work right through the winter. I think this is a disgraceful state of affairs. I know this is a matter of great controversy but I think reasonable and sufficient action has been taken by the Government-I commend it for this-for us now to make another appeal to Mr Gray not to go ahead with something which he knows is very likely indeed to be an absolute waste of money and to deface an important part of the national heritage to no good purpose whatsoever. It will impose an enormous cost on the State, the revenue of which he has a responsibility and an obligation to protect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I ask: Is it correct that the Australian Labor Party's policy on uranium is destroying the potential for thousands of jobs in a major growth industry?

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is no. The plain fact is that the state of the world market precludes any new mines from being opened under the policy of this Government or the policy of the previous Government because nobody can sign a contract at a price that is acceptable. Nobody knows that better than Mr Anthony because he declined to approve a contract between Pan Continental Mining Ltd and Central Electricity Generating Board because the pricing arrangements were not satisfactory. ANSWER.PARA: While it is a matter of judgment as to how long that world market condition will remain, it is highly unlikely to change in the first term of the Labor Government and probably unlikely to change in the second term. The plain fact is that this is a subterfuge by Mr Anthony which is designed to divert scrutiny from his own record. The fact is that he was the Deputy Prime Minister of the most thoroughly discredited Government in Australian history for the seven dark years during which unemployment trebled, during which the economy was plunged into the deepest recession that it has been in since the 1930s, which left this Government with a $10 billion impending deficit because of the cynical manipulations of electoral and accounting procedures. I give a piece of gratuitous advice to the former Deputy Prime Minister of this thoroughly discredited former Government. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Mr Wran is Premier of New South Wales and it is in the New South Wales context that these allegations have been made; it is in the New South Wales context that they will be dealt with. It is not my business, as a Federal politician, to tell the Premier of New South Wales what he will do and the way in which he will deal with these matters. That is up to him.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health explain what sort of provisions will be made under the proposed Medicare health scheme to cover those people in need of continuing dietetic or nutritional care? I have in mind particularly people with medical conditions such as anorexia nervosa or diabetes.

—It is my understanding that after the establishment of Medicare the actual conditions, initially at least, will not vary from the conditions which exist now. That means, of course, that patients suffering from diseases such as metabolic diseases and some genetic diseases, such as malabsorption syndrome, will receive some assistance under Medicare, as they do under the present medical system and pharmaceutical benefits system. I know of no intention to incorporate conditions such as anorexia nervosa into the scheme. However, I will seek further information from the Minister for Health and ask him to consider such changes after, if not before, Medicare is introduced and we have monitored how the system is working.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that 500 people of 1,300 cases have died so so far due to a previously unknown, so far inexplicable and so far incurable disease known as AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a disease of the body's immune system, and that reportedly no one who has been infected has yet recovered from it? Is the Minister aware that cases have recently been reported also in Denmark, France and Germany, and that while most cases are said to occur among homosexual men and intravenous drug users of both sexes, it is now spreading to the partners and children of these people, and also has been transmitted to recipients of blood transfusions? Does the Minister know it is now suspected that, due to a latent and potentially infectious phase of this disease-possibly as long as two years-it is regarded as having a major potential for spreading? Has the Minister noted that, according to today's issue of the Bulletin magazine, the first case of AIDS has been reported in Sydney? Has the Minister taken steps to see that this disease is identified, notified and monitored if it occurs in Australia? If no action has been taken on the matter, will it be taken as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Acquired immunity deficiency syndrome is the name given fairly recently to a reported complex of health problems associated in all these patients with a severe loss of their natural immunity to disease. This leaves them open to other infections, if indeed it is an infection, called opportunistic infections. Most reports of the disease have been received from the United States of America although some have been received from the countries which Senator Mason mentioned. Indeed, one case has been reported in Australia. Certain groups are particularly vulnerable, including male homosexuals and abusers of intravenous drugs. A group of male Haitian immigrants to the United States who are in fact almost universally heterosexual also seem to be prone, as are patients with haemophilia. The cause has not been identified but, as Senator Mason, I think, suggested, it seems that it may well be a transmissible agent, a virus with a prolonged latent period. As was mentioned in, I believe, the Bulletin, one case has been reported in Australia. If indeed it is a transmissible disease, one can expect more cases because of modern travel and because of the way in which drugs are used and abused.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that the situation is being monitored by the communicable diseases committee and the public health advisory committee. I would have thought that recently considerable publicity had been given to this condition in both the medical Press and the lay Press. I am unaware of any specific action by the Department of Health to publicise the condition. I will seek information in that regard from the Minister for Health. It is obviously a serious problem. Whether it is a new disease or a newly-recognised disease or whether the syndrome covers a multitude of medical conditions or sins I do not think has been determined yet. Certainly it is being carefully monitored by the Department of Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. What has happened to the former Government 's proposals, based on the razor gang report, to lease Australian Government Publishing Service sales outlets to the private sector? Will the Minister consider returning the Sydney sales office to a street level shopfront location so that it is more accessible to the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs asked me about a decision made by the previous Government in respect of the Australian Government Publishing Service. Of course , that decision was to lease it to the private sector, which in its very operation would have restricted public access to the important role that the AGPS plays. I have been advised that the Minister for Administrative Services, my colleague the Honourable John Brown, has already directed that the AGPS is not to proceed with any proposals to lease the operation to the private sector. He has asked the organisation to review the bookshop operation with the objective of improving public access to Government activities. I think that is a very important part of this Government's approach to making available to the public all the activities of the Federal Government. In particular, steps have been taken to review the accommodation and location aspects.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the Australian Government Publishing Service has in recent days entered into a three-year lease with an option for a further three years for ground floor accommodation at the corner of King and Clarence Streets in Sydney. Of course, that applies only to New South Wales. As the honourable senator comes from that State, I am sure that is his particular interest. The accommodation is the best suitable premises that could be located in the city area. It is currently being refurbished with a view to providing the public with ready and pleasant access to Government information. As far as other States are concerned, the organisation has been directed by the Minister to review the suitability of other bookshop locations with a view to reaching a similar arrangement in respect of providing the facilities for the general public. As you well know, Mr President, the public utilises these bookshops very consistently and on an increasing scale. We would therefore want to provide such facilities for ready access for the citizens of Australia to acquire whatever information or books are available as a result of the activities of the Australian Government Publishing Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I remind him that the appointments of commissioners to the Australian Broadcasting Commission will need to be considered in the near future when the Commission is reconstituted. I ask the Minister to assure the Senate unequivocally that there will not be a mass sacking of the present commissioners as retaliation against the most serious allegations about the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, made on the ABC Four Corners program and, furthermore, that a policy of non-interference with the board of the ABC in its handling of public affairs issues will be maintained, even where these programs are critical of friends and supporters of the Australian Labor Party.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a fairly despicable sort of question. I will not be told by representatives of a former government which, when it came to power, sacked the whole Australian Broadcasting Control Board, in order to get rid of what it perceived to be political appointees, what we should do about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and its future board. Let me just say that the Government had determined the names of a number of possible appointees to the board of the future Australian Broadcasting Corporation before any matter arose on the Four Corners program last week. I want to make that quite clear.

QUESTION.PARA: I also remind honourable senators who interject with a degree of ignorance that legislation which was introduced into the Parliament by their Government last year will be reintroduced in very similar form by the Labor Government. In fact, it has already been introduced, I believe, into the House of Representatives. That legislation provides for a substantial change in the management body of the Australian Broadcasting Commission or the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as it will subsequently become. For example, the numbers of the board are reduced. I believe it to be a bipartisan policy that the numbers should be reduced and that the function of the new board of the Corporation should be not a representative one, as it was said to be in the past, but that it should be strictly a board of management. People will be chosen for the board of the Corporation on the basis of their expertise in management, their knowledge of broadcasting and matters of that kind. So it will not be a representative body as it has been in the past. Of course there will be changes. That is inevitable. They will be announced at the appropriate time but not on the basis of the sort of suggestion contained in Senator MacGibbon's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it then that the political allegiances of the future commissioners are the determining factor in their appointment.
—Senator MacGibbon will have an opportunity to determine that when he sees who is appointed.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: Will the Government change the system of payment of family allowances, which currently are paid to around two million families, so that the allowances are backdated to the date of birth of children, rather than being paid from the date of application as at present. This arrangement appears to disadvantage those families who have the least knowledge of their entitlements and who are probably the neediest of families.

—I will take Senator Maguire's suggestion on board although at the moment I have not made any investigations into this matter. I point out that at present family allowances in general are paid from the date of application although in some limited circumstances they may be paid retrospectively. Family allowances are one of the best known of the social security benefits. From memory, they are the social security payments which have the highest take-up. I will make some investigations to see whether a large number of people are affected through ignorance and report to the honourable senator and, indeed, the Senate, on this matter.

—Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree that a national centralised wage fixation system is one which determines a wage for all workers covered by Federal determinations and which is then, in the words of Mr Charles Fitzgibbon of the Australian Council of Trade Unions at the National Economic Summit Conference, 'applied to all-no more, no less'? If he agrees with that how does the Government justify seeing that principle subverted by an apparent willingness to agree to special allowances for workers in the building industry?
—I am not able to answer that question in detail.
—You are not able to answer it at all.

—The honourable senator would be one to talk. I will certainly get an answer to the Leader of the Opposition on that matter. He read with great haste a statement by Mr Fitzgibbon and then asked me whether I agreed with it. I would like time to consider whether I agree with it and to consider the views of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations on that matter. I will obtain an answer for the Leader of the Opposition in due course.

—I direct a question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the Federal Government's policy concerning the Gordon below Franklin Dam and its desire to use its constitutional powers to preserve this area. Is it a fact that in the past there has been a bipartisan policy concerning Federal intervention to protect the environment or to preserve the national estate? Was this policy ever set out in print prior to any election by any spokesperson for the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some documentation is available as to the attitude of the present Opposition to these matters which, I believe, makes a fascinating case study in hypocrisy. In the 1975 election campaign, the then Opposition, as it is now, stated in its environment and conservation printed policy that it took the following view:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Government has direct responsibility:
in relation to our international obligations.
This is in the context of the policy on environment and conservation. The policy statement went on to elaborate on the nature of those international obligations saying, amongst other things:
In relation to our international obligations, we are pledged to:
Sign and ratify appropriate international agreements, and fulfil our obligations under those agreements, having regard to the role of the States.
Moreover, a quite specific commitment to the Tasmanian situation was expressed in the following terms:
We will:
Assist the Tasmanian Government in establishing a National Park of world significance in South-West Tasmania, to include a substantial wilderness area.

When pressed as to what all that meant and in particular how much regard would be paid to the role of the States and, if the Liberals came to power after 1975, how much action the Federal Government would be prepared to take in reliance on its own constitutional power in this area if faced with an unco-operative or recalcitrant State, Mr Hunt, the then spokesman on environment matters for the Liberal-National Country Party coalition, was reported in the Age of 11 December 1975 as having said:
We will not hesitate to invoke, where appropriate, the powers vested in the Commonwealth under Section 51 of the Constitution in order to protect the environment or to preserve the national estate.

That, of course, is exactly what the present Commonwealth Government is doing. Senator Chaney, Senator Durack and numerous other members of the then Opposition are still active and prominent figures in the Liberal Party. It is clear that we have a situation that can most charitably be described, I suppose, as situation ethics-the kind of ethics and the consistency that were demonstrated by Senator Durack in his contribution to the Australian Constitutional Convention. It is this attitude of mind which says: 'We can say anything we like in a situation when we are in opposition, or at some stage in the past. There is no question of consistency or coherence in our position over time'. I believe that these matters, which are all on the public record, amply demonstrate that the forces now arrayed against us on this matter have in the past taken exactly the same view of both the Commonwealth's powers and responsibilities in these matters as the present Labor Government is now taking.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the answer given yesterday by the Minister to Senator Chaney's question relating to wage levels and his comment that it depends on whether one is talking about restraint by the lowest paid workers in the community, whether it would be appropriate for them to receive a wage increase of some kind this year, or whether one is talking about highly paid people in the community such as politicians. I now ask: Did the Minister's comment yesterday indicate that plateau indexation is in contemplation by the Government? If so, will he advise the Senate of the differential wage levels under consideration?

—A number of matters are under consideration by the Government in terms of what will be put to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission when it meets to determine whether there should be any national wage increase this year. When the Government has decided what matters will be put to the Commission, they will be announced.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Will the Government give consideration to the provision of electronic monitoring devices for elderly and handicapped people who live alone, thereby enabling them to maintain their independence and also reducing the demand for costly residential care?

—I have no detail on how far investigation of these devices has proceeded within the Department of Health. They are expensive. I believe they have not been fully tested in all circumstances, but it is my understanding that the matter is being investigated by the Minister for Health. I dare say that if they were proved to be effective, if there were sufficient demand and if, indeed , as Senator Zakharov implies, they would result in a considerable saving, the Government would certainly consider providing them. I will seek further details from the Minister for Health.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does Mr Hawke's offer of a small wages increase this year, to be followed by full wage indexation next year, indicate that the Prime Minister wishes to commit Government and unions to projection A as canvassed at the National Economic Summit Conference? If so, does that mean that he has accepted three years of unemployment at higher than current levels, as outlined in that projection?

—I find it extraordinary that the question is posed in terms of Mr Hawke's offer. Mr Hawke has made no offer and he is not in a position to make offers. He answered a question in the House of Representatives yesterday when he was asked about the likely effects of wage increases on the general level of economic activity and consequently upon the level of unemployment. He gave an answer relating to those matters and the answer is in Hansard. I have nothing to add to it.

—I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs when the Government will begin providing assistance to enable the introduction of urban and rural alternative lifestyle projects. Does the Minister agree that such projects would be a constructive and imaginative means of offering an alternative to chronic unemployment? Will the Government seek the assistance of State governments in providing education in basic trade skills and skills of survival and self-sufficiency to equip young people for the demands of alternative living? Finally, will the Minister investigate the possibility of employing the experience of skilled pensioners and retired trades people in educating the unemployed youth in the various crafts and trades necessary for any degree of self-sufficiency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very well aware that the unemployment crisis, particularly the crisis of unemployed youth, which we have inherited from the previous Government means that we have to look beyond the conventional work force when we are planning employment opportunities for young people over the next decade. Because we recognise this we are looking constructively at what alternative forms of employment are possible. In the honourable senator's question to me he in fact indicated some of the kinds of developments which would be constructive in this context. I have already asked officers of my Department to look at the possibilities of developing co-operative opportunities for young people in order to provide work. This matter was referred to by me at the National Economic Summit Conference. I am pleased to say there was a very positive response from some sections of industry which also are very well aware that the youth unemployment crisis created by the previous Government cannot be overcome simply by waiting for conventional employment opportunities to develop.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of possibilities. The success of some rural communes is something that it is time for us to recognise. It is time we looked at that as a possible area of future development. But perhaps what is of more interest, particularly to industry, is the possibility of developing small co-operative enterprises and providing training in some of the unused workshop facilities which industry currently has available as a result of the economic crisis. The suggestion in Senator Jones's question that there are people in the community, particularly in the aged group, who have craft and trade skills that they would willingly impart to young people I think is a very constructive suggestion. It is the kind of creative thinking that the community as a whole will need to engage in to solve this immense problem. I am pleased to report, as I said, that I have had positive responses from industry. I will also be speaking, of course, to the trade union movement about this matter. Senator Jones can be assured that we are pursuing with great seriousness this particular new development which could provide viable economic and socal arrangements for a considerable section of unemployed youth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Has the Government given any consideration to the establishment of a planning council to act as a focal point for a process of consultative planning about Australia's medium term development and to assist in promoting discussion on economic, environmental, social and cultural issues? Has the Government considered the establishment of a commission for the future to study long term economic and social developments with special attention to prospective developments in science and technology? Is the Minister aware that similar organisations exist in New Zealand and have proved highly effective in drawing the issues of the 1980s and beyond to the attention of New Zealanders? Finally, what mechanisms exist or are proposed by the Government to keep the Government informed of the likely impact of technological developments on the social, economic, cultural and political life of the nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans asked me a number of questions. In the brief time at its disposal since it was elected the Government has not given attention to establishing a planning council dealing with social, cultural and other issues to which the honourable senator referred. I am not saying, because we presently are not giving attention to it, that it is a matter which the Government would not consider. I regard the honourable senator's question partly as a suggestion and partly as a question. It is a matter which the Government would certainly be keen to examine. Because of the mess this Government inherited from the Fraser period of government its first priority is to establish the Economic Planning Advisory Council and a price surveillance mechanism, because one cannot make any social or cultural progress in the community with one million people unemployed and in the economic situation in which this Government found the country after the recent election.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the question of a commission for the future, I am aware of such a body in New Zealand. In Sweden, for example, there is a council for the future . There are similar bodies of that kind. At the moment I am not in a position to say anything about the matter except that the Government recognises the importance of such bodies. One of the important responsibilities of my portfolio and the portfolio of science and technology will be to determine or address policies relating to the impact of technological change on industry particularly .

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. What natural gas resources have been found in Bass Strait? Is Tasmania entitled to share in this energy resource? Could Bass Strait gas supplement Tasmania's energy needs?

—If I may take up the last part of the question first, Bass Strait reserves, in total, could supply Tasmania's energy needs. That is obvious. However, that is not economically feasible. If Senator Hearn is referring to discoveries in Bass Strait to supply Tasmania's needs, supplies that are within the range of economic feasibility, it appears that the answer is 'not likely'. One well which struck gas was drilled 70 kilometres north of Burnie. I think it might be called the Pelican Well. The reserves estimated in that field were one trillion cubic feet which, to put it in perspective, is about 2 per cent of the North West Shelf reserves and 4 per cent of the proven reserves in Bass Strait. The most significant test of whether that was economic is, I think, the fact that Hematite Petroleum Pty Ltd subsequently surrendered the lease. Clearly, in the judgment of the company, not only was it not an economic proposition at this stage but also it was not likely to be an economic proposition in the future.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and refer to a May Day rally held recently in Adelaide. Is it a fact that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Honourable Stewart West, when addressing the rally, suggested to the workers that they should press for considerable wage rises? If that is a fact, is that a Government policy? If it is not, can the Minister say whether the Government is operating on the basis that individual--
—The fact is that he did not say it. That is the point.
—I am asking the question: Is it a fact? If it is not, is the Government operating on the basis that individual Ministers may put separate views on important policy issues?

—I do not know whether Mr West, when addressing a May Day rally, said anything of the exact kind suggested by Senator Jessop in his question. I do know that if he did it is not Government policy. I read a report on the front page of the Melbourne Age which said that Mr West had been reprimanded by the Prime Minister-if he had, in fact, said anything of that kind-for making a statement which was not consistent with Government policy.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation aware of the concern expressed, particularly by local government spokespeople, over the use of the Perth Airport by KC135s during a recent military exercise? Is he aware that this concern is related not only to noise pollution but also to the fact that the Western Australian emergency services would not have the capacity to handle an accident involving one of these tankers? In the light of that concern, will the Minister advise whether any more visits by such aircraft are currently forecast and whether he will consider some means of advising nearby residents prior to such an exercise?

—Senator Coleman asked me a question which obviously requires a detailed answer. I am afraid I have no information on the matter, although I share her concern and, in fact, the residents' concern about such use, if it has taken place. I will undertake to refer the matter to the Minister I represent in this place and get her a very early reply.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment deny that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983, using the Tasmanian dam issue as the reason for its implementation, can be used, under the guise of protecting the environment, against any project in any State with which a centralist Federal government does not agree?

—The purpose of the legislation referred to in the honourable senator's question is to protect certain areas that have been declared as places that should be protected for their natural significance. These places include areas such as Fraser Island and the Great Barrier Reef. It is not intended to be legislation that can affect just any part of Australia at any whim of the Government but it is designed to protect specific areas and I think it will have bipartisan support.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and it concerns the now defunct Professional Employment Office. Is the Minister aware of the very efficient service provided by the PEO to unemployed professional people prior to its abolition in May 1981? Is the Minister also aware that the needs of both unemployed professional people and employers seeking professional staff are not being met by the Commonwealth Employment Service job centres? Can the Minister confirm that the previous Government abolished the PEO as a result of pressure exerted on Sir Phillip Lynch and the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations by private employment agencies? Will the Government re-establish the Professional Employment Office and in doing so provide a free employment service to unemployed professional people?

—The Professional Employment Office attached to the CES was abolished by the Fraser Government. I understand that it was of assistance to many people. I am unable to say whether it was abolished as a result of pressure put on Sir Phillip Lynch. My only observation would be that if pressure was put on Sir Phillip Lynch he would be just the person who would yield to it. The question also asked whether the Government would re-establish the Professional Employment Office. That is a matter about which I will obtain advice from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I should say that in the absence of a professional employment office run by the Commonwealth there have been widespread abuses by private employment agencies which are the subject of State government investigation in several States. I think that in considering whether the Professional Employment Office should be re-established the extent of those abuses should be taken into account.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence inform the Senate what action has been taken or will be taken by the present Government in disposing of the two Boeing 707 aircraft, the acquisition and use of which was constantly criticised by the previous Opposition? Further, does the Minister not agree that the sale of the two planes would be another great idea at this time of restraint in government finances?

—I am not in a position to give a detailed answer to the honourable senator on those matters. I do not think there is a very substantial market, except in the context of refuellers and tankers, for used Boeing 707s in the aviation world at the moment should we want to dispose of the VIP Boeing 707s. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister and seek an answer at the earliest possible opportunity.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, refers to comments in the West Australian newspaper of 26 April by a spokesperson for the Fremantle City Council that a women's refuge, built only 12 years ago, is now totally inadequate because of the increasing numbers of women and children needing refuge and the increasing time of such required refuge. I understand that this is not a unique situation and that it relates not only to Warrawee but to most of the women's refuges around Australia . Can the Minister please give me some information which will give some hope to those people who are running the refuges and those people who require the services of refuges? Can the Minister state what specific initiatives the Labor Government will take to ease the situation in the immediate future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coleman is well aware that the great difficulties which have faced women's refuges, those who work in them and those who have needed them in recent years are partly because of a failure to maintain an adequate level of funding and, more recently, because of the policy of the previous Government to opt out of this situation and provide the States with grants for these purposes through the community health program. Other factors have affected the operations of women's refuges. One of these factors has been the increasing tendency in some States to limit the length of stay of people, for instance in mental hospitals or psychiatric hospitals. Although that has laudable aims, sometimes it has had the effect of increasing the burden on women's refuges and other shelters of this type.

ANSWER.PARA: My colleague the Minister for Health will be discussing the future of this program with the States in the light of our policy. We believe it is a national program and that it should be nationally funded. Our policy was, and is, to institute a national women's emergency program which would cover women's refuges and women's health centres of this type. When the program was initially handed over to the States in the manner in which it was handed over a couple of years ago it was our view that we would take it back to the way in which it had been funded before by the Federal government. Since that time, of course, more State Labor governments have been elected. I note that those running women's refuges in some States are happy to deal with the State governments in those circumstances. In those cases we may be in the situation of being able to negotiate with the State governments to provide them with increased funds and more efficient services. However, in order to obtain exact details of the program I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Health. The Minister for Health has discussed this matter already but he will be discussing it further with State health Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the damaging results of the proposal by the Federal Minister for Health and the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland to decriminalise the growing of marihuana for private use? Does the Minister realise that recent studies into health effects of marihuana use prove that this drug produces acute effects on the brain, causes periods of anxiety, confusion and psychosis and can interfere with ovulation in the female body? Can the Minister confirm that it is Labor Party policy to decriminalise the growing of marihuana, as suggested by the Minister for Health, which will have very many detrimental results?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has a view on marihuana which he has held for many years. He presented this view honestly before he became a Minister and he did not resile from it after he became a Minister. But he was in no way advocating that policy as Minister for Health; nor is it Labor Party policy. In fact, such matters would largely come under the Attorney-General and others in this Government. I point out to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that the present Minister for Health is not the only one who holds such views. In fact the former Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, held views similar to that-I concede that they were not exactly the same-and he came under considerable criticism for those views from another female senator on his side of the House.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that reports continuously come out about alleged effects of marihuana. I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, of which Senator Baume was the Chairman, which looked at such reports which had been produced since, I think, the year 1898. Most, if not all, of the reports to that time about the sorts of effects Senator Bjelke-Petersen was talking about, were not substantiated. It is a difficult problem. It is a problem which is not only a medical problem but also a social problem, and it is a problem with which we all have to deal.

I do not think the debate on this situation is assisted by remarks of the type made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen or attempts by Senator Walters, as she has done in recent weeks, to portray the Australian Labor Party's policy as being for decriminalisation when the Labor Party has no such policy. Senator Bjelke- Petersen has tried to portray Senator Tate, myself and Dr Blewett as being the only people in this Parliament who have ever expressed a view in favour of decriminalisation and, at the same time has carefully ignored people on her own side who have expressed those same views. The Senate Standing Committee at the time said that one of the problems facing us in the whole drug scene- particularly with marihuana-was the lack of rational debate, a lack of debate about the facts and too much of the emotive sort of language that Senator Bjelke -Petersen has introduced, as she did in her question, I believe in search of the popular vote rather than in search of a sensible solution to the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs any evidence that Aborigines were found in the Maralinga test area immediately after a test, as was reported by a British television program recently? If so, what action has been taken on behalf of these people, firstly, to provide all necessary health measures and, secondly, to compensate them or their relatives for damages caused by the tests?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has not provided me with specific information in response to the issues raised by the honourable senator' s question. However, I think it is widely acknowledged that during the period of the previous Fraser Government the whole issue of environmental health damage to Aborigines living in that area was raised. Like so many other issues affecting Aboriginal people, that matter was not resolved or properly investigated by the previous Government. I understand that there is now a claim by Aboriginals living in that area for land rights in respect of the area. Of course, this raises not only the question of their capacity to claim land under the South Australian legislation-which I think they have-but also further environmental and health problems that could exist if parts of the land still have high levels of residual radiation. The South Australian Minister of Aboriginal Affairs has written to the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on this issue. When I have the reply from the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I will let Senator Robertson have any information that may be pertinent to the question that he raised.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's report to this Parliament on the National Economic Summit Conference. This report was read in the Senate chamber by Senator Button yesterday. Is it a fact that this report-in particular the lists of achievements set out on three pages of the report-does not contain one single reference to wage restraint but instead mentions a commitment explicitly 'to the maintenance of real wages'? Is this not all the more evidence to confirm that the Labor Government is in fact giving in to the unions and to the most serious danger-a wages explosion-that will wreck the Australian economy and lead to even higher levels of unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin the answer to this question by saying that it is very sad that the Opposition in this Parliament having, as a Government last year, fixed on wage increases as the cause of all this country's problems, is still obsessed with that idea in 1983. It is sad that a political party, which in government adopted the view of the then member for Macarthur that it had to be seen to be doing something about unemployment-and then adopted the wages freeze as the answer to that problem, is still fixed with the idea that that is the solution to this country's problems. I make that comment in relation to a number of questions which have been asked, and particularly Senator Teague's question. He referred me to the communique issued after the Summit. That communique is not a legal document. It is not a document which expresses anything more than the attitudes of various parties which attended the Summit. The important thing about that document is that it represents changed attitudes on the part of most of the participants at the Summit, including the trade union movement. Of course, the trade union movement in Australia has to be concerned about maintenance of real wages.

ANSWER.PARA: The alternative is not something on which I want to elaborate in Question Time. I suggest that Senator Teague should think about what he means in terms of the standards of living of Australians if he does not believe in the maintenance of real wages over time, as expressed in the communique. Of course all Australians ought to be concerned about the maintenance of real wages and the decline in the standard of living which has taken place in this country in recent years. Of course the Government is concerned about wage restraint. We have said so and we will continue to say so. But wage restraint, as the Government has said repeatedly, must be seen in the context of restraint by all sections of the community. That is the message which derives from the communique and that is the answer to the honourable senator's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I was not referring directly to the communique but rather to the terms in which the Prime Minister reported to this Parliament about the communique and about the action that the Government has on its agenda from now on. I acknowledge that there is to be restraint in every area, but--
—Will the honourable senator ask his supplementary question.
—Why is there a grand omission in the Prime Minister's report to the Senate? Why is there no reference at all to wage restraint?

—I have not read the statement which I read to the Senate yesterday with the same finesse as Senator Teague read it this morning prior to asking his question. But if that is a matter of great concern to him, I will ask the Prime Minister about that error, as Senator Teague puts it, in the speech. The Prime Minister is on the public record on a number of occasions in relation to wage restraint.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, arises out of part of an answer he gave in which he suggested that the previous Government had fixed on a single issue of wages as the cause of our economic problems. Did not the Treasurer, in his address to the National Economic Summit Conference, admit that there was a stimulation in the last Budget, the effects of which were currently flowing through to the economy? Was that not evidence of one of the elements of the previous Government's approach to meeting Australia's problems of reduced economic activity?
—The previous Budget was not in any sense a response to Australia' s problems; it was a response to the perceived desire of the then Prime Minister to have an early election, and nothing else.

—During Question Time Senator Maguire asked me a question about the backdating of family allowances. In my answer I omitted to give him and other honourable senators the information that at present, if family allowances are claimed within six months of the birth of the child, payment is backdated to the first pay day after the birth. It can be backdated after six months, but only in special circumstances. That does not alter the gist of my answer-that we will look at this matter overall.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time Senator Walters asked me a question concerning a Royal Australian Air Force flight over South West Tasmania on 24 March 1983. The Minister for Defence was asked a similar question. In the House of Representatives last night he advised as follows:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The critical importance of a firm and effective wages policy if unemployment is to be reduced.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is putting forward this matter of public importance today because there is a widespread understanding that wage policy is one of the critical areas if we are to reduce unemployment in Australia and that is the common wish of us all. However, we are not putting it forward on the basis that was imputed to us by Senator Button at the close of Question Time this morning when he tried to suggest that the ex-Government, the present Opposition, was clinging to wages policy as being the sole area of economic policy which mattered. Clearly, that is not the view of the Opposition and it is not a view which should be ascribed to us. I think the importance in bringing it forward now is that it is quite clear from the vagueness of the answers which Senator Button has given in this place that the Government has not yet determined precisely what attitude it will take when it goes before the wage tribunals, in particular the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and in the critical discussions which will determine what happens after the wages freeze. Either the Government has not made up its mind or it is not yet prepared to tell the public what its attitude is. In that circumstance all of us, particularly, perhaps, Government senators, are in a position to seek to influence the Government in a way which will produce the most beneficial result for the unemployed in Australia, the result which will bring about the greatest increase in employment. It is very easy for the Government to say, 'Look at what we have inherited. The position is difficult.' Nobody, of course, denies that the position is difficult, but the decisions henceforth which will change that position are in the hands of the Government. It is important that decisions should be made which will reduce the level of unemployment rather than increase it. Wrong decisions now will damage the prospects of the Government having success later. The Opposition brings this matter forward in the hope that the Government will adopt the most sensible policies possible with a view to reducing unemployment. Again, I put to rest the point which was raised at the end of Question Time-that the Opposition sees wages policy as the sole area of economic policy. I simply remind the Senate that a series of policy changes by the previous Government over the last year were directed to attacking the problem of reduced economic activity and higher unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Senate again to the record of the National Economic Summit Conference and the words of one of the representatives of the Government, the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, who talked about the change in the levels of expenditure on things such as housing, capital works and training for people who are not in employment. Those changes reflected the various areas of policy that the previous Government tackled in order to meet the problems which were emerging towards the closing months of the Government's life and, indeed, during the last year. Whilst wages policy is clearly not the sole area of policy which is important it is an area of critical importance to the future of employment in Australia. The Government now concedes that there are other factors, such as the international economic situation and the drought, which happily over most of Australia is now broken, which affect us, but it remains true that wages policy and what happens to earnings in Australia will be a critical factor in determining what level of employment we have in the future.

The Opposition is directing this debate to the question of what policies will produce 'jobs, jobs and more jobs', which we were told was the objective of the Government. The greatest value of the Summit is that this Government and many of the participants in the Summit established clearly the linkage between jobs and wages. In fact, it should not have taken that Summit to achieve that because it is nearly 10 years now since Frank Crean said, 'One man's pay rise is another man's job.' I think it is important that that proposition is broadly understood and, more importantly, acted upon. If that is to occur it is important that it is seen not as Fraser or Liberal rhetoric but as part of the reality with which we have to deal. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the present Government set out three scenarios to assist the Conference which was convened by the Government. Whilst there are limitations on such scenarios, they show the links which the various policy options have and the effect that wage changes will have on employment levels. Presumably, the objective of putting those scenarios before the Conference was that there would be a broadening of that understanding. They show that wage policy is a key factor in determining levels of employment. The three options put forward were remarkable because they really all produced a fairly gloomy prognostication for the unemployed.

Option A was relatively modest on the wages front. It allowed for no wage catch -up for any consumer price index increases prior to the current pause. It involved a wage increase of about 3 per cent in the latter half of 1983-that proposition now seems to be embraced by the present Government-and a return to full quarterly indexation and annual productivity cases subsequently. If we followed that scenario, according to the information which the Government has put before us, we would have an unemployment rate of 9.7 per cent in 1985-86. That is a total unemployment level in three years time of 710,000. On the evidence which is available to us that appears to be closest to the option that the Government might embrace, an option which would produce unemployment in three years in excess of 700,000. The second option was the sort of option which some elements of the trade union movement seem to be pursuing. That was for full catch-up, full quarterly indexation and productivity increases. The result of that would be to increase unemployment from 10.6 per cent in 1983-84 to 11.7 per cent in 1984-85 and 12.2 per cent by 1985-86. That is a horrifying scenario for everybody in the Senate, Government and Opposition senators alike. None of us wants to see unemployment at that level. That is what the scenario suggested would occur if we had a full catch-up and full indexation after that catch-up.

The third scenario that the Government put before the Conference was one in which the pause would be extended to April 1984. In other words, it involves a higher level of wage restraint, an extension of the pause to April 1984 and only partial indexation thereafter. That would allow for a small fall in unemployment to 8.7 per cent three years down the line. That of course is significantly better than an unemployment rate of over 12 per cent three years down the line. Those scenarios emphasise that there are significant choices to be made in the immediate future and in the years ahead which will significantly affect how many Australians are unemployed. I do not believe that anybody who voted to elect and support the present Government would have believed that it would follow policies which permit an increase in unemployment. I am sure the expectation was that it would pursue policies which would reduce unemployment.

I do not think very many people in this place would accept that the options which were put forward for the purpose of illustration only predict a level of unemployment that any of us would regard as satisfactory. Most people here I think would agree with the late Sir Keith Campbell, who pointed out that those options were not satisfactory and that the Government should indeed be considering what he described as option D, a fourth option which would involve very considerable wage restraint and the possibility of a greater increase in employment and, hence, a greater decrease in unemployment. I wish to quote one paragraph of what he said to the Summit:

For the jobless and I suggest for the whole economy, scenario C offers the most hope. But it still predicts, its deficiencies accepted, an unemployment rate on average in 1985-86, little different to that in 1982-83. Surely that is not good enough. If we genuinely care about the jobless and genuinely wish to incur discipline and sacrifice, we need to put together a scenario D. Unless the broad messages from the scenarios are meaningless we must clearly extend the wage pause to the end of 1983, we should clearly agree that there should be no catch- up at that date and we should agree further to review, on behalf of the employed and the unemployed, this vital community matter during the first quarter of 1984 having regard to our then progress and circumstances.

On behalf of the Opposition, and I believe on behalf of most people in the Australian community, I would urge the Government to consider introducing some scenario D which will hold out a greater hope for the unemployed than do the sort of possibilities which are currently being canvassed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He admits to the possibility of an end to the wage freeze this year and to indexation thereafter, and of a situation which, on the Government's own forecasting, is unlikely to produce an improvement in the employment situation and may indeed produce a worsening of it.

It is clear, both on the face of the Summit documents and on the basis of what has been told to the Parliament in this place and in the other chamber, that there is an objection to the extension of the wage pause and to the idea that those of us who are fortunate enough to be in employment should be called upon to sacrifice ourselves further. The reality of that objection has to be understood and grappled with if we are to tackle it positively and if we are to produce a better result for the people of Australia. It appears to me that the objections to a really positive attitude to wage restraint are twofold. One is that there is concern about what would be termed 'industrial relations reality'. Senator Button has, I think, touched on that in some of his answers to questions over recent days. The attitude seems to be that it is just not the real world to expect those who are currently in employment to accept that their wages should remain frozen for a longer period; after all, their standard of living has declined.

The second area of argument appears to relate to the question of hardship. I should like to touch on that matter also. It is a fact that people who are on low salaries are in a much worse position to have their wages remain frozen than those who are fortunate enough to be on high salaries. I would suggest that to the extent that industrial relations reality prevents the Government from following and urging wages policies upon the industrial authorities of this country which would reduce unemployment, that exposes the sham of the consensus and the accord which allegedly have been reached. If trade unions, as the representatives of the 90 per cent of Australians who are in employment, insist on maintaining their real wages at the expense of the unemployed, what has been achieved? I suggest that nothing has been achieved if those of us who are in employment-I include all of us who are in employment-are still in a position to insist on maintaining our living standards at the expense of the unemployed.

If trade unions do not want to put the creation of employment first, then I put it to the Senate that the Government must do so. The test of this Government's bona fides will be when it goes before the industrial arbitration authorities and puts its views on what appropriate wage policies are. Will it favour the unemployed in this country who desire to be employed or will it favour those who are currently in employment? Government senators should note their responsibility on this issue. On this issue the buck does not rest with the previous Government; the buck will rest with those who have been elected to government and who maintain the Government in its place.

It is important to acknowledge the second point I mentioned, the question of hardship. I have a lot of sympathy for people who say that it is all very well for those on high earnings to urge restraint, but it is not very good for the chap who is on a minimum wage and trying to support a family. I think that is an argument which needs to be considered and understood. I note that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), in response to a question by me, raised the possibility of plateau indexation as one possible approach to that problem. That approach was also dealt with by some of the participants in the Summit. They suggested that all of us who enjoy a salary above a certain level might lead the sacrifice rather than those who are at the bottom of the heap in economic terms. I simply say to the Government that that is one of the options which are open to it to consider if it wishes to grapple realistically with this question of getting the Australian economy back into balance and growing again. I hope that we will see something more than a craven acceptance by the Government of a trade union view that there simply must be increases because there have not been increases for some time, and rather an attempt to work out some realistic balance.

It is also possible in other fields to assist those who are on low incomes without affecting the salary rates. There was bipartisan support for a measure which we introduced in the last Budget, although the then Opposition, the present Government, said that the measure should have been more generous. I refer to the family income supplement for low income working families. So a range of options is available to the Government. It can face the very real issues and challenges of the imbalance between wages and profits in this country without ignoring the difficulties which have been raised. There are solutions to them. I hope that the Government will search out these solutions and go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with a positive approach which involves continued wage restraint on the part of those who are fortunate enough to be in employment-one which pays heed to the warnings given at the Summit by people such as Mr Leard that we, as a country, are living beyond our means-so that there is genuine hope for the unemployed in the operations of this Government over the coming months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Chaney that I hope so, too. I want to address myself to some of the issues which have been raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in this matter of public importance which draws our attention to the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The critical importance of a firm and effective wages policy if unemployment is to be reduced.

I find that to be an exciting idea coming from the former Government because no government in the history of Australia has had a less firm and effective wages policy than did the Fraser Government between 1981 and its ultimate demise in March 1983. There has been no effective wages policy over a very long period. When Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd sought to increase its prices in respect of steel the reason it gave initially was labour costs. That was true in a sense. It was due to labour costs, but they were labour costs which flowed into the economy in the last quarter of 1981 and early 1982. All those things happened because of a complete absence of a wages policy on the part of the Fraser Government. Not only did this Government inherit an economic mess generally as a result of the policies of the Fraser Government; it also inherited a mess in respect of a wages policy. The National Economic Summit Conference was most important in obtaining at least some attitudinal consensus on the changes needed in the approach to wage fixation issues. I wish to come to that matter in more detail in a minute. I agree on the importance of a firm and effective wages policy if unemployment is to be reduced. Of course, these things can be established only in a community climate where there are attitudes of consensus in relation to them. That was what the Government sought to do at the time of the Economic Summit and is still seeking to do.

I wish to take Senator Chaney up on one point. He talked about the Australian Council of Trade Unions dictating policy in relation to wages matters, representing a greedy work force and so on. I remind members of the Opposition that it was only in November of last year that the ACTU made a formal offer to the Government to forgo tax cuts which the Government had offered by way of an electoral bribe in anticipation of an early election. The ACTU offered to the Fraser Government that it would forgo half of those tax cuts if the Government would establish a national employment fund out of the proceeds which would be made available as a result. That was refused peremptorily by the Fraser Government and it is not a matter about which I believe the Opposition can now talk with any sense of satisfaction.

Of course, a number of issues concern the competitive position of Australian industry and affect levels of unemployment. I hoped that after the election the level of debate about some of those issues might have been raised in this chamber.
