In now saying that the wage freeze ought to be extended to the end of this year-perhaps, if one takes an alternative option, it ought to be extended until April 1984-the question the members of the Opposition have never satisfactorily answered is, first, what happens at the end of the wage freeze? What is their view about that topic? Secondly, when talking about the competitiveness of Australian industry one has never heard from the Opposition, since it has been in opposition or while its members were in government, what the factors are which go to the alleged lack of competitiveness of Australian industry or whether there are factors at all. Is there only one factor? That is all one ever hears about from Liberal Party spokesmen. They say that there is only one factor which goes to the question of competitiveness of Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Technology, as well.

—No, I am talking about the way the argument was put by Senator Chaney and by all the Opposition front bench spokesmen. The only issue is wages. The now Opposition ran that line for seven years in government and it is running it still.
—What about the tax changes of last year on depreciation?

—Senator Chaney raises the question of tax changes. It is extraordinary that a government of a trading nation such as Australia, after other countries had introduced depreciation regimes, took 10 years to introduce tax changes of the kind that the Fraser Government introduced last year. It is extraordinary that we took 10 years to do that in spite of a lot of criticism from industry and so on about assistance to industry provided in other countries . We were about the last member country of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development to do that. I congratulate the Fraser Government on finally having done it. But we cannot compete if we take that length of time to wake up to what is going on in the rest of the world.
—But you cannot say that that is the only area of policy-wage policy-which we tackled. I mentioned tax and various other things.

—The honourable senator mentioned tax, but I thought with not much success because that area was an extraordinary failure for his Government, as I have just pointed out. If the honourable senator wants to mention anything else we can deal with it as we go along, but the prime point I am seeking to make is that I am not just attacking honourable senators opposite, although they deserve it. The debate in this country about the competitiveness of Australian industry has been reduced to abysmal levels of sloganeering. Those on the conservative side of politics say that it is all due to wage increases and nothing else. We have tended to say that it is not all due to wage increases. I have never heard conservative political parties in Australia asking: 'To what level should wages in Australia be reduced to make us competitive as a nation'? If honourable senators opposite have only one leg to their argument, as they basically do-that it is all a matter of wage levels-to what level ought wages be reduced to make us competitive? They ought to address that argument and then they ought to advocate their argument in public. What they will find is that the levels of Australian wages should be reduced very substantially and that this country would abandon, as an instrument of wages policy, very rapidly instead of very slowly, the standard of living which it has enjoyed for generations. That argument is never addressed by honourable senators opposite. They really have to come up with some answers about that matter if they are going to address the question of unemployment and competitiveness of Australian industry solely on the basis of its being a matter of wages.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point I would like to make, which arises very much from the Summit, is that in our view a number of other issues relate to competitiveness of Australian industry. Those matters were addressed at the Summit. For the first time in the history of this country a serious debate which could never have taken place under a Liberal government is going on in industry about many of those other issues. It is taking place in the maritime industry, which has been very severe about the capacity of Australian industry to compete. It is taking place in the metal trades industry and in the transport industry. All sorts of issues are now being addressed, which have never been addressed before, such as questions related to overmanning of restrictive labour practices and even penalty rates. Those questions are being addressed and they all go to competitiveness.

For the first time on the other side of the political fence or the industrial fence questions relating to product design and a variety of other matters- questions about whether industries are manufacturing for the right market or just manufacturing because they have done it that way for 30, 40 or 50 years-are being addressed. They are questions which came up in the context of the Summit and they are still being considered in many seminars and discussions taking place around the country. They are important issues about the competitiveness of Australian industry which ultimately go to the question of the levels of employment we are able to establish in this country.

So I say that, not in any hostile spirit I hope, although I might have smiled and said something which might have seemed less than charitable to somebody on the other side. I say that, because I believe that the nature of the debate on these issues in Australia should be raised. It is sad to see Senator Chaney, the newly elected youthful Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, going back to that tired old stuff as though wages policy was the only issue involved. It is not. There are many other issues about which we have to be concerned.

The second thing I want to say about employment is that another issue we have not addressed in public debate in this country is whether one does everything right with the Australian economy in terms of wages policy, fiscal policy and monetary policy. We have not discussed whether, if one does everything right in terms of macroeconomic decisions, this country can get back to the halcyon days of the levels of employment we enjoyed in 1965. I believe there are many misguided, highly qualified economists who take the view that we will. I personally believe it is sheer rubbish to say that we can possibly attain to the levels of employment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that during the election campaign?
—I have said it for years in this chamber, in the election campaign and everywhere else.
—Not your leader, though.

—No, we said that if Fraser Government policies were continued there would be a million unemployed people in Australia by the end of 1983. We have since said, having discovered the most horrendous character of the mess honourable senators opposite left when they were put out of government, that levels of unemployment, as Senator Chaney pointed out in the scenario, will remain high. It is a matter of great regret. The point I was simply trying to make before I was interrupted-Senator Durack interrupted on the basis of not have heard the point; that was a brilliant interjection, I must say, as he interjected before I had finished-was we have to look at questions such as the size of the Australian labour force. I believe the size of the Australian labour force is too great, given the potential of this country in terms of manufacturing and other employment.
—Malthusian.

—No, it is not Malthusian. Many people in the electorate recognise that better than the honourable senator does. I am surprised he has not picked that up. People go around saying that married women should not work, that migrants should have second preference for jobs and things like that. What they are saying is simply that. They recognise that the size of the work force is too great. One of the reasons it is too great is that we have no policy in place in terms of the working life of citizens in this country. We have no real agreement about early retirement programs. We have many ad hoc early retirement programs operating now and many forced early retirement programs in particular industries. We have no agreement about when people should start their working life. That is a tragedy because in the United States, Japan and countries with which we compete hardly anybody is employed under the age of 20, largely because such people are all in educational or training institutions of one kind or another. That is probably why those countries have a more sophisticated work force than we have now.

SPEECH.PARA: I am making these points not because they are the fault of the Fraser Government of the last year or so but because they are the fault of 30 years of conservative governments which have neglected these issues. We came into government to find chronic disemployment going on in a vast variety of Australian industries. Unemployment is not just due to the recession; it is due to lack of planning in respect of those industries over many years and lack of capacity of industries to adjust structurally.

I reject the contention that it is superficial and that the whole question can be solved in this sort of gimmicky way in which Liberal Parties have sought to solve it. As I mentioned this morning at Question Time, the previous Government saw the unemployment figures rising, it thought of a number and the former honourable member for Macarthur said: 'We have got to be seen to be doing something'. So the wages pause was invented as a solution to unemployment in Australia. It is not the solution to unemployment in Australia. It was a very glib and very slick approach. As a result of that approach the previous Government won the Flinders by-election but lost the seat at the election five months later. It is a very slick, glib approach. It does not address the variety of issues which have to be addressed in terms of the competitiveness of Australian industry and unemployment. The point I am really trying to make is that if we can get away from the ad hoc, fitful, gimmicky sort of approach of the past we have a better chance of dealing with some of these issues than we had before.

In relation to a couple of other comments by Senator Chaney, I want to say only that it is no good trying to set us up now so that in six months time if there is still continuing high unemployment, which of course there will be, the Opposition will be able to come back to say: 'Look, we told you so. If the wages pause had only stayed in place until April 1984 all this unemployment would not have been here'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not said that.

—Somebody else accused the Opposition of saying that. I am not accusing Senator Chaney of that. It is no good trying to set up that political excuse in desperation now. It shows an element of foresight about it but not much insight, if I might say so. This matter of public importance proposal amounts to a reiteration of the Opposition's view that a firm and effective wages policy is necessary if unemployment is to be reduced. I am not going to dissent with that view at all. I think a firm and effective wages policy is necessary as part of the process of reducing unemployment. Many other factors have to be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the beginning of my speech, I find it extraordinary that the Government is being assailed on this matter, as it were, by a former government whose commitment to a firm and effective wages policy was absolutely negligible. It was so negligible that we lost any wages policy we had in 1981 because the then Prime Minister had to get overseas to a royal wedding. That was how firm and effective the wages policy of the former Government was! The wages freeze is not a wages policy. It has never been a wages policy. I concede that it is a policy which relates to employment in some respects. To that extent the Government has sought to continue it to this time.

The other point which I should advert to, of course, is what will happen if this country starts to come out of recession. What wages policy did the previous Government have to meet that situation? This Government has a wages policy to meet that situation. Everything that happens now and in the next few months is relevant to our capacity to meet that situation. Everybody here knows what Australians are like. The moment the economy picks up a bit people start to stop thinking. We lapse back into the pursuit of sectional and sectoral interests. The capacity then to maintain restraint in all sectors of the economy is very reduced and it is very difficult. Therefore, it is important to have policies in place to cover that situation as well. This Government has such policies. We do not reject the essential element of the matter of public importance which has been raised today but we point out that it is a very narrowly based and narrowly conceived argument to put to the Senate in May of 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is timely that the Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance today. The speech of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has opened up a number of issues which I hope will be debated from time to time. He has not only touched upon wages policy but also looked at the structure of the work force of this country, the participation rates in the work force and the working life of all Australians. He raised the question of why we are not competitive in our trading within our country or with other countries. He has raised many questions. We would like to hear some of the views of the Government with regard to the matters raised by Senator Button.
—We would like to know if you have any views at all on those questions. You certainly didn't show much sign of it last year.

—The Australian Labor Party is in Government at present. It held the National Economic Summit Conference. It has a prices and incomes accord with the unions. The Government has a responsibility to the public in the forthcoming wages hearings. It is timely that we discuss some of the issues raised by Senator Button. I do not think the lack of competitiveness was disputed at the Summit. The Leader of the Government talked about attitudinal changes today. If those attitudinal changes are within the community in general-employers, union members and the Government-it seems that the events of the past week or two have brought some confusion into those attitudinal changes. There is confusion as to whether there is some consensus within the different groups in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated to hear Senator Button raise such matters as overmanning in industry. I was interested to hear him talk about penalty rates. These are the very issues that will need to be addressed by all of us as we look to regaining some sort of competitiveness for our products and for our labour. I think discussion of these matters is of very great importance. I do not think productivity was mentioned as one of the problems in this country. If we are to look at productivity we need to examine hourly rates of pay. The conditions, as well as the wages, in this country are part of our problem with regard to a lack of competitiveness. Unless these issues are addressed seriously by the Government, unions and employers we are not going to see the improvement that we wish to have.

One of the matters which I think was raised concerned lower income earners and the difficulties they face. We agree that there can be great pressures on those who are trying to pay their way when inflation is far too high. Those people are faced with problems. Their problems need to be contrasted with those of the people who are unemployed and who face greater difficulties. If there is to be some sharing of the burden it is of no consequence simply to look at those who are employed and at the maintenance of their real wages, whether over time or in the immediate future, and not at the same time to look at the problems of those who are unemployed and those who have yet to be employed in the Australian community. For those reasons the Opposition asks: What will be the Government's policies on these matters? We have agreed that having the Summit Conference bringing forward information and public debate on issues is a very healthy process. It has brought forward and given access to information and a discussion forum which can only assist in an understanding of the problem. But once one diagnoses the problem one looks for the cure, and the cure is what I think all of us need to address.

As far as wage restraint and the need for restraint in the demand of those who are selling their labour is concerned, we should look at the Summit Conference communique and the recognition throughout the Summit that at the time of seeking wage restraint there is a need to improve profits and to recognise the importance of profits if there is to be an improvement and recovery in the labour market. The sorts of things that developed at the Conference indicated the previous Government's approach of recognising the importance of wage restraint and profits in assisting those seeking employment or those seeking to retain their employment. Recognition of these things was achieved in discussion, but we need now to ask the questions that arise from the discussions at the Summit and the matters contained in the prices and incomes accord between the Labor Party and the trade union movement.

Last week, if we were asking questions, we could have posed them along the lines: Will the Government advocate an extension of the wages pause? I think that what has been said in the past few days leads us not to ask that question any longer because it seems obvious that the Government will not advocate an extension of the wages pause. If we were to address the question of what case the Government will argue before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the public interest, we would need only to look at the statements of a number of Ministers in recent days. They raised many questions in our minds about what will be the Government's approach in the public interest. The Government's submission to the Arbitration Commission should raise some of the questions that were raised by Senator Button in his speech today. Undoubtedly they are questions that need to be addressed by the trade union movement.

We welcome the changed attitude that has been expressed as being the attitude of the trade union movement. However, that leads us to ask the questions that arise from some of the statements of the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and his approach to the role of his trade union body on behalf of trade unionists. It has to be said that the ACTU obtained agreement on central wage fixation without having to concede anything on the enforcibility of awards that may come from the Arbitration Commission. I would think that that was a fairly important thing that was down the line and facing all of us. If there is to be-we accept that there is to be-a central wage fixing authority, what is the attitude of the ACTU with regard to the enforcibility of the awards that will flow from that wage process? What changed attitudes will we hear expressed by the ACTU with regard to the sectional interests that were to be suppressed by the trade union movement? If the Government members, trade union leaders and businessmen who were at the Summit really wanted to help those seeking jobs or wishing to retain the jobs that they had, I would have thought they would have accepted one of the harder options-the best outcome of the Department of the Treasury-at the Summit or, as was said by Senator Chaney, they might have looked for a further option, another scenario, that would have helped those who were unemployed.

There are obstacles to restraint that must be of concern to us. What is of concern to me is that employers and unions now appear to be adopting sharply contrasting interpretations of the Summit communique and the commitment to wage restraint. I suspect that what is happening with the ACTU and individual unions regarding the commitment to the Summit communique is that they would prefer the options raised in the prices and incomes accord that they settled with the Labor Party before it became the Government of this country. If the prices and incomes accord approach is to be the preferred course of the ACTU and individual unions, I wonder what sort of consensus we will find and what assistance that will give in the pursuit of wage restraint. It could become a real obstacle to wage restraint. I would think that if employers were to express their views-as they did-they would claim that there should be no wage rises outside the Arbitration Commission national wage adjustments. One could then ask: Why is it that at present we have individual unions pressing their claims? One must link that with the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday and what seems to be some sort of an agreement that in a short time there should be a 3 or 4 per cent wage increase. At a meeting to be held quite soon with building industry unions their individual claims will be pursued. These are the matters that I do not think anyone has accepted were within the Summit communique or people's understanding of it because they were not discussed properly and amplified in a full debate by those who are in the habit of pursuing debates of this kind. That is why the Parliament must do a great deal of debating on these matters.

If the Government persists with the approach that it will support the maintenance of real wages over time we will want to know what 'over time' means and what effect the pursuit of that policy will have on employment. I heard Senator Button say this morning that he had nothing to add to what the Prime Minister said yesterday in answer to a question by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) with regard to the effect on employment of a 3 or 4 per cent wage increase. I do not criticise Senator Button for not wishing to add to the answer that was given by the Prime Minister. It was not an answer. It would not have enabled him to clarify the outcome of a wage rise of that kind or enabled him to express an opinion about what would have occurred. It would have put him in conflict with a very confused non-answer from the Prime Minister when a very specific question was asked of him yesterday.

The Government seems to prefer that the magnitude of wage adjustments be determined by movements in the consumer price index rather than by relating them to economic capacity to pay or to productivity increases. That is another issue of concern. If we look at the maintenance of real wages through movements in the consumer price index without relating them to economic capacity to pay or to productivity increases we will not be heading down the track of doing something to improve employment prospects.

The reason the Opposition raised this matter today is that we are now finding in our daily Press not one or two approaches to what has been said by different Ministers, but today I think we had at least three interpretations of what the Prime Minister said yesterday about wage increases and the demands of the building industry unions. The various outlets of the media put their interpretation on what the Prime Minister said and that adds to the confusion that can occur when people are seeking guidance on the Government's approach. I wonder whether the approach to CPI increases and full indexation does not show that the Government has an inflation mentality. If one is approaching any sort of payment, be it a pension payment, a wage payment or whatever, and is always seeking full indexation, seeking to cushion the effect of inflation, I wonder whether the fight against inflation that undoubtedly ought to be undertaken is being undertaken. Various Ministers-the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr West, and others-have said that it is proper for unions to pursue claims for their improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said Mr West and others. Which others?

— I could refer to the remarks of the Prime Minister with regard to the building industry unions and his support. If we were to look at some of the statements that have been made in answers to questions we would see that there is not the wage restraint that was the concept that people embraced as a result of the Summit that was held with the unions and others in this place. The economic journals stress the difficulties in the pathways to recovery. The March journal of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd states:

SPEECH.PARA: With unemployment still growing . . . and the need for a reduction in real wages to help restore profitability and reduce inflationary pressures, there appears very little scope for an increase in real household disposable income in 1983.

Yet we are talking about increases. The ANZ Bank has drawn attention to the problems that have been outlined. We want to see a responsible statement from the Government of its approach to the public interest in these matters. I think we all wait with great interest and some anxiety to see the submission that will be made to the national wage case to pick up many of the points which were raised as questions by Senator Button and which, I hope, will be addressed by the Government in the interests of all Australians, both employed and unemployed .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been one of the most amazing debates put forward in this place in the time I have been a senator. Not only has the Opposition, in the presentation of its argument, bored the Senate almost to death but also it has come to us today with an amazing degree of effrontery and gall. Opposition senators forget that for the last seven years they have been in government and they have had the responsibility of producing wages and employment policies. They are now in a totally new situation. Suddenly they claim no responsibility for the past. They are looking to the present and blaming this Government for those problems. One thing has shown up this afternoon; that is, the sooner the Opposition gets Senator Withers on its front bench the sooner there will be some activity on its side of the chamber. Opposition senators talk about unemployment with some concern. It was their Government that in 1975 promised jobs for those who wished to work.
—Jobs for those who didn't work.

—In the time of their Government, unemployment doubled. As Senator Walsh said, the previous Government gave jobs to those who did not work. Unemployment now stands at 10.4 per cent. In the last Budget that the Liberal Party brought down in this place it allowed for an increase in unemployment in the vicinity of 190,000 Australians. In the last 12 months to March this year 271,000 Australians joined the unemployed ranks. The Opposition's policy was in fact to increase unemployment and to reduce wages, and it failed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at who is talking. Let us look at their economic record-their economic credibility. They promised to reduce inflation. Our inflation rate now stands at a level much higher than those of our competing overseas partners. We are far in excess of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development projections for this financial year. The monetarist policy of the previous Government has failed in this area. As economic managers Opposition senators claimed to be able to bring down the Budget deficit. In the last financial year the previous Government budgeted for a deficit of $1,700m. That has ballooned to approximately $6 billion, with next year's deficit, as we all know, estimated to be in the vicinity of $9 billion.

Unemployment, as I said, has doubled. The previous Government totally lost control of interest rates. It applied tight monetarist policies in order to control interest rates and interest rates in fact went up. Its economic policy had one direct effect; that was the effect of redistributing money and wealth from those in this community who could least afford it and those who would have been in the best position to spend money and wealth in order to generate economic activity. The previous Government did not generate economic activity; it failed dismally. Opposition senators now put themselves forward as economic managers with credibility. They lost that credibility over the last seven years. I am sure that people listening to this broadcast throughout Australia will find the whole exercise this afternoon somewhat incredible.

Let us look at the wages policy, the topic to which the Opposition wishes us to address ourselves this afternoon. In 1975, as a prelude to the election in that year, Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister for the last seven years, said:
We will support wage indexation.

He, together with his colleagues, some of whom are still on the Opposition front benches, spent the next six years undermining and torpedoing wage indexation. Let us look at what economic commentators had to say about this. Pat Mills, a reader in commercial and industrial law at the University of Sydney, said:
For five years now-
This was in mid-1981-
in the national wage hearings the Fraser Government has consistently opposed wage indexation, both the idea itself and its application in practice.

The previous Government came to office with a dishonest policy, and in its implementation of it was even more dishonest. In 1981 the whole concept of wage indexation was abandoned by the previous Government, substantially because of the effects of the Government's torpedoing of wage indexation, hearing after hearing. We found in 1981 a government totally at sea without any clear indication of where it was going. As I said, It supported indexation. It showed no record of support. In a Press statement from the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, dated 11 February 1981, he stated:
A centralised system in which national wage cases play a dominant role should continue in the present circumstances . . .

That was Mr Peacock-not in vacuum, however, because at that time the Liberal Government was totally undecided as to what direction it was taking. On 19 February, a very short time thereafter, Mr Peacock made a totally contradictory statement which highlighted the problem that his Government had in diagnosing the problem facing Australia, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle may wish to put it. An article in the Melbourne Age stated:
The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peacock, hinted at the move last night when he said the Government's present wage proposals sought to keep indexation alive 'in the short term' . . .
Mr Peacock said that when the Arbitration Commission inquiry was completed-
That was the inquiry appointed on that day-
there would be a need to take a 'long and serious look' at alternative wage fixing systems.
The article went on to highlight the problem which the Liberal Party had at the time. It continued:
Several Ministers believe a decentralised system, where wages are determined by collective bargaining, could be more effective.

So there was this conflict in the Liberal Party, a Party which now comes to us claiming to have some sort of economic credibility. The problem was highlighted again in the Budget Statements of 1982-83 which were brought down in this place by the previous speaker, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. In this respect I refer to page 52 of Budget Paper No. 1, which states:
With the benefit of hindsight such a bargaining process-
Here I talk about a decentralised process that had been in operation for some months--
can be seen to be still far too 'centralised' . . . to be able to take appropriate account of the interests of all the units involved.

Opposition senators were lost then, and they are lost now. I do not have to make this claim myself. All I need to do is to refer honourable senators to a statement of the present Leader of the Opposition which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 April 1982. This was at a time when he felt at odds with the rest of the Liberal Party, and especially the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser . Mr Peacock is quoted as saying:
In industrial relations, the most critical element is wages policy. Regrettably , there has not been a wages policy.
He was talking about his own Government. He said:

. . . there has not been a wages policy. When indexation was knocked out by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, no long-term plan was put down, and no interim policy was put down while you were working to a long-term plan.

So Opposition senators come here before us claiming to have some sort of economic credibility when the record and their own statements show that they failed dismally in pursuing policies on the same matter they have raised today. It is little wonder that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) could not even fill his time in the debate. He spoke for 15 minutes, and fell short of his allotted time by five minutes. One thing did happen under the previous Liberal Government and that was the instant-mix response of a wages freeze. It won the Liberal Government a by-election and, as Senator Button said earlier, it lost it the election. The wages freeze was applied towards the end of last year in the context that Australia's economic ills were all to be blamed on the Australian worker. Let me highlight for a minute the particular problem that Australian workers have had to face in recent years; that is, resources have been diverted from them to other sectors of the community, from people with no capacity to pay to sectors of the community with no need to receive the benefits of economic progress.

Let us look for a moment at wage and salary earners, those skilled workers under the metal trades award who consistently incur the wrath of conservative governments in this country. In 1947 under the Mooney award a fitter's wage was set at 113.8 per cent of average weekly earnings. In 1983 terms that would mean $386.92 a week. However, in 1983 the fitters wage is only $234.10 a week. There has been an inadequate increase in those wages.

When one looks at the fitter and compares his wage with that of the more highly paid wage earners in the economy one sees where the increases have gone. In this respect I refer to the increase between January 1973 and January 1983 of the salaries of adult males in six State capital cities-on the minimum wage. In that period the increase was 183.6 per cent. The consumer price index increase over that period was 200.2 per cent. One finds that the increase in wages has not kept up with the CPI increases. But when one looks at average weekly earnings- those earnings which last year Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Mr Anthony were keen to point out as evidence of a wages explosion-one finds that wages have increased by 258 per cent. So those on the bottom of the employment scale are the ones who have been missing out in terms of wage increases.

Of course that is extremely relevant when one comes to assess the claim put up by the Opposition that wages have by-passed inflation increases. Once again that claim ought to be hit very much on the head. I will do so quoting to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle her own statements. The Senate Hansard of 17 November 1982 shows that Senator Tate asked her whether it was not a fact that, whilst inflation had been running at an annual rate of 12.3 per cent, based on the previous quarter, average award rates had increased by somewhere in the vicinity of 11.7 per cent over that same period and not the 17 per cent or 18 per cent as had been claimed both by Senator Guilfoyle in Parliament that week and also by Doug Anthony in the conduct of the Flinders by-election campaign. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle is on record in the Senate as saying:

. . . I accept that there has been a change in the composition of the work force and that at the lower end of the working wage scale there has been a reduction in numbers which would be reflected in a reduction overall at some later time.

Let us look at this wage debate in the context of wage equity and justice. Let us look at it in the context of some of the things about which Senator Button spoke earlier in this debate. We need to have a wages policy. We have not had one for the last seven years, but if a wages policy is to work it has to be based on wage justice and fairness. The reason it has not worked over the last seven years is that we have had a government that has taken the approach, at wage indexation applications and hearings, that there should not be an increase at all.

I wish to comment now on the current situation. As I said, this Opposition is coming to us without any sense of credibility. In doing so it is nitpicking the Labor Government's current proposals to handle the area of wage fixation. When we were in opposition we recognised that for our policies to work there would have to be a degree of co-operation between government and unions, employees and business. It was to this end that we formulated the social compact. It was to this end that the present Labor Government worked towards having the National Economic Summit Conference. It was aimed at organising a consensus between all sectors in this community and a fair and just distribution of wealth in this community. In that context we talk about wage fixation.

The choice for this community is not as clear as has been presented in the last seven years. It is not a question of saying to one section of the communty, 'You cannot have increases', whilst on the other hand saying to companies and others: 'You can have any price increases that you like'. The choice is essentially one between a smooth and predictable wage fixation system and an erratic and unpredictable one such as that which operated in the last couple of years of the Fraser Government. We are committed towards the former-that is, a smooth, predictable system based on a centralised wage fixation system, a policy which the Liberal Party in government rejected totally and which now, in opposition, it is presenting as some sort of an answer to the problem that we have.

As I said at the start of this debate, it is quite incredible that we have members of the Liberal Party coming here parading as economic managers. It would seem as if they are coming to us as arsonists complaining about the bushfire. On that line I end my contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the critical importance of a firm and effective wages policy if unemployment is to be reduced. This debate was put forward as a matter of public importance by the official Opposition. So far we have heard a great deal about the need for Australian products to be competitive on international markets. We have heard a great deal about the need for wage restraint and the need to reduce unemployment. The argument that has been put forward by a number of speakers already today, that wage restraint will automatically increase our competitiveness on international markets and that this will then increase employment opportunities in those industries, is indisputable. Nevertheless, it overlooks several other factors involved in economic management and the approach that this Government and this country must have to economic management in the coming years. Some of those matters were raised in the Senate in December last year in the debate on the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill. They were put forward then by Senator Chipp. He raised them, in the main, in an amendment that he moved to the motion for the second reading. I would like to remind the Senate of some of the elements-not all of them-that were contained in that amendment. Senator Chipp moved at the end of the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate declares that to restrict wages only is an inadequate response to the present economic emergency, that the Government should take action to achieve reductions in prices and government charges for a similar period across a broad range of goods and services . . .

He listed a number of areas, including the freezing of Commonwealth Government charges, preventing profiteering, requesting professional and trade bodies to freeze their fees and the non-implementation of world parity prices for Australian-produced petroleum products. He ended his proposed amendment with the following statement:

. . . that the Government should take urgent and comprehensive measures to stimulate the economy, restrict imports, and call a national conference to begin a process of long term co-operative indicative planning.

The answer that the present Government gave to that was to accept at least the last part of that amendment, since I presume that that was what the National Economic Summit Conference that has just ended was all about. The motion that is before us today, however ignores a number of other elements in the points that have been brought forward. There are factors affecting the competitiveness of Australian industry other than simple restraint on wages, the cutting back of penalty rates and so on. We have to look at the effect of high interest rates on profits in industry, particularly in areas such as the housing industry. We have to look at the problem of turnover since this has a secondary effect on unemployment. Again I cite the housing industry as an example since any downturn in this area affects turnover in the white goods industry which inevitably affects employment in that area, as has been seen by the number of redundancies in companies, such as Kelvinator in South Australia. We have to look at forms of income restraint other than simply restraint on wages and salary.

Senator Chipp made the point in his speech in December last year that it was iniquitous to expect wage and salary earners to accept restraint in their incomes and the decreased standard of living that ensues if they can then see their solicitor, presuming they have one, their private doctor, whom they inevitably would have, and their accountant, if they have one, putting up their fees. I accept the fact that a lot of these professionals argue that anything between 40 and 70 per cent of the charges that they impose are due to the wages of their staff. There should be no reason, if staff salaries and wages are held down, for these people to increase fees with the glee and frequency that they do . However, their argument then was that government and other charges were not being kept down. This has occurred again in South Australia recently with regard to electricity charges which have a substantial effect on industry and professional earners' costs. Electricity charges in South Australia have gone up by over 30 per cent in the last 12 months. If the problem that is facing them with regard to increased costs of Cooper Basin natural gas keep on, those increases will continue.

To argue that unemployment will be significantly reduced if wage restraint is introduced, whilst ignoring restraints in areas of professional fees, in government charges, prices and so on, is really to put our heads in the sand. We have got to look at pegging these things as well. By putting a restraint on income is by no means the sole way in which unemployment can be reduced. Senator Chipp also made the point in his speech of December last year that job creation schemes were an integral part of this. He referred specifically to the introduction of high technology accompanied by retraining, compensation, taxation reform, income support schemes and transition measures which turn the potential catastrophe of technological change into a positive growth factor. I share the concern and the interest held by the present Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) in these areas and his belief that the biggest growth area in Australia's future will lie in the area of high technology development, providing we pick it up quickly and develop it appropriately to our needs. But it does require attention to research and development, to adequate training and retraining and to something of a changed attitude to what Australia is capable of doing. We have been locked in for too long to traditional attitudes to job creation in this country. It is time we looked with some imagination and initiative to the future.

One other point which has been overlooked entirely today has been the need to change another traditional attitude, that is, our attitude to unemployment itself. For far too long Australians have equated status and individual worth with employment and the level of one's income. It seems to me that when we are discussing problems that are facing the economy we must look at reappraising this traditional attitude to people's value in society. Certainly, while income is necessary if we are to survive, the whole emphasis which has been put on people's worth and status through their income has to be looked at. That, of course, is linked in with the attitude that it is only wage restraint which needs to be incorporated in improving employment prospects in this country. For too long those people who are independently employed have seen themselves as being beyond the touch of government regulation and imposts. Their status as independents, as professionals, is impugned, they believe, if they accept any regulations from the Government with regard to wage restraint. That, of course, has got to be challenged.

The Australian Democrats believe that a wages and income policy is a basic tenet of any economic policy. We believe though that a one-sided approach is doomed to failure, that incomes, prices, fees and charges of all kinds should be subject to restraint. For that reason we applaud the establishment of a price surveillance system as mooted by the National Economic Summit Conference communique. We ask that we do not lock ourselves into the argument that wage restraint is the only cure for unemployment but should look beyond that to a reasonable future and, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said as she finished her speech, this should be not only for the employed of this country but also for the unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not a representative at the recent National Economic Summit Conference. The Opposition parties were not invited and the unemployed were not represented. Small business, which is a major employment sector, also was not represented. The Opposition in its concern for the unemployed, for the employment generation potential of the small business sector , feels most keenly that wage restraint is the most available single action that can lead towards solutions. Although this was a major aspect of debate in the recent National Economic Summit, it is not reflected in the summary of the communique of the conference given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday. Therefore, it is a matter of urgency that I, as a Liberal senator from South Australia, and we, as the Opposition, bring the importance of wage restraint to the attention of the Government as being the outstanding omission in the Prime Minister's report and the single most important factor that can help the small business sector and the unemployed of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus spoke about the past. He talked about the difficulties of the earlier government and of past years. But we are not to be denied the chance now to represent our views in this debate. We believe that a part of the solution is at hand and that it has been underestimated by the Government. We urge the Government to take this matter up. Accordingly, I remind the Government in the debate today of the critical importance of a firm and effective wages policy if unemployment is to be reduced. This indeed is the subject of this matter of public importance. It was also the most central feature of debate in the House of Representatives yesterday and in Question Time in the Senate today. But beyond that, I put it to the Senate that this was the key feature for the last election.

On 3 February, when the former Prime Minister announced that there would be an election, he said that the issue before the people of Australia was wage restraint; that the wages pause was in jeopardy; that the unions had set out with the concerted objective to undermine the wages pause; that the then Opposition, the Australian Labor Party, was right behind them; that this was intolerable to the Liberal Government; and that we must get a reinforcement of that issue. The Government could now say that that issue was put by us during the campaign and that we were defeated. I do not believe we were defeated on that issue. We were defeated partly because of our record, because there was high unemployment, because of the ills of a depression and drought and because we had lifted the expectations of the Australian people to expect more from government. I believe that many governments, of whatever persuasion, have been thrown out in this time of recession in the world. I do not believe that the urgency of this important factor of wage restraint, in order to help the unemployed, to allow the cake to be divided more justly amongst the people of Australia, was defeated at that election.

I believe that this factor was also the sharpest distinction in our debates during the election campaign. Members of the then Opposition, the Labor Party, tried to give the Australian people what I thought was an irresponsible but very attractive offer. They said: 'Elect us and we will give you tax reductions'. Taxes will now be increased, but they promised tax reductions. They said: 'We will support, through our prices and incomes policy, the maintenance of real wages; so people of Australia, vote for the Labor Party. We will cut your taxes and allow your wages to rise. Vote for the Liberals and they will maintain this wage pause. They say it is responsible; they say it will help the unemployed. Privately, we think it will, but we want your votes. Therefore, vote for us'. That was the most distinctive contrast of the election campaign. I also see it as the issue that was the last straw in undermining the former Leader of the Opposition, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden. At first, Mr Hayden welcomed the Liberal Party initiative that there be a wage pause commencing in November last year.

Honourable senators will remember when six State and Territory governments and the Commonwealth Government had a conference. They agreed that a wage pause was in the best interests of the unemployed and all Australians. Everyone agreed to at least a six months, and possibly a 12 months, pause. The then Leader of the Opposition and leader of the Labor Party, Mr Hayden, agreed that this would be wise and in the best interests of Australia. But, lo and behold, the unions got to him and his own party got to him. They said: 'We will be denying our supporters if we accept that policy'. By the time the Flinders by-election was held early in December last year he had reneged on his previous position and said that he was not any more in favour of the wage pause. In January, after having time to think during summer, he said that it was in the national interest , after all. Mr Hayden came out with a strong statement in mid-January in which he said: 'Yes, we will do our best to make the Government's policy work'. He had got the message from the results of the Flinders by-election which the Liberals had won. But, lo and behold, the unions got to Mr Hayden yet again at the end of January. They said: 'You've swapped all over the place. You are seen as an ineffective Labor leader. We must have a new leader'. The Labor spokesmen got together at their Federal conference and asked Mr Hayden to step down because he had been all over the place on the subject of a wages policy and it was the last straw. The current Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was elected as the new leader. Throughout the election campaign he was ambiguous, equivocating and not at all clear because he wanted to give the cue to the unions that by electing a Labor government there would not be a wage pause.

The importance of the wage pause has been central not only to the debate in this session of the new Parliament-we had the chance to debate the matter yesterday in the House of Representatives and in the Senate today-but also to, and the most distinctive aspect of, the last election campaign. It was central also to the defeat of Mr Hayden as leader of the party. It was seen by me, by many spokesmen at the Summit and by the Opposition parties not as the only policy that will lead to a solution to unemployment and Australia becoming more competitive internationally, but as the only policy that is at hand and that can readily be implemented. By supporting this policy more of the unemployed will be able to re-enter the work force.

During this debate the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, asked for advice from the Opposition. He put three questions to us. He said: ' The Government would like to know from the Opposition why Australia is not more competitive internationally. The Opposition believes that this is because of our inadequate wage policy, but surely there are some other factors'. Of course there are other factors. They have been debated by us in this chamber over the last five years at least. They are, for example, the tax disincentives to Australia's industry and investors. We need to modernise and upgrade our technology. Even Senator Mason has urged that policy upon the Senate. We have to encourage it also. When we were in government the Minister, Ian Macphee, was our spokesman, linking science, technology and education. We need modern design. That was referred to during the Economic Summit. If we are to compete internationally we need better management. The honourable member for Mackellar, Jim Carlton, a member of the House of Representatives, has spoken around the country about the need to improve management techniques in Australia. We need better education structures so that school children will be better served towards the employment prospects that they will face. I have urged this many times in debates in the Senate. It has been the subject of Senate committee reports. It has been widely acknowledged and is starting to be implemented.

I believe that we need a general reduction in tariffs. We need to develop secondary industries in Australia which exploit better the raw materials and natural resources which Australia has in plenty, rather than merely exporting the raw product. Wage restraint is one of the more than half a dozen important factors, but it is the most available single factor that will lead, if understood by the Government, to improvements in employment levels. The second question which Senator Button asked the Opposition referred to the level at which wages and salaries should be restrained. Our answer is that they should be restrained to a level that will allow half a million currently unemployed persons to gain jobs in Australia; that will allow our current unemployment to be halved from 10 per cent; and, at the same time, that will allow a return to a normal level of profitability in Australia so that real, sustained new investment and growth can be restored.

Senator Button asked the Opposition a third question. He asked: 'What does the Opposition advise the Government to do at the end of the wage pause?' We have urged that the wages pause continue beyond six months, even beyond 12 months, into 1984. At the end of the wage pause the question of wage and salary levels should be referred in the normal way to the established authority-that is, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We urge the normal and expected outcome , that the Arbitration Commission hear views put by the parties and that the Commission make its normal decisions. Yesterday we heard the Prime Minister's statement on the Summit Conference. During Question Time today in the Senate I referred to pages 8 to 11 of that statement. I seek leave for those pages to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
I turn now to the more specific achievements of the Conference. At the broad level, I think there were three of about equal importance:

Firstly the degree of common understanding reached on the nature and source of Australia's economic problems-an achievement due in no small measure to the frank and detailed information and analysis put before the Conference by the Government and by many of the participants and observers themselves;

Secondly, the degree of consensus reached-as expressed in the Communique-on the basic framework and approach required to begin to arrest the decline in our economy, to arrest the expansion in unemployment levels, and, in an ongoing sense, to put our economy on a path of sustained non-inflationary growth; and

Thirdly, the recognition on all sides that the consensus reached at the Conference is only the first step and commitments have been given, again on all sides, to translate that consensus into effective action.

The main specific conclusions of the Summit are set out in the Communique which was tabled earlier in the House along with other documents submitted to or emerging from the Summit Conference. The Communique was virtually unanimously adopted; only the Government of Queensland, from the multitude of participants, formally reserved its position, though even the Queensland Premier by no means rejected entirely its main thrust and conclusions. Naturally not every conclusion and every piece of information shared in the Conference could find expression in such a document. What it had to cover was the principal message of the Summit, the main points of the framework within which we must all now follow up in setting about tackling the serious economic problems facing this country.

I would like now to point out to honourable members some of the more significant points made in the Communique. I will necessarily be selective, but would commend the document as a whole for close study by every Member of the Parliament and indeed by every Australian who is interested in his nation's welfare.
The key elements of the Communique, as I see them, are:

First, in paragraphs 2 to 5, recognition of the nature and sources of the serious economic problems facing the Australian economy, the need for a co- operative and innovative response to those problems, and, particularly, the recognition that to achieve recovery will require restraint in expectations and claims from all sections of the community except the impoverished;

Second, in paragraph 12, recognition of the importance of tackling the problems of unemployment and inflation simultaneously, and that an effective incomes and prices policy is essential if an expansionary fiscal policy is to be pursued without adverse consequences for inflation;
Third, in paragraph 18, recognition by the trade union movement that the maintenance of real wages will be an objective over time, during a period of economic crisis;

Fourth, in paragraph 20, consensus on a return to a centralised approach to wage fixation and recognition that a suppression of sectional claims is essential except in special or extraordinary circumstances;

Fifth, in paragraph 26, recognition that the Government has a mandate to establish a price surveillance mechanism and agreement on an examination into the most appropriate form of functioning of this mechanism;
Sixth, in paragraphs 24 to 28, agreement that if restraint is to be exercised then such restraint should be exercised universally, including in respect of dividends and non-wage incomes;
Seventh, in paragraph 31, acknowledgment that increased aggregate public expenditure may require increases in taxation or less than full tax indexation;
Eighth, in paragraph 33, recognition that priority in the social security area should be on real improvement in entitlements to those in genuine need;

Ninth, in paragraph 34 acknowledgment that, in the next session of Parliament, the Government would introduce a bill abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau and facilitating the amalgamation of unions;

Tenth, in paragraphs 43 and 44, agreement that the basic rights of women should be recognised and protected and on the need for imaginative policies to assist young people severely affected by the recession;

Eleventh, in paragraph 48, recognition of the importance of stable health policies and reaffirmation by unions that they will accept an offset in wage increases on account of the introduction of the Government's proposed health insurance scheme;
Twelfth, in paragraphs 50 and 52 stress on the importance of continuing the sharing of information to aid understanding of Australia's economic problems;

Thirteenth, in paragraph 53, general agreement that a small independent representative Economic Planning Advisory Council-EPAC-should be established to continue the process of consultation begun at the Conference; and

Finally, in paragraph 54, expression of hope that the Summit marks the beginning of consensus, not the end, recognition of the enormous amount of work that still remains to be done and commitment to that task.

All in the community have a part to play. For its part the Government has already taken a number of concrete steps to follow up the success of the Summit Conference by setting off firmly on the path to recovery to which the Summit pointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those pages set out the achievements that the Prime Minister wanted to bring to the attention of the Parliament from the Economic Summit. I concede that there were some achievements. It is important for the level of understanding of economic facts to be lifted and that was certainly achieved by the Conference. But there has been no action yet. That is why this debate is important, so that we, as representatives of the people-I, as a Liberal senator from South Australia-can put our views before the Government decides on a course of action. I urge the Government to give a much higher priority to wage restraint than is reflected in the Prime Minister's statement. For example, in the achievements listed by the Prime Minister, no mention was made of wage restraint; there were glib references to general restraint. I implore everyone to read those three pages containing the so-called achievements of the Summit, because when he got to the specifics there was no mention of wage restraint. He has ignored even Mr Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who at the Summit outlined the views of, presumably, the trade union movement when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU believes unequivocally that the priority of this nation must be employment growth. We therefore reject the policy prescription of fighting inflation first through increased unemployment. Such a policy is a policy of despair and defeat. We accept that seeking the achievement of lower rates of inflation and higher levels of employment will involve moderation in wage demands.
It was put even more clearly by Sir Keith Campbell at the Summit when he said:

The broad but very clear messages were: The longer the wage pause and the lower the wage adjustments, the lower the rate of inflation, the higher the rate of growth and the lower the rate of unemployment.
If it is not too late, we in the Opposition urge that, among all the actions available to the Government, there be such wage restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: - There is a Hebrew word which is pronounced 'chutzpah', I believe, and for which there is no precise English translation. It has often been described as a condition under which somebody who has just murdered his parents claims the mercy of the court on the grounds that he is an orphan. They are the people who presided over seven dark years during which unemployment trebled. They are the people who pushed the economy into the worst depression for 50 years. They are the people who allowed tax cheats to steal billions of dollars from honest taxpayers and finally left us with a $10 billion deficit which, in the week before the election, they said was $6 billion. Those very people now have the chutzpah to lecture a government that has been in office for two months about economic management and economic responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: When the last Government was clearly on the skids during February last, what did it try to do? The then Prime Minister tried to start a run on the banks. The present Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia then tried to start a run on the dollar; and he succeeded. Since the election they have been trying to start a run on the superannuation funds. As a result of the present Liberal Party leader's irresponsible action in touching off a run on the dollar, Australia has lost between $250m and $300m. That is a dead loss to the country. In that action Mr Peacock rewarded the most odious of all parasites-the international currency speculators. Effectively he took $300m off us and gave it to them. He has a record of being a successful economic saboteur. The behaviour of the Liberal Party in particular in that month before the last Federal election was reminiscent of Adolf Hitler, who in the final days of the Third Reich ordered Speer to destroy Germany on the grounds that the German people were unworthy of him. The doomed Liberal Government, led in the most appalling way by Mr Peacock, tried to destroy the Australian economy. He collaborated with the currency speculators while the present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party fiddled the books.

In mid-1981, after five years of sniping at the wage indexation policy, the Fraser Government finally scuttled indexation. It asserted that wages were best left to market forces. After five years of sniping it completely buried centralised wage fixing. Whether that decision was due to long-standing antipathy to the policy or to the prime ministerial desire to jump into a Boeing 707 and duck off to London for the royal wedding has never been entirely clear. But what is indisputable is that for the next 16 months we had no wages policy at all. The present Liberal Party leader in an interview in the Sydney Morning Herald published on 10 April last year said:
In industrial relations the most critical element is wages policy.
To a very substantial degree people on this side of the chamber would agree with that. Mr Peacock continued-remember, this was just over a year ago-by saying:
Regrettably, there has not been a wages policy. When indexation was knocked out by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission--
At the urging of the then Government-
No long-term plan was put down, and no interim policy was put down . . .

That was said just over a year ago by the present Leader of the Opposition. Then , at the end of 1982, the former member for Macarthur said that the Government had to be seen to be doing something. The former member for Macarthur was seen by many people to be doing quite a few things he should not have been doing when he was a Patrick partner. I notice that he is now working for the former Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party. It will be interesting to know whether he is applying to that task the skills he learned as a Partick partner. He said that the Government had to be seen to be doing something-not actually doing anything, but seen to be doing something.

That recommendation was taken up by the Liberal Party and the National Party and the then Government. It came up with a 12-month wage freeze. Having 16 months before completely torpedoed indexation and centralised wage fixing, the then Government did a U-turn and settled for the ultimate centralisation of a wage freeze imposed to the extent to which the Commonwealth had the power to impose it and, in collaboration with the States, announced its intention of imposing a total freeze throughout the economy. What would happen after 12 months had expired was and still is a matter for wide-eyed conjecture as far as members of the Liberal and National parties are concerned.

Of course, the truth is that the wages freeze was a stunt for an election, a stunt which the then Government hoped would get it past an election which it had to pull before the truth of the impending Budget deficit and the gross irresponsibility of the 1982 Budget became apparent to the public. In another Road-to-Damascus conversion Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle this afternoon described scenario C from the Summit Conference as the best outcome. It is interesting to note that that was the scenario with the largest deficit. That came from a very senior representative of a former government which had long been hooked on deficit fetishism. Indeed, fetishism was a recurring theme throughout the life of the Fraser Government. We had the fetish that large deficits and large deficits alone caused inflation; the fetish that full indexation and falling inflation were mutually exclusive; and the fetish that the public sector borrowing requirement was positively and at all times tied to interest rates. All those fetishes were contradicted from time to time by the empirical evidence. But they were still advanced as fundamental analyses of the economic problem and one-shot solutions to it.

The latest of the fetishes was that wage rises alone were the cause of the depression. That analysis was supported by the simplistic argument that if inflation in Australia-inflation being taken by the previous Government as being synonymous with wage rises-was higher that it was for our trading partners, ipso facto Australian industry must become uncompetitive. That analysis fairly accurately described the pre-1971 Bretton Woods world of fixed exchange rates. Whilst I am certainly not arguing that a government should be heedless of high inflation rates or reckless about the dangers of them, to a very substantial degree the international uncompetitiveness induced by higher wage increases in any country and consequential higher inflation rates is offset by adjustments to the exchange rate. The thinking of the Liberal Party in this issue was of the pre-1971 period, which I guess is perhaps fairly modern compared with its thinking on a number of other problems or the era to which many of its other ideas belong.

It is a truism that a country which has an adverse movement in its terms of trade and which is afflicted by drought at a given level of employment must either maintain incomes by borrowing overseas or real incomes, on average, must fall. The terms of trade did move against Australia and the country was afflicted by drought. The employment level was not given, but in fact fell. Because of those factors there are only two options-to maintain real incomes, on average, by borrowing overseas, which has been done to some extent, or real incomes, on average, must fall. I believe, and the Government believes and has made explicit on many occasions, that a fall in real wages is very likely an essential component of a package for economic recovery. But a wages freeze and the consequential fall in real wages in isolation is not a package for recovery, and could, indeed, exacerbate an existing recession.

The Australian Labor Party both in opposition and in government has made it perfectly clear that it believes that there must be restraint on wages growth. Even if that is achieved, the magnitude and the dimensions of the problem facing us ought to be recognised. If the present level of unemployment is to be brought down to the levels which were regarded as normal in the 1960s we require real growth in gross domestic product of 5 per cent a year or above for five consecutive years. To give honourable senators some idea of how difficult that has been to achieve, in only one year in the last decade has a growth rate of that magnitude been recorded. As I said, the Labor Party both in opposition and in government has made it perfectly clear that it believes that in the short term a decline in real wages is probably an essential component of a package for recovery.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated yesterday his belief that the economy could accommodate a wage increase of around 3 per cent towards the end of this year. There may be room for legitimate dispute about that but I think it ought to be recognised that we live in a dynamic society, not in an economist's computer and that there are political factors which must be considered as well as the arithmetic. The Labor Party both in opposition and in government has also stated that the real level of wages which prevailed a year ago will be restored or maintained over time. It has been stated that that goal is achievable. It is not in conflict with the acceptance of a policy of an interim decline in real wages which, to some extent, has already taken place. It is achievable because the productivity of labour continues to grow. It is not true, as is so often asserted by conservatives, that full indexation of wages ensures that a given rate of inflation becomes perpetuated. That is not correct because the growth in productivity allows inflation to be controlled and real wages over time to be increased.
