DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRADE AND COMMERCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Australian Fishing Industry

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 April 1983, on motion by Senator Coleman:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce presented its report on the development of the Australian fishing industry on 10 January 1983. Due to the election in March this is the first opportunity we have had to debate this report in the Senate. I say at the outset that this report was presented under the chairmanship of Senator Archer. However , I hasten to add that the Committee was unanimous in reaching the conclusions and recommendations made in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is the culmination of a detailed and lengthy inquiry and provides a comprehensive and critical examination of all aspects of the industry with particular reference to the implications for Australia and for the Australian fishing industry of the declaration of the 200-mile Australian Fishing Zone in 1979. Although the industry has assumed national and international recognition only in the last 15 to 20 years, the Australian fishing industry is today an important primary industry making a significant contribution to the national economy, particularly in terms of export earnings, which in 1981-82 amounted to $306.5m.

As an industry the Australian fishing industry shows considerably less co- ordination than any other primary industry of similar size and capital investment. During the inquiry it became clear that neither the State governments nor the Commonwealth Government have accorded priority to the industry or to its development. The declaration of the 200-mile Australian Fishing Zone signalled the beginning of a new period of growth and development for the industry. Scope for import replacement was also believed to be considerable.

Although the earnings derived from high unit value species such as prawns, rock lobsters, scallops and abalone have continued to rise, the high expectations raised by the prospect of the declaration of an extended Australian Fishing Zone have not yet been realised in respect of the development of new fisheries for the export and domestic markets. It is indeed a matter of great concern that Australia still imports 50 per cent to 60 per cent of fish consumed domestically and 35 per cent of fish used commmercially. While the value of the Australian fishing catch has been rising, the overall position of the industry has not improved commensurately and some sections have experienced serious downturns in their fortunes.

The Committee believes that the Australian fishing industry has scope for expansion. As the maximum sustainable yield is now being approached from the established high unit value fisheries which are directed towards overseas markets, it is now necessary for the industry to direct its attention towards the development of new fisheries, particularly species for import replacement purposes. The development of new off-shore fisheries will require a different approach from that adopted with the developed inshore fisheries. Exploitation of off-shore resources will require the adoption of improved fishing and handling techniques and the upgrading of Australian fishing vessels, which will in turn result in better quality produce and the promotion of Australian fish for both domestic and overseas consumption. It will also require that the Government direct greater attention towards programs of fisheries resource evaluation to provide the industry with the necessary data on which it can base commercial decisions and towards incentive schemes which recognise the high risks associated with the development of off-shore fisheries.

Since the declaration of the Australian Fishing Zone the Commonwealth has been required to extend its role in resources management, particularly in off-shore fisheries which fall within its jurisdiction. It has also assumed greater responsibilities for such matters as the conduct and co-ordination of fisheries research; the regulation of imports and exports of seafoods; the provision of financial assistance to the fishing industry; the control, monitoring and surveillance of foreign fishing; the provision of vocational training for fishermen and women; and the upgrading of navigational aids. The Committee has examined the effectiveness of the Commonwealth in fulfilling its role within these areas. It has also assessed the Commonwealth's effectiveness in promoting off-shore fisheries development and exploitation by both Australian and foreign fishermen. Responsibility for the administration of Australia's fisheries has continued to be shared between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory and the Committee has therefore directed its attention towards the adequacy of the co-operative arrangements for fisheries management purposes. It has also examined the effectiveness of the various mechanisms devised to promote co-operation and co-ordination between the public and private sectors of the industry. The other major areas of concern which the Committee identified were the inadequacy of present domestic fish marketing arrangements and the need for the industry to make a concerted and co-ordinated effort in the promotion of Australian fish.

At the commencement of the inquiry the Committee saw the Australian Fishing Industry Council as the means by which industry could contribute to fisheries management and participate in the decision-making process. While it is generally accepted that government-industry consultation and liaison improved following the establishment of AFIC the evidence presented to the Committee indicates that the industry's efforts to achieve greater participation in the decision-making and policy areas of fisheries management through AFIC and other government- industry liaison and consultative bodies have failed dramatically. The Committee has therefore recommended that the Commonwealth Government introduce legislation providing for the establishment of a national statutory fisheries authority which will create a formal framework for co-operation between government and industry in the formulation of fisheries policy and all aspects of fisheries management. It has also made specific recommendations concerning the membership, functions and funding of the proposed authority. It has further recommended that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) seek the views of all sectors of the fishing industry concerning any additional functions which the national statutory fisheries authority should assume. It is envisaged that this will leave the Commonwealth Fisheries Division with responsibility for issuing licences, monitoring foreign fishing activity and representing the Government at international conferences and forums dealing with fisheries matters.

In relation to marketing, the Committee believes that, unless there is a considerable improvement in domestic marketing arrangements, Australian-caught fish will not compete effectively against the imported product. One of the problems affecting the local marketing of Australian-caught fish is that there is no premium for good quality products and, conversely, no penalty for poor quality. This points to a need for a proper system of product grading for the local market. The Committee also believes that the consumption of Australian fish can be significantly increased by improved domestic marketing and promotion of locally caught species. It has therefore made several recommmendations concerning the marketing and promotion of Australian fish. The Committee's attention was drawn to the practice among some fishermen, restaurateurs and retailers of misrepresenting species of fish and to the practice among retailers and restaurateurs of claiming that fish is fresh when it has in fact been frozen . The Committee's view is that these practices can only harm the overall reputation of the fishing industry in the long term. The public relies on labelling or nomenclature being correct when it purchases fish and misdescription of fish or substitution of less favoured species for popular species will only hinder the development of the Australian fishing industry. The Committee supports the view of the Australian Fisheries Council that all governments in Australia should enact legislation to ensure prosecution can be undertaken for fish substitution.

I have already drawn the Senate's attention to the importance of the export market to the Australian fishing industry. However, the potential to increase this market is being frustrated at present by a number of unnecessary or inflexible government regulations. In particular, the Committee has recommended that a review of the Exports (Fish) Regulations be undertaken with the objective of amending standards to allow the export of lower grades of selected species which are acceptable to certain overseas markets. This, I believe, will help maximise our exploitation of the new off-shore fisheries and encourage the development of export markets for less preferred species and new fish products. Further, the Committee has recommended that mandatory labelling requirements for fish and fish products be simplified to include details required by the overseas buyer.

It was of some concern to the Committee that evidence was received, for instance, from processors, that frequently the information required by the importing country was not that which was required by either mandatory labelling requirements under the Exports (Fish) Regulations, or non-mandatory recommendations of the Department of Primary Industry fisheries inspectors. I can give the Senate a simple example, Mr Deputy President. We were informed that a contract had been obtained overseas for rather large amounts of frozen abalone . The requirement of the importing country was that there would be a statement to the effect that the net weight when fresh or packed was a certain amount. The Department, however, insisted that the packaging be marked 'net weight when thawed'. Honourable senators, particularly those of my sex who deal with frozen food in their own kitchens, would realise that the net weight of a frozen article when thawed would be impossible to estimate.

Finally, I wish to turn briefly to a number of other recommendations in the report. These concern: The development of a comprehensive national fisheries policy and guidelines for its implementation; the establishment of national objectives, priorities and criteria for allocating funds for fisheries research activities; the development of a uniform system for the collection of national fisheries statistics; the terms and conditions under which foreign fishing vessels should be granted access to the Australian Fishing Zone; and the provision of financial assistance to the fishing industry through the implementation of a national adjustment scheme and the introduction of a national development fisheries finance plan which provides incentives for the diversification of fishing effort and/or the develoment of new fisheries within the Australian Fishing Zone. In conclusion, I thank all members of the Committee , in particular the former Chairman, Senator Archer. I also thank all witnesses who gave evidence to the Committee and all others who contributed to the lengthy inquiry, in particular the Committee staff and its former secretary, Mr Chris Shrosbree. I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (PREVENTION OF POLLUTION FROM SHIPS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to the protection of the sea from pollution by oil and other harmful substances discharged from ships.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am pleased to introduce into the Senate this Bill and the Navigation ( Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill 1983, which I will introduce shortly, concerning the protection of Australia's marine environment against pollution. The purpose of the Bills is to give effect to the 1973 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships as modified by the 1978 protocol. The Convention is widely referred to as the MARPOL 1973-78 Convention. The Bills are essentially the same as those introduced by the previous Government on 21 October 1982. As the Senate is aware, the Government views very seriously the need for Australia to accede to and honour international conventions, not only in the transport field, which is the responsibility of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), but also in other affected areas such as the environment. Our national transport policy states explicitly that we will promote the conclusion, ratification and application of transport conventions under the auspices of the United Nations and its specialised agencies.

The particular subject of attention by this Bill is, of course, basically environmental in its origins and effects and I believe it is important to note the way in which concern for the marine environment has been incorporated so effectively. Australia has an extensive coastline and spread of territorial waters. It is fundamentally important that we be able to demonstrate to ourselves and the international community that we take our responsibility for this national and global resource seriously and that we are committed to its protection.

The MARPOL Convention is a departure from previous pollution conventions in that it addresses all the various forms of ship-sourced pollution in one treaty. The Convention contains five annexes which deal respectively with pollution by oil, noxious liquid substances carried in bulk form, noxious substances carried in packaged form, sewage and garbage. Initially, Australia will implement only the compulsory annexes I and II of MARPOL 1973-78-that is, those dealing with oil and bulk noxious liquids. In addition we will defer the operation of Annex II for the next three years permited by Article II of the 1978 Protocol to ensure that adequate reception facilities for the discharge of tank washings and sludge are provided at Australian ports.

The Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory are examining, in the forum of the Marine and Ports Council of Australia, the provisions of annexes III to V in order to arrive at a recommendation concerning their acceptance by Australia. The findings of this examination may well make it necessary to amend, in due course, the legislation currently before the Senate. The construction of the Commonwealth Bills is based on the jurisdictional arrangement recommended by the Marine and Ports Council of Australia which requires that complementary Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory legislation be enacted before Australia can ratify MARPOL 1973-78. The proposal is therefore in accordance with current arrangements between the Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory. The MARPOL Convention will be applied legislatively in Australia by two Commonwealth Acts and by State and Territory legislation. Implementation by two Commonwealth Acts continues the traditional way of giving effect to pollution control legislation.

The Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Bill 1983 will, upon proclamation, repeal and replace the Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act 1981 which applies the provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil known as OILPOL. The Bill also contains provisions imposing discharge prohibitions, the obligation to carry and maintain oil cargo record books on ships and to report any discharges. Matters pertaining to the construction, survey and certificate requirements of ships will be given effect in the Navigation Act. This method of giving effect to MARPOL 1973-78 has been adopted for simplicity of administration and understanding by the industry. This Bill introduces new and improved provisions for oil pollution prevention and control including special arrangements for protection of the Great Barrier Reef. This particular issue was included in the 1981 Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act which provides Australia with the enabling legislation to implement provisions of the 1954 OILPOL Convention which are not yet in force internationally. Following notification late in 1982 that MARPOL will enter into force on 2 October 1983, the MARPOL 1973-78 Great Barrier Reef protection measures will now enter into force earlier than the OILPOL provisions.

The Bill also introduces new controls on the operation of ships carrying noxious liquid substances in bulk. Specifically, provision is made concerning prohibition of discharges of noxious liquid substances into the sea, cargo record book requirements and cleaning of cargo tanks following discharge of cargoes. The protection of the Great Barrier Reef will be maintained in relation to noxious liquid substances by imposing outright prohibition or special discharge rules when ships are within particular distances from the outer edge of the reef. Differing rules are applied depending on the categorisation of the substance and its strength in the mixture being discharged. In many cases discharge into the sea is prohibited entirely.

The implementation of the MARPOL Convention in Australia will introduce stricter control of ship-sourced oil combined with compulsory ship construction and operational requirements which are designed to reduce the incidence of pollution at sea and in port. The Convention requires that ports themselves provide adequate shore reception facilities to receive ship-generated wastes. The Convention and the legislation to implement it are a marked improvement on existing arrangements and will place Australia in the international forefront in the field of marine pollution convention implementation. I therefore commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NAVIGATION (PROTECTION OF THE SEA) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Navigation Act 1912 and the Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Act 1981.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the second of two important steps in applying the provisions of the 1973-78 International Convention for the Provention of Pollution from Ships-the MARPOL Convention. In this Bill, Division 12 inserted by the Navigation ( Protection of the Sea) Amendment Act 1981 is repealed. The existing Division 12 has not yet come into force because it was included in the legislation to enable Australia to implement the 1971 ship construction provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships. Those provisions have not yet attracted sufficient signatures for them to have come into force internationally. The MARPOL 1973-78 Convention supersedes the 1954 Convention and therefore new requirements will be incorporated in the Navigation Act 1912.

This Bill inserts a new Division 12 relating to ships carrying or using oil and a new Division 12A making provision concerning ships carrying noxious liquid substances in bulk. These Divisions will incorporate in the Navigation Act 1912, provisions relating to ship construction, equipment, survey and certification for ships covered by the respective divisions. I mentioned in my second reading speech on the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Bill that all matters relating to construction, safety and survey of ships are incorporated in the Navigation Act. For simplicity of administration and understanding by the industry, MARPOL Convention requirements will be included in the Act now being amended by this Bill, in accordance with usual practice. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Reynolds.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Address-in-Reply be agreed to:
To His Excellency the Governor-General
May it please your Excellency-

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

It is indeed an honour to move this motion today and to follow my predecessor, Jim Keeffe, into this chamber. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the long and devoted service given by Jim Keeffe. His work on behalf of so many Queenslanders, indeed so many Australians, will long be remembered and his contribution in formulating policy will continue to have effect for many years to come.

I speak today in my first address to this chamber as a member of the Australian Labor Party, as a woman and as a senator for Queensland. These three loyalties shape my experience and determine my priorities as a member of this chamber. As a member of the oldest political party in Australia I come into this chamber knowing that I bring with me the loyalty and hopes of many thousands of Queenslanders. My contact with the elder members and supporters of my part has highlighted the rich historical tradition of the Australian Labor Party. I draw to the attention of honourable senators the speech of the first Labor member ever to speak in an Australian Parliament. George Black, in his maiden speech to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly in 1891, told the assembled chamber of professionals and entrepreneurs that Labor members 'have not come into this House to make or unmake Ministries. We have come into this House to make and unmake social conditions'.

Such a commitment is still fundamental to the principles of the Australian Labor Party today. In government it has had a sound record of introducing legislation designed to reform social conditions. It is a party of initiative. I too will be working for social justice. I will be placing priority on the making of social conditions which will better provide for disadvantaged groups.

Australia owes a better deal to its elderly citizens, its youth and those living below the poverty line. This nation ranks eighteenth out of 21 in terms of its welfare spending. Despite popular belief, it is among the lowest taxed and has low welfare spending when compared with other Western nations. I will also have absolutely no hesitation in working towards the unmaking of those social conditions which perpetuate privilege and power in the hands of the ruling class and overseas monopolies.

In assessing my priorities I speak too as a woman. I am aware that the last two elections have seen an unprecedented number of women enter Federal Parliament. Similar trends exist at State and local government levels. I welcome this. This chamber, with 13 women of the 64 members, has the highest proportion of women members of any parliament in this country. Yet, women are still a political minority, holding just five per cent of seats in Federal and State parliaments. Therefore, I recognise an ongoing need for women to participate to a far greater extent at every level of decision making if they are really to represent 51 per cent of the population.

I view with pride the effects of the second wave of feminism which began in Australia just a decade ago. I pay tribute to the many people, both men and women, who have worked assiduously to achieve greater equality for Australian women. In 1981 women welcomed the initiative of my colleague Senator Susan Ryan in introducing to this chamber a private member's Bill on sex and marital status discrimination. Therefore, it was commendable to hear from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) last week that ratification of the United Nations Convention on Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women will be finally proceeded with in the very near future.

But there remain many areas of economic and social deprivation among women. I mention in particular the problems faced by rural and provincial women. There is still a lack of recognition of the vitally important role of women in rural areas. Women take on the burden of farm duties in addition, often, to their roles as housewife, nurse, teacher and driver. Isolation and lack of services place very real hardship on women in outlying areas. As mothers they have to cope not only with the normal pressures of family care but also with limited access to medical and educational facilities and other support services. Job opportunities for rural women are fewer than for women in urban areas. Women in rural and provincial areas therefore have less chance of gaining appropriate training for themselves and for their children.

Transport and communication links are few and expensive. This highlights the need for the Mobile Outback Support Team, based in Mt Isa, which does outstanding work in bringing outback women together and lobbying for essential services. Such innovative schemes warrant extension and ongoing government support. I speak especially as a senator for Queensland and in doing so emphasise that I speak firstly as a representative of provincial Queensland and secondly as an advocate for non-metropolitan Australia. Having lived and raised a family in North Queensland for nearly 20 years, I know well of the disadvantages suffered by provincial Australians.

One in three Australians live in rural and provincial areas; that is, 33 1/3 per cent of the Australian population lives outside capital cities. I believe that there is an imbalance in the provision of services between provincial and urban areas. For example, Queensland is a vast State with strong regional loyalties. My city, Townsville, is 1,200 kilometres north of Brisbane-1,000 miles away, as the old bush song records. It is the de facto capital of a distinctive region. The tourist potential of areas north to Cairns, west to Mt Isa and south to Mackay is already recognised. The increasing number of interstate and international visitors annually reflects the importance of the tourist industry to north Queensland. However, this region's tourist trade is vitally affected by its isolation, which seriously influences the cost of providing services and bringing visitors into the north. Therefore, the stated policies of this Government-that is, to reintroduce the diesel excise exemption for Barrier Reef island resorts, to remove sales tax from the freight element of goods which are delivered to north Queensland, to negotiate for a 30-day fixed air fare for tourists-are all welcomed by north Queenslanders as indicative of the support they can expect from this Government in the future. I emphasise that it is this Government that is the first to introduce a policy for North Queensland.

North Queenslanders have always suffered from the tyranny of distance. That tyranny is not only a matter of endless hours of travel over roads which are an absolute disgrace to modern society. Nor is it only the inability to match the ever-increasing costs of air travel which could minimise that sense of isolation . It is also manifested in the economic, social, educational and cultural inequalities suffered by Australians living outside metropolitan areas.

From its earliest days economic growth of north Queensland has been linked with its mineral resources. It was gold that gave impetus for population growth and later it was the discovery of lead, silver, tin and copper which created new towns and attracted people to the North. Today coal and bauxite dominate north Queensland's mineral scene. But many people argue-I am one of them-that the real benefits of the so-called resources boom do not go to the people of north Queensland but rather to the capital city and overseas investors who usually have little interest in the region and little concern for the quality of life there. Governments too, particularly the previous one, are guilty of this lack of concern.

Queensland primary producers claim to have suffered a 75 per cent decline in their purchasing power over the past 15 years. They say that their inflation rate is many times higher than that of average wage earners because of gross discrimination against rural and provincial areas in terms of fuel and transport costs. In regard to education and cultural facilities too, provincial Australians are treated as second class citizens.

The annual general meeting of the Queensland Division of the Arts Council of Australia recently passed a motion recording its disappointment that the Arts Council there had been forced to reduce its touring program in 1983 because of lack of funds, thus depriving many Queenslanders outside the metropolitan area of access to the performing and visual arts. Its President, Sir Theodor Bray, said:
We are greatly concerned that country areas are not getting anything like a fair share of the Arts available to the Metropolitan area.
We do not exaggerate when we claim that Queensland, outside the Metropolitan area, will be culturally deprived, unless we get more support.

As a member of the Townsville City Council for four years I was constantly reminded of the centralisation of political power in Australia. Brisbane is even more ruthlessly centralised than Canberra was under the previous Government. I know that we will see a change with the new Government. Provincial Australians suffer from a lack of autonomy and have little control over decisions affecting their region. Too many bureaucrats and even, dare I say it in this chamber, some politicians show an arrogant disregard for the needs of people in regions beyond the metropolitan area. Yet it is the wealth and taxes of these regions that help provide so many facilities in capital cities.

My concern about the disadvantages of life in provincial Australia is strongly linked with my commitment to equality, that central aspiration of social democratic parties throughout the world. Inequality takes many form-class, race and sex-all of which create great disparities and glaring differences in life chances of individuals. Life chances are also shaped by locality. Socialist thinkers have been aware of this problem of spatial inequality for some time. The renowned Swedish economist Gunmar Myrdal, in Economic Theory and Underdeveloped Regions, wrote:

If things were left to market forces unhampered by any policy interferences, economic activities would cluster in certain localities and regions leaving the rest of the country more or less a backwater.
More recently, the English Labour economist, Stuart Holland, argued:

The regional problem is nothing less than the spatial dimension of inequality. It is an area which socialists have tended to neglect in favour of concentration on inequalities of class and social structure. Yet economic and social opportunities often are determined as much by the region as by the class into which people are born.

Obviously it is of absolute priority to me that this Government is committed to the formulation of policies which will overcome the inequalities experienced by provincial Australians. My belief in equality and my concern for provincial Australia both contribute to my commitment to a better deal for Aborigines and Islanders, who make up over 10 per cent of the population of north Queensland. Therefore, as a group, Aborigines and Islanders are as significant demographically in this region as Negroes are in America or Maoris are in New Zealand. The inequalities of class and race meet and are compounded in Aboriginal and Islander communities, especially those on reserves and missions and in isolated outback towns or the fringes of provincial cities.

Recent discussion raised by the Medical Journal of Australia has highlighted the appalling levels of Aboriginal mortality and morbidity on Queensland reserves. I further refer honourable senators to a report of a Queensland Government health team which screened the health of school children on Palm Island, a reserve off Townsville, in May 1981, a report which has been passed on to me as additional evidence of chronic health of Queensland Aborigines. The survey concluded that 148 Aboriginal children, or nearly 50 per cent, were stunted in growth and weight by poor nutrition and ill health. Some 73 per cent were clinically anaemic by the standards laid down by the World Health Organisation. Consideration of such shocking health statistics leads to a realisation of the vital importance of greater support for community health programs run by Aboriginal people. That is an essential feature of self- management and is inextricably linked with the question of land rights.

I do not wish on this occasion to embark on a detailed analysis of this issue, but I stress that the importance of land to Aboriginal communities cannot be over-emphasised if we genuinely seek to give Aborigines an opportunity to develop self-respect and independence. This is not the view of an outspoken minority but it is supported by a wide range of community and church authorities , including the Lutheran Church of Australia which recently visited Hopevale and Bloomfield communities, both long regarded as the most conservative in Queensland. In its report it concluded:

Local Aborigines have an innate and inalienable relationship to their land. Even where they have been legally dispossessed they speak of 'their land' and call areas by the names of their people. They know they have been pushed off and out, and today they are crying for compassionate consideration.

The claim for Aboriginal land rights affects less than 2 per cent of Queensland, yet it could provide the basis for self-determination for 10 per cent of its population. Current grim statistics of Aboriginal health and crime demonstrate that paternalistic management of Aboriginal communities is not providing solutions to massive social problems. A new direction must be found, and that involves granting Aborigines the recognition and respect to manage their own affairs.

In conclusion, Mr President, I will also place absolute priority on finding new directions to start to overcome some of the inequalities I have described today. In joining this side of the chamber I have absolute confidence in this Government and welcome the proposals presented in the Governor-General's speech. I believe these initiatives will start to move this nation towards providing solutions which will see a more equitable distribution of the nation's resources and a fairer deal for all Australians.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Reynolds on what I believe was an outstanding contribution as a maiden speech in this chamber. I trust that her continuing contributions will be of a similar standard to the contribution which she made this afternoon. Having the opportunity to speak this afternoon which I did not have yesterday afternoon, I join with others who paid tribute to some of those who are no longer with us-Senators such as Neville Bonner and Jim Keeffe, to whom Senator Reynolds made reference this afternoon. I endorse a number of things that were said, particularly what Senator Kathy Martin said about Senator Neville Bonner. But that is not the purpose for which I rise this afternoon; it is to address the motion for the adoption of the Address-in-Reply. In doing so I foreshadow that I shall move an amendment to that motion which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:
', but the Senate is of the opinion-
(a) that the program outlined in the Governor-General's Speech will result in higher unemployment and represents a callous disregard of the needs of the Australian people; and
(b) that the Governor-General's Speech fails to identify a legislative program for the implementation of the policies promised by the Government during the recent election campaign; for instance-

(ii) it fails to honour the commitment to reduce taxation,
(iii) it fails to develop any programs for better industrial relations,
(iv) it fails to develop any policies for the steel industry or manufacturing industry generally,
(v) it fails to honour the commitment to reduce the tax burden on small businesses, and

My advisors have assured the participants at the Summit . . . of the Government 's support and assistance in building upon the foundations laid so successfully at the Conference.

I ask: What were the foundations which were laid so successfully at the Conference? Was it really a successful Conference? I wish to refer to a couple of comments made by the media. David Potts, a well known contributor to the Australian, said:
And consensus was reached because no decisions of substance were made.
He went on to say:
The communique was not a contract, and the unions have signed nothing.
He stated further:
Instead employers have to give a lot away, while the unions gave away nothing.

. . . one must start listing the economic problems the summit did not tackle: Tariffs? Structural change in industry? Transnationals? Job-replacing new technology? Even wage indexation (shunted off to the Arbitration Commission as ' too hard')?

I ask all honourable senators to get together to try to identify in what way the Summit was successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both industry and labour felt that it was.

—Let us try to identify in what way it was successful. I am inviting honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber to respond. I am raising some questions and I am inviting honourable senators opposite to respond, if they wish to do so, as to the way in which they claim the Summit was successful. Increasingly a number of trade union leaders are claiming that it did not reach any agreement and increasingly people are analysing the Summit communique and are saying that it did not no more than identify that we all believe in motherhood. It did not really come to grips with what we are going to do about Australia and what we are going to do about the problem. SPEECH.PARA: 'At no stage was it ever put by me that this summit could be a determiner of how long the wages pause would last or what the circumstances coming out of that pause could be . . .' 'People who've tried to say that in some sense the summit may have been a disappointment because it didn't make those decisions betray, if I may say so, an abysmal ignorance of the constitution and institutions on wage fixing in this country.
But as the National Times pointed out to Mr Hawke and to any of its readers:
After that put-down we can regard that agenda item (3) (a) . . . listing subjects for discussion at the summit, states under the heading of 'Incomes': duration of the exit from wages pause'.

The problem which Mr Hawke had, after the failure of the Summit to come to grips with this, was to try to explain it away. That was his attempt to explain it away. I simply draw attention to it and identify it. If there is an explanation I am sure that honourable senators on the Opposition side of the chamber would like to hear what it is. The Governor-General's Speech went on to say:
The Government will develop a program of industrial regeneration to revitalise existing industries and seek new opportunities for growth in areas of high technology.

The Minister's waning--
I think it should be 'warning' but it might have been both-
follows Canberra reports that the Cabinet had given low priority to Mr Jones' input to next week's summit which aims at achieveing consensus for a national recovery.
Among the missed-out groups protesting at being snubbed, the ones with greatest potential as future wealth and job creators are the 'sunrise industries'.

Muzzling Barry Jones from discussing the employment problems which will be caused by technology will not solve tomorrow's issues . . . 'One is left asking oneself how fair dinkum is the Government in looking at the real problems facing the country and the growing generation.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity we cannot get a copy of the speech he had written.

SPEECH.PARA: Muzzling Barry Jones . . . will not solve tomorrow's issues.

What measures were announced in the Governor- General's Speech to revitalise existing industries? I cannot find any. I invite the Government to tell us. TALK.START.PARA: —When was it purchased?

SPEECH.PARA: The national airline, TAA, will remain in full public ownership. Consideration will be given to the capital needs of both TAA and Qantas and steps will be taken to place them on an improved commercial basis.

The Government is considering steps which might be taken to place the Australian Shipping Commission . . . on an improved commercial basis. Legislation will be introduced to provide financial incentives for the expansion of Australian's shipping industry.

The Federal Government is close to clinching a deal with maritime unions which would result in a capital injection for the Australian National Line comparable with that announced for TAA and Qantas.

Provision of the extra capital will be conditional on unions agreeing to reduce crew numbers on ANL ships to internationally competitive levels and to discontinue restrictive ship-board practices.

I am quite certain that in relation to that matter Senator Grimes, who has made a couple of interjections, and I, will find that there is absolutely no difference. I will not take time to deal with that matter in any more detail. TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I rise to second the motion moved so ably by my colleague Senator Reynolds. In doing so, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to pass on my congratulations to the President on his elevation to that office of President. I am sure he will carry out his duties with dignity and distinction. I am pleased to join you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and my fellow senators, as part of a Hawke-led Labor Government. On 5 March the people of Australia ringingly repudiated seven years of Fraserism. Nowhere did that occur more decisively than in the State that I am privileged to represent, Western Australia. In fact, it can be said that Western Australian was twice blessed. The two weeks between 19 February and 5 March-the weeks that herald the change of seasons from summer to autumn-heralded in Western Australia a change of political season from Liberal to Labor. Two weeks before the Federal election the Burke-led State Labor Government came to power. The figures of the vote on that occasion are interesting. Labor achieved 54 per cent of the vote cast, a swing of 7.48 per cent, and now has a seven seat majority in the Legislative Assembly in that State. Two weeks later, on 5 March, in the Federal election Labor improved on that swing, obtaining a swing of 8.2 per cent or 55 per cent of the vote in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that a number of observations and a plea should be placed on the record in view of those figures. The first observation I make of them-I think it is appropriate that it comes from a male-is that five of the new Labor members elected in the Western Australian State election are women. All won seats for the first time. Many of them obtained the biggest swings of any of the candidates. For example, Pam Buchanan, contesting the seat of Pilbara-it was said that a woman could never win the seat in that remote mining community- achieved a swing of 18.1 per cent. Jacki Watkins in Joondalup achieved a swing of 15.8 per cent and Pam Beggs in Whitford achieved a swing of 15.1 per cent. In the Federal seat of Canning, Wendy Fatin, who so ably moved the motion for the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech in the House of Representatives last night, achieved the second biggest swing of any House of Representatives candidate in Australia-13 per cent. Some observations can be made about those figures. Firstly, the figures indicate that the affirmative action program of the Australian Labor Party in selecting women candidates is successful. Secondly, the result removes completely and, I believe, for all time any suggestion that women candidates cannot succeed in being elected to office. Thirdly, it may even open the question that women candidates are a positive advantage to the political party they represent. The other point I wish to make- in many respects this may be regarded as a trite point in view of the figures-is that the Western Australian result represents a landslide in both State and Federal elections. It gives Labor a mandate in the State and Federal areas after seven arid years to do something about the economy, to improve the prospects for employment, to turn away the divisiveness that typified the previous Government and to turn the nation towards national reconciliation. Given the election result, the party occupying the Government benches in the Western Australian Legislative Assembly should not be frustrated in carrying forward its program. But already the Opposition in Western Australia has indicated that by use of its numbers in the Legislative Council it may interpose its will against the will of the people as expressed by the election of the Labor Government.

Some figures on the gerrymander in Western Australia should be reported. In the Legislative Council in the last election Labor achieved 51.3 per cent of the vote and won seven seats. The Liberal Party, with 45.7 per cent of the vote, won 9 seats. The National Party, with 3 per cent of the vote, won one seat. The metropolitan area, which holds 68 per cent of the electors of the State, has 14 Legislative Council seats. But the rural area, which has 32 per cent of the electors, has 20 seats. Almost 70 per cent of the electors live in the metropolitan area but return only 40 per cent of the members of the Legislative Council. Indeed, the North East Metropolitan Province has 85,906 electors and returns two Labor members. The Lower North Province, which returns Liberals, has 7,199 electors. That shows the graphic distortion. These figures, I believe, define the meaning of the word 'gerrymander'. That conclusion is not only mine. The West Australian newspaper, in an editorial on 2 March headed, appropriately, 'Power games', opined:

The Legislative Council, as it is constituted, is an anachronism. Public respect for Parliament cannot be maintained while a key section of the parliamentary system is subject to a gerrymander held in place for base political reasons.

The use, or threatened use, of numbers achieved by this electoral means is an exercise in anti-democracy. The Burke Government in Western Australia can consider that it has a mandate. It is in government, but without control of the Council is not in power. The plea I make is this: Let not words like 'fair', ' just', 'equal' or 'democratic' be used in this chamber or elsewhere to describe my State's voting system. Those words are not appropriate when such a savage rape of electoral reason continues to reign in Western Australia.

I turn to the Governor-General's Speech. I am pleased to note that after the introduction to the Speech the headings are, firstly, 'The Economy' and, secondly, 'Employment and Industrial Relations'. I will direct my comments to those areas. After seven years of conservative government Labor has come to power with Australia in deep recession-some would say in depression. We have high and sustained home loan interest rates. We have, despite a fight-inflation- first policy, high and double-digit inflation. We have a negative growth rate. We have a $9.5 billion deficit. We have two million Australians, as the Governor -General pointed out, living in poverty. We have, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 10.1 per cent of our work force unemployed. But if one applies to those figures the calculations of the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, there are another 5 or 6 per cent unemployed constituting hidden unemployment, putting the real figure of unemployment in Australia at around 16 per cent or well over one million.

On all fronts the economy which Labor inherited is deteriorating. Indeed, over the 25 years from 1955 to 1980 Australia fell from No. 5 to No. 12 in standard of living rankings within the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development group. As well as that economic chaos we have inherited a loss of national confidence, a confidence that was lost by virtue of the selfishness, divisiveness and confrontation which epitomised the Fraser years. In the two months since Labor has come to power there has been a rekindling of the national spirit. We now have direction. The National Economic Summit Conference last month was an historic event. It was perhaps the most historic event since the Depression. That Summit has achieved a new direction for Australia. It is interesting that the last speaker should ask: What did the Summit achieve? I want to list what I believe, as an observer of that Summit, were some significant achievements. Firstly, the business community has moved to an acceptance, albeit in broad terms, of the prices and incomes policy approach. It has rejected the fight-inflation-first view and adopted the view that we must fight unemployment and inflation simultaneously. There is an acceptance of the need for price surveillance. Indications of support from within the business community for a fair capital gains tax have been obtained. There is overwhelming support for a centralised wage fixing system. There has been acknowledgement of the need to maintain real wages over time and there has been acceptance of the need for restraint from all sections.

Two other major developments should be noted. The mystical fascination with the deficit has been addressed in a new light. No speaker at the National Economic Summit expressed the view better than the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Kelty, when in the most admired speech of the Summit he said:

However, the size of the deficit in dollar terms is only one aspect. Of greater importance is its relationship to the size of the economy as a whole; that is, the Budget deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product and the size and direction of the change in the deficit compared to the previous year's Budget outcome.

In terms of deficit size in relation to the economy Australia, with a current deficit level of about 3 per cent of gross domestic product, is well below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 4 1/2 per cent .
He went on to quote from Dr Peter Sheehan's view of deficits, a view which I endorse, and concluded:

In endorsing that view it should not be taken to follow that we simply believe that the deficit can be set at any level. Therefore we have no difficulty accepting that there will be some necessary limitation on the size of the deficit. However, in recognising that the deficit itself is an objective, we believe that the size of the deficit is not a starting point in any proper analysis.

The key question is not so much the amount of the deficit, although of course that is important, but the reason for it. If the deficit blows out, as it did under Fraser because of the drag of the unemployment benefits, handouts and other throwaways, it is a deficit of despair. If it is caused by job creation funds and other stimulatory measures it is an investment in the future. If it is an example of Rooseveltian priming of the pump, it is a deficit of hope. The Summit also endorsed the Government's stand on tax avoidance. Honourable senators may recall that in 1981 Professor Russell Mathews, a consultant on taxation to the previous Government, said:

The essential problem is not to make the rich pay higher rates of tax than the poor. It is to make the rich pay any income tax at all. There has recently been some discussion about the potential for tax revolt in Australia. It must be recognised that a massive tax revolt has already taken place, but it is a revolt of business taxpayers against wage and salary earners, of the rich against the poor.

Honourable senators will recall that last year Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association estimated that the loss of revenue to the Government through tax avoidance and evasion was marked at the level of $7 billion, and thus a high cost was imposed on all taxpayers to meet the cost that had been defaulted by the evaders and avoiders.

The Summit was a start. It needs to be strengthened and developed. It is a start on tripartitism as a need for further direction of our economy. When we look at the economies around the world which traditionally are similar to ours and which are performing better than ours we look at such countries as Austria and some Scandinavian countries. They are distinguished by the presence of a prices and incomes policy. Those countries have unemployment levels of around 2 per cent and inflation levels of around 4 per cent. The objective of the Summit and of the prices and incomes accord reached between the Australian Labor Party and the ACTU is to aspire to that goal and the aim of the Government is to reach that goal. In those circumstances those who chip away at the base of the Summit, deride its achievements or try to undermine its success, chip away at the attainment of that goal for Australia.

Before coming to this place I was for 17 years a trade union official. For eight of those years I was Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia and an executive member of the ACTU. Since 1981 I have been a junior vice-president of the ACTU. I want to spend the last moments of this address concentrating on some aspects of industrial relations. Firstly, it should be remembered that Australia has a high percentage of union membership; 56 per cent of our work force are members of unions. Those who attack unions should remember , therefore, that they are attacking a majority of the working community and a majority of the families in Australia. The Government aspires to protect the interests of the majority and of the majority of families. Often the attack on unions takes the view that it is the fault of unions that strikes occur. It is rarely acknowledged, if ever, that the fault often lies on the side of the employers or, as during the period of Fraser Government, on the side of that Government by virtue of its exploitation of industrial relations issues for base political purposes.

Rather than attacking the effect of a strike-no one wants them, least of all the workers-the most important question that should be asked is: What causes ordinary Australian men and women to voluntarily forgo income for a certain period in order to achieve some end benefit? If we look at that question we direct our attention to the cause of industrial disputation, not to its effect. The effects have to be considered, but the effects will be resolved only if the cause is resolved. In looking at the cause of industrial disputes I draw attention to a list of priorities. Before I do so, I should say that the whole debate about strike action in Australia tends to ignore one fundamental and more important aspect, that is, that more time is lost to our economy and more damage is done to our citizens by the level of industrial accidents and occupational hazards that exist in the work place than is attributable to strikes. Last year the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Macphee, in an address to the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, said:
Australia is shelling out at least $4 billion a year for accidents and injuries in the work place and losing one million man weeks a year.

It is interesting that Mr Macphee also admitted that it was the first time the Government had attempted to calculate officially the financial toll resulting from work accidents and occupationally induced sickness. In my view those figures are conservative. If the real calculation were made one would find that twice or maybe three times the amount of damage is done to the economy by accidents and disease in industry than is caused by strikes. If we have a priority to cause industry to establish a base for better development, it is to lower the frequency of accidents and to overcome the impact of disease in industry. That is the starting point and the first point that should be made in any debate about strikes.

Let me now turn to strikes and their causes. I believe that there are three major areas. The first is living standards, which I believe is properly answered by the existence of the prices and incomes policy. That does two things of great importance. It guarantees a sense of equity to wage and salary earners who know that they will not be the ones who shoulder the burden of sacrifice on their own to achieve growth in this economy. It also guarantees to them that their reasonable expectations will be realised over time. If people have a sense of confidence and security and are not cast into the market place having to maximise as best they can whatever advantages they have, that feeling of confident expectation, I believe, overcomes the fear that strike action might be necessary lest one's living standards deteriorate. The answer to the first problem is a prices and incomes approach. That is the approach of this Government.

The second area is the need for job security. Last year over 50,000 Australians were retrenched. This year the level of apprenticeship intakes is down; there is a slippage of between 25 to 30 per cent in the number of apprentices taken on board by industry this year as compared to last year. Jobs are being lost simply because there is not enough protection for workers against redundancies and there is not sufficient training and retraining to enable people to move smoothly from one area of employment to another. Our level of industrial training and skill is dropping. When the world turns to countries with high levels of skill, which will survive best in a rapidly technological future, it will be to those countries that have invested most in training. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Observer recently reported that the West German Government had set itself a target of training 80 per cent of school leavers to the level of tradesmen. In Japan the objective is closer to 90 per cent. In Australia we train about 29 per cent of school leavers to that level, and that is not true of all States. If we are to provide greater job security we need to invest in training to provide the skills for industry to grow, so that with an increasing technological future jobs will be made available, not go off shore, and Australians will find work. That is a prime consideration.

The third area I raise is that increasingly the reasons for strikes cited by the Bureau of Statistics centre on the heading 'managerial policy'. Under that heading a number of things that originate from management occur, and that is the second major cause of strike activity. Again, if we look abroad we discover that those economies similar to ours which do better than us in terms of industrial disputes are distinguished by another feature which is absent from Australia. In those economies an advanced and mature form of industrial democracy is practised , whereas in Australia, by and large, it is absent. We run industry on strict hierarchial control. We do not tap the intelligence and ability of workers to the full. We do not involve them in management decisions or in key aspects of how the activities of a company should be divided, what are the goals of companies and what the needs are to distribute the wealth of companies. In those countries that implicate workers in decisions so that their voices are real and they are not transitory or exploited, industrial disputation falls as management and labour confront each other with a common goal of improving industrial performance for the sake of greater productivity and a greater advantage in the longer term.

I note that in this chamber during the last session Senator Siddons introduced legislation in the field of industrial democracy. Whilst I have some reservations about the nature of that legislation, he is to be commended because he made a positive start in that area. I look to this Government, of which I am a part, to continue that action and develop an industrial democracy program that will enable Australian workers to have a say in Australian industry for the benefit of the Australian community.

I conclude by saying that all those things are fundamental and important to me but that overall the most important issue is, I believe, that of world peace. We face a world that is sharply divided between the super-powers and in which the arms race grows apace. Since 1981, when President Reagan made his famous pronunciation that a nuclear war is winnable, the idea of nuclear war being winnable is taking root. I think that overriding all the considerations of our community is the need to obtain nuclear disarmament in the world so that all people can carry out their lives dissenting or agreeing between themselves on the basis of a confidence that the world and the community will survive.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Reynolds and Senator Cook on their maiden speeches. I wish them well in their sojourn in this place. This evening we are participating in the Address-in-Reply debate. The Governor- General's Speech heavily emphasised the so-called mandate that the Government was given for consensus, co-operation and reconciliation. Under that mandate the Government held what it labelled the National Economic Summit Conference. The purpose of that Conference, I believe, was to achieve consensus between industries and unions. That is certainly what the Australian people saw as the purpose of the Summit. We were told by Mr Hawke that it was bringing Australians together. As such, I wonder whether it was too much to expect that some of the more difficult questions arising in those areas of major disagreement between business and unions could have been faced and answered. That business and unions did not come to agreement was to me a great disappointment.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just itemise a few of the areas that I believe should have been faced and on which agreement should have been found. How long was the wage freeze to last? When the Liberal Party was in government it put forward the view that the wage freeze should continue until the end of 1983. The then Opposition disagreed . Mr Hayden opposed the wage freeze altogether. Mr Hawke then said that he thought it might not be such a bad idea. At the National Summit the Government said, as it says now, that it believes that the wage freeze certainly should continue until at least June. But no decision was taken on how long the freeze should last, what should happen at the end of it, whether there should be some sort of catch-up and, if so, when.

A decision was made to return to a centralised wage fixing system. With that return, what factors should be taken into consideration when the amount of the increase is to be judged? Should the consumer price index, productivity or some other factors be taken into account? Again, the parties did not come to any agreement on the matter, so no decision was taken. They decided to leave these hard questions to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The parties at the Summit having made that decision, surely they should have then agreed that when the Arbitration Commission came to a decision all parties concerned should at least agree and abide by that decision. But we could not even get that agreement. We know that employers have been bound by the decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the past and will continue to be bound by them in the future. They are bound by awards. If they disagree with an award and decide not to pay according to its provisions they are fined. But, of course, the situation is not the same in the case of the other party to an Arbitration Commission hearing. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission can come up with all sorts of decisions, as it has already done in the Builders Labourers Federation case, and with all sorts of conditions, as it has done in the wide combs dispute. The employers are forced to abide by them, but the unions do not. If they do not like a decision they just do not abide by it and that is all there is to it. They go on strike.

The Summit handed all the difficult decisions over to the Arbitration Commission. The one major decision that would have helped in that handing-over would have been that all parties must abide by the Commission's decisions when they are made, but the Australian Council of Trade Unions said: 'No, we could not possibly agree to that. There could be no agreement in that regard'. Another one of the main decisions that had to be made, I believe-it certainly was recognised-was that profits needed to rise. The ACTU, the employers and the Government all decided that profits needed to rise if expansion in employment was to be achieved. How was that to be done? How would profits be increased? That is a simple question. Not only did the parties fail to face that issue and come up with any decisions on how profits should rise, even in certain industries; they came to the decision that there should be a prices surveillance mechanism. To anyone, even in this chamber, a prices surveillance mechanism is completely in opposition to the recognised need for profits to rise. The Summit even came out with a mechanism which was contrary to one of its agreed recognitions.

Some other matters were brought up in some of the speeches. One was penalty rates. No one was going to face that hard question because the unions would not countenance it, so the Summit could not decide upon the abolition of penalty rates. The need was expressed but the parties could not even talk about it. They could not discuss the 17 1/2 per cent holiday loading either. No decision was taken on that matter. The same applied to the size of the deficit. Good heavens, what has that to do with the Summit? The Summit could not come up with an agreement as to the size of the deficit, yet it was held in order to put the economy of this country on its feet again. The method of taxation-whether increases should take the form of direct or indirect taxation-was not discussed. These questions were all too hard for the Summit and it did not come up with any decisions in this area. Mr Keating certainly expected more. In his opening speech he said:
If this Summit is to succeed it will need to do more than put forward proposals that sound like programs . . . but are really only statements of goals-not methods of attaining them.

Nothing in the final communique underlines to me or to anyone firm methods of attaining those goals that Mr Keating was hoping might come from the Summit. In contrast to Mr Keating's optimism at the beginning of the Summit, the communique formulated at the end of the Summit states:

The Summit stresses that the Conference was never intended as a forum to negotiate the timing or quantum of wage increases. It is accepted that this is a matter for the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

It was never intended but it could, and certainly should, have come up with the timing of the wage freeze. It should have decided how long the freeze should go on and the quantum of increases to be given at the end of it. Judging by Mr Keating's early comments at the Summit, I am quite sure he expected that sort of decision, at the very least. We could well ask why the Summit did not come up with the answers to these tough sorts of questions. All I can suggest is that the captains of industry were all intimidated by their presence in the chamber across Kings Hall. They were not prepared to be seen to disagree publicly in any way; they were intimidated by the whole affair. I wonder how Sir Peter Abeles, a friend of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), is feeling now that $115m has been provided as a gift to Trans Australia Airlines in complete opposition to his policy of open and fair competition. The Governor-General, in his speech, claimed:

The agreement reached at the Conference contains the basic framework and approach to enable Australia to begin to arrest the serious economic decline and place the economy on a path of sustained, non-inflationary growth. My advisers have assured the participants at the Summit and their representative organisations of the Government's support and assistance in building upon the foundations laid so successfully at the Conference.

So we have this final agreement, this final communique. It all sounds like sweetness and light. Yet today Senator Button, when asked about the final communique, said: 'Look, let's get it clear. The important point about that final communique is that it was an expression of changes in attitudes. It is not really an agreement. It is not binding and it is not a legal document.' The crux of the whole Summit is the agreement arrived at. Is that agreement to be abided by or is it just an expression of attitudes by the participants? I am quite sure that the employers are expected to abide by the final communique. They are expected to abide by the decision to return to a centralised wage fixing system.

TALK.START.PARA: —They agree with it.

—They were not in agreement with it. The honourable senator had better return to his seat is he wants to interject. They certainly were not in agreement with it, but they did reach a consensus and agree to a return to the centralised wage fixing system. They were also expected to agree to the Government's setting up this price surveillance mechanism. The communique is not a legal document but, of course, the employers will be expected to agree to that . As I have said, Senator Button just says that it is not a legal document. There certainly has been a change of attitudes. Senator Button says the situation just reflects the change of attitudes of the people present at that Summit. There has certainly been a change of attitude since that Summit.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Summit we had the ACTU agreeing that 'a suppression of sectional claims is essential except in special or extraordinary circumstances proved before the centralised wage fixing authority'. Now the ACTU is backing the oil industry's claim. It is also backing the building union's claim and the $40 a week increase for the crane drivers in the Australian Capital Territory. I wonder why there has been this sudden change of heart by the ACTU. At the Summit it agreed that there should be no sectional interests and now it is backing the oil industry, the building union and the $40 a week increase for the crane drivers in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is also backing down and all the ideals of the Summit are crumbling about his feet. Mr Norm Gallagher of the building union can intimidate others and not just the witnesses at the Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. He can also intimidate the Prime Minister of this country and, indeed, has done so because the Prime Minister has now stated that there is room for an increase in the building employees allowance which is specific to that industry and not capable of a flow-on. So Mr Hawke has now succumbed to Norm Gallagher. Why would Mr Hawke say that unless it were the case?

Let us look at what the Summit has done for industrial relations. The Summit was held from 11 to 14 April. On 11 April 122 stoppages were recorded. That was before the Summit started. In the week ending 8 April there were 124 stoppages. The Summit did a lot for industrial relations, did it not? Let us look at the statement of accord between the Australian Labor Party and the unions. Page 9 of the accord states:

In formulating claims for improved wages and conditions at the national level the unions will have regard to government economic policy and will consult with the Government on the amount of such claims.

That refers to conditions and claims. I do not know whether anyone else is aware but I certainly am not aware that the people responsible for those 124 stoppages consulted with the Government. I am sure that with this new Government's decision for open government we would have all been told about it, but I certainly have not been. I do not think anyone else in Australia has been consulted about the reasons for these 124 stoppages or knows whether the Government gave permission for the 124 stoppages. The ACTU has no intention whatsoever of abiding by that accord. No wonder Senator Button is backing off and saying that the communique is not really an agreement and not a legal document but just an expression of attitude, the important point being the acknowledgement of a change in attitudes. If I were Senator Button I would be saying that the Summit really is not binding, that it did not come to any agreement and that it was really just an expression of attitudes by the participants at that Summit.
