In 1980 we came within 500-odd votes of winning-I believe the closest vote on record-and still missed out winning a seat. Thanks to the continuing support and confidence of the Australian Democrats in Western Australia at our third attempt we were successful. This spirit is typical of Democrats around Australia. Not only are they caring, concerned people but also they have a dedication to this country which is an inspiration to all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now evident that Australians from all States recognise the value of having a third independent political force in this country. Third parties are not new to Australia. However, the Australian Democrats not only hold the balance of power in the Senate but also offer genuine alternatives to the confrontationism of our political system. My Democrat colleagues and I can and will act positively to break down the polarised nature of parliament. We will continue to act as watch-dogs and we will exercise the mandate we have been given. We will propose alternatives to government policies and we will initiate legislation and debate in areas we believe to be important. The three party system will benefit the Senate and our system of government but most of all it will benefit our constituents as their respect for a constructive, concensus seeking parliament evolves.

This Government, according to the Speech by the Governor-General, wishes to make many parliamentary and electoral reforms. These are vitally important. They will continue the democratisation of government. The proposed reforms are also important because they are making Australians think about the nature of our government. In general, it could be alleged that many Australians are not concerned, or aware, of the inequalities and impracticalities of the present system of government. Reforms such as those proposed are valuable because they increase the awareness of the Australian population.

The Australian Democrats have introduced to this country, and, indeed, to the world, a new style of participatory democracy. Our democratic method of deciding policies, the election of our leaders by the total membership of the party and the right of any member to initiate policy or constitutional change, has set a pattern for participatory democracy which this country would do well to follow. It is exciting to see that the other new political party making a substantial mark on politics in the English speaking world-the British Social Democratic party-has adopted these methods to develop its own policies. I commend to this Parliament the concept of citizens' initiative which enables a representative group of citizens to initiate legislative or constitutional changes through a system of referendums.

I support the Bill of my colleague Senator Mason which would establish this right if a successful referendum followed. In my State of Western Australia only the government of the day can bring about constitutional or electoral reform. A conservative government-from which my State has suffered or benefited, depending on one's point of view-has had absolute control of the Parliament since the day it was first opened. The gerrymandered upper House is a parody of democracy. One can understand the frustration of Western Australian citizens who realise that there is neither a constitutional nor democratic means for them to reform the upper House of that State. The very Constitution itself can be changed at the whim of the parliament of the day without reference to the people. The establishment of the rights of ordinary people to petition for a referendum binding on the Government is a vital step in reforming our political systems across this nation.

The Australian Democrats are committed to the introduction to Australia of a new era of industrial democracy. There are many exciting developments in other countries which could be used as a guide to far better industrial relations and to a concept of participatory industrial decision making. We want to enhance both the rights and the job satisfaction of people in the work force. We will pursue the legislation introduced by one of Australia's great exponents of industrial democracy, former Senator John Siddons, I hope with the support of the new Government and the Opposition.

The Australian Democrats recognise the values and virtues of a mixed economy which provides for an appropriate system of support for those in need, together with an environment which encourages individual enterprise by individuals and groups. Nonetheless, this country suffers from one of the most restricted, protected anti-private enterprise economic systems in the free world. Governments have not only constrained free and open competition but also have protected large monopolistic enterprises and industries, frequently to the detriment of the smaller enterprises. The Australian Democrats believe the economic wellbeing of Australia rests with individual enterprise, especially small business. In place of constraints and barriers, small business people should be encouraged, given incentives and supported by the Government. The kiss of life to small business not only will revive the most dynamic sector of the economy but also will create jobs and stimulate demand for goods and services. Small business employs 65 per cent of the Australian work force and is growing.

To alleviate unemployment it is surely logical for the only expanding area of economy to be nurtured. For far too long Australia has suffered from ad hoc government economic planning. This is partly caused by the relatively short three-year parliamentary term. That period is shorter for some governments. It is apparently endemic to our system that even if the government does engage in long term indicative planning for its own purposes the rest of the community is denied access to this information. No major enterprise would survive very long without long term plans. It is imperative that the governments of Australia provide the economic guidelines within which Australian enterprise must function . I welcome the dissemination of information by this Government and its moves to introduce indicative planning for a number of industries. The Australian Democrats would like to see these moves extended and co-ordinated by a small, open and independent agency.

We have little cause to be proud of the actions of some Australians within our own country. Australia is one nation and yet a minority wishes to see Australia divided. This minority has argued, for instance, States rights in regard to the Franklin Dam issue. It is not a States rights issue; it is an Australian issue; it is an environmental issue. In the past decade we have witnessed a resurgence of national feeling and cohesiveness. It is a shame that this should be destroyed by the inappropriate use of States rights arguments. The States do have powers and responsibilities and they have fulfilled a valuable role. Notwithstanding the nature of the States, government needs to be brought closer to the people. Power needs to be dispersed from national and State levels to a level much nearer to the grass roots of Australia. Local government needs to be more effectively used for instance. Regionalisation and decentralisation will be a positive step in beginning to develop Australia's most important resource, our people. Australians are the most valuable asset Australia has. We need to develop and nurture this human capital and ensure that it is utilised to its fullest extent.

In particular, we need to examine education-its role, its content and its funding. Education is an investment in the future. If Australia is to reap its rewards we need to invest heavily now. Tertiary and post-secondary educational institutions are catering for more students yet their funding is not being increased correspondingly. More funds are not the only answer, however. The nature of education itself must be examined. Students cannot benefit from tertiary and post-secondary education if they are mistrained or discarded by inappropriate secondary schooling. Likewise, primary and pre-primary education are vital building blocks in developing our human resource. But education is more than buildings and teachers. The Government has a duty to create a national environment within which learning and personal development are encouraged.

Education has to grow hand in hand with high technology in this country. As society adapts to high technology Australians, both young and old, must also adapt. The use of computers and the development of a technological awareness need to become an integral part of every Australian's preparation for future years. High technology must become a tool rather than a master. This will occur only through increased knowledge, awareness and experience. The education system , therefore, has a crucial role to play. Individuals must be valued more than technology. Technology must be developed and employed but not to the detriment of individuals. It is the Government's responsibility to ensure that technology does not create a society in which people are increasingly superfluous. The importance of the individual is paramount. Technology must be adapted to aid the growth and aspirations of society and those within it. Unemployment, particularly among young Australians, is a problem related to both education and high technology. Unemployment is Australia's greatest social problem.

Unless both education and high technology are developed with an awareness of this problem the social cost to Australia will be immense. The status of the individual must be lifted. In modern society there is a frightening tendency for the individual to be subordinated to supposedly more important institutions and necessity. The basic human rights of every Australian must be formally recognised and entrenched by all governments. Australia must have a Bill of individual rights. History-even current events-has demonstrated that elements in our society ignore and suppress those rights. Discrimination must end, particularly in relation to race and sex. Australians must be encouraged, educated and, if necessary, even coerced into stopping discrimination. The plight of the Aboriginal peoples must be redressed and handicaps imposed by society on those people must be removed. Australians and the Australian Government must increasingly recognise the value and status of individuals. We must be aware of handicaps-physical, economic or as a result of discrimination- and be prepared to act to redress the inequalities that do exist. Every person, no matter what disadvantage he suffers, should be able to participate in and be a valuable member of our community.

Individuals while having rights also have responsibilities. Each and every Australian has a responsibility to fellow Australians and to future generations of Australians. This responsibility is becoming increasingly recognised in regard to the environment.

It is every Australian's responsibility to ensure that the Tasmanian South West wilderness area is preserved for future generations of Australians and the rest of the world. It is pleasing to note that a majority of Australians already acknowledge this responsibility. Similarly, we must protect other portions of our national heritage such as our rain forests, waterways and endangered coastal areas such as the Great Barrier Reef and Cockburn Sound-in my State-and our rare timber forest areas such as the beautiful jarrah and karri forests in Western Australia.

It is our responsibility, as Australians, to ensure that apart from research and medical purposes nuclear energy is never used in this country. This country has the resources and the expertise never to need nuclear energy or a nuclear fuel industry of any kind. Nuclear waste is a legacy which we cannot leave to future generations.

I am pleased that the new Government has acknowledged the debts that we owe to other Australians and our children. The Australian Labor Party has come to government with long-overdue initiatives and reforms. The Government it replaced had become complacent and was not responding adequately to the needs of Australians. The reputation and economy of Australia and the great individualism of Australians has grown as our rural and mining areas in the back blocks of this country have thrived. But as a nation we have been inclined to take from our rural and mining areas all of the benefits without returning an adequate share to the people who live and work in those areas.

This is not simply a matter of compensating people for living in difficult environments-in fact many Australians far prefer those environments to the city lifestyle-but rather a matter of recognising our national need to enhance the quality of life in those areas. The people with the courage, fortitude and initiative to work in those areas will have children with the same qualities. Those children must be given the avenues currently denied them but which are available to childen in city areas. The women in rural and mining areas are renowned for their resilience, their ability to tolerate hardships and their initiative. It is not acceptable to take advantage of these qualities and simply let these people provide the wealth of the nation without reaping, at the very least, rewards equal to those who live in the cities.

Whilst Australia has an adequate health service system, so much emphasis has been placed on the economic and repairing aspects of our health system that we have tended to ignore the urgent need for all governments to encourage the concept of preventive health. I believe that by fostering sport and other health giving activities, by educating for better eating habits and improved lifestyles , the people of Australia will live happier, healthier lives. From the economic point of view the cost of health repair will gradually decline. One can understand that given the choice of spending millions to put out the fire of bad health today, a government may not be inclined to spend additional millions on preventing that fire from starting. This is one of the difficulties which any government has to face up to: Is it willing to invest in the short term for benefits which will accrue to a subsequent government, maybe decades later? I hope that this Government is not so short-sighted as its predecessors and will move the emphasis towards building good health for all of our people.

I commend the new Government's proposed programs, its attitude that there is much to be done within Australia and that it is time for initiatives and reform. While there are some ALP initiatives and policies with which I do not agree, I applaud the spirit of co-operative development that the new Government has already shown. I have but one reservation. Will this new Government ossify, as did the old Government? Will we see the spirit of initiative develop into a docile air of complacency? Will the concern of this new Government degenerate into a lack of concern and an acceptance of the status quo? Only time will tell. Australia has had a breath of fresh air. It is vital that this breath does not slowly fade and become stale, that Labor in its turn does not pursue power for power's sake.

Australians, with people around the world, are becoming increasingly aware of a number of global issues. Environmental issues are becoming more important, but nuclear power and nuclear weapons are the issues of greatest concern. The campaign for nuclear disarmament celebrates its twenty-fifth anniversary this year when its support is at its peak. The concern for peace is becoming so great that the average person is becoming aware of and involved in anti-nuclear movements. The Greenham Common women's peace camp is an example of the growing concern and growing fear. It is a concern that has prompted Australians also to march and demonstrate. It is imperative that the proliferation of nuclear arms be halted. A nuclear war threatens civilisation itself. The Black Death, the fate of the Roman Empire, the Thirty Years' War would be nothing compared with the effect of even a limited nuclear war.

In addition the establishment of nuclear-free zones must be encouraged, particularly in the Indian Ocean. The nations around the Indian Ocean have little to gain from the presence of nuclear weapons. However, the world has much to gain from the establishment of a large nuclear weapon-free area of the globe and Australia, of course, has a vested interest in such a zone. While the Indian Ocean nuclear-free zone is only a concept, Australia has with other nations maintained another peace zone which has had reality for 22 years. I refer, of course, to the Antarctic Treaty. This was established as a zone free from military activities, and has encouraged international scientific research and co -operation. It appears that this 30-year treaty will be successful for the whole period. It is hoped the new treaty which is being negotiated will be as successful.

Australia has helped to achieve one nuclear-free zone and it is crucial that we combine with other nations to create others. We Australians should be proud of our participation in the Antarctic Treaty.

I am sure that honourable senators will understand the concern of a Western Australian when the topic of defence is discussed. Our State has the longest coastline of any in the Commonwealth. It is vulnerable to drug importation, illegal immigration and criminal infiltration. A fleet of relatively small, fast , quickly deployed naval vessels providing surveillance around our coastline would be preferred to, for instance, a single aircraft carrier, wherever it might be deployed.

Probably no other country has the opportunity and the environment Australia has to develop a great multicultural society. With our abundant resources, our ample living space, our generally tolerant society and our many established networks- such as the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Special Broadcasting Service and our sporting and cultural networks-Australia is uniquely placed. The enrichment of the Australian lifestyle, through the infusion of some of the world's oldest and richest cultures, has set a pattern from which Australians and the world can benefit. The Australian Democrats will support and encourage in every way possible the development of attitudes throughout our society which enourage Australians from other cultural backgrounds to bring their cultural wealth with them. At the same time they can adapt to those parts of our lifestyle which suit their needs. Thus, our new citizens will enrich our society , give to their children the values of two cultures and obtain a fulfilment they would otherwise lose were they compelled to reject their former culture.

The Australian Democrats bring to this Parliament a truly reformist attitude. Let me be clear. Our nation has existed in an international backwater for years while other progressive, reform governments have overtaken us. The Governor- General has indicated in his Speech that the new Government plans some long- overdue reforms. We need bold innovations. We need a spirit of constructive co- operation and a new inspirational level of political integrity. My Democrat colleagues and I intend to ensure that the Government fulfils its responsibilities to all Australians. I shall try not only to be a prompter and a watchdog but also to present initiatives to this Parliament. The very presence of Australian Democrats in this chamber is a sign that the Australian people want traditional confrontationist politics to be replaced by a consensus- orientated approach. Australians need to work together to face the challenges which lie before us. If Parliament can lead all Australians in working for the good of this nation and the individuals who comprise it, it will fulfil its responsibility to the whole nation. I and the Australian Democrats will do our best to achieve this end.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate requests the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to initiate a new program for young people aged 16 to 21 years to alleviate the worst effects of unemployment in this age group by:
(a) the introduction of permanent part-time work without penalty in the form of reduced unemployment benefits;
(b) encouraging businesses and unions to co-operate in making at least one work place per enterprise available, worked on a roster basis, for young unemployed people; and
(c) providing many more part-time and full-time educational and training opportunities for unemployed people.

I think this is the first initiative in the new Senate to deal specifically with unemployment, although the previous Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes ) did mention it from time to time during his comments in the previous debate. It is no accident that it is an early initiative from the Australian Democrats. We stressed heavily throughout the last election campaign that the major problem of this society is unemployment, especially youth unemployment, not only for the obvious economic reasons but also because of the enormous social impact on so many young people who finish their education and are then told that society has no work for them and no need for them. They are told to stay at home, presumably to medidate on their predicament. If they use their time to go to the beach; bush walk or anything like that they risk being labelled as dole bludgers, although I am very pleased to find that that word is being used less and less in society.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an overstatement.

—Indeed so. This situation is absolutely intolerable for young people. It is something like road accidents, an intolerable situation to which we have somehow accommodated ourselves. We talk about it endlessly, preferably in general terms, so that we do not actually have to do anything. It has caused unnaturally high rates of illness and mental breakdown among young people. It has also increased the suicide and crime rates. These things are well established by a large variety of authorities. They are now beyond doubt. I suggest to honourable senators, through you Mr Acting Deputy President, that we should not be surprised at that. We should understand that these evil manifestations are intrinsic to the situation. The problem is, of course, urgent because of those things. It is quite possible to ignore or overlook individual tragedies, but by ignoring them we do not remove the fact that they exist and continue to happen or mitigate to any extent the suffering that they cause.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have patiently waited out the various talkfests with which the Government has occupied its time so far. The National Economic Summit Conference was of course useful. It had its values in general terms but I have perceived nothing it has done to solve specific problems in this society which urgently require solution. The other talkfest, the Constitutional Convention, appears to have been a complete disaster and an utter waste of time and public money. However, it is of interest that the Summit promised co-operation and consensus between the unions and employers on our problems. The time has now come for the Government to put those fine words into action and get something done. We appeal to it to tackle the area of youth unemployment immediately and in certain specific directions with which we believe it would not entirely disagree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion before the Senate and the amendment that was proposed earlier today by Senator Peter Rae on behalf of the Opposition. That amendment rightly draws our attention to the very considerable difficulties which arise when one closely examines the Governor- General's Speech. I should make clear one thing at the outset; that is, that the Governor-General's Speech is prepared for him by the present Government and does not contain his own words. Consequently, any reflection that I might make upon his Speech tonight cannot be read as a personal reflection upon the Governor- General. I hope that Senator McIntosh, who is attempting to interject, will be very wary of this. I hope that he has his Standing Orders before him should I do that.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues arise out of the Governor-General's Speech upon which I would like to comment although they were ably dealt with by Senator Rae in his remarks earlier this afternoon. Before I attack some of those points I would like to have a look at some of the issues which are concerning my own State of South Australia, the State I represent in this place. One would know from a coursory understanding of the economic scene at the present time that South Australia is suffering substantially from the economic recession. One of the reasons for that is that it has a very heavy manufacturing industrial base. That has been understood by successive State and Federal governments. We know that the reasons for its development have been organic but it has also been brought about by various government policies over the years, in particular, of course, the non-regard for very essential, economic facts of life by State governments, starting from about 1970 onwards, led by successive Labor Premiers. I refer in particular to the Dunstan Government in the period from 1970 to 1979.

During that time some of the concerns which had developed in South Australia- they were quite clearly pursued by former State governments, particularly the Government led by that Premier of South Australia, Sir Thomas Playford, who sought to keep the costs of manufacture in South Australia lower than other States-led to an industrial boom. Subsequent State governments did not have regard to those factors. They tended to concern themselves with things such as social issues rather than the basic facts of life which were the determining factors in the quality of life of all South Australians. We saw a divergence from these essential factors to other concerns on the part of the State Government of South Australia. The net effect was a gradual decline in the state of efficiency of South Australian industry.

That certainly is a very broad statement and obviously there are exceptions. Clearly, some industries and particular firms in South Australia have developed very forward looking policies in manufacturing. It might be said by some that they are far more forward looking policies than those in other States. I can instance firms such as the Simpson Pope organisation and Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd which have developed very forward looking policies, both in regard to industrial relations and production techniques. Those things have helped to maintain job stability and improve the job situation in South Australia. But clearly there remain very real difficulties while there is such a heavy investment in that industrial base in my State.

In recent times we have been searching for alternative industrial bases upon which to develop job opportunities for South Australians. The former Liberal Government under Dr Tonkin spent considerable time, energy and funds in searching for minerals. This has been going on for some years and it cannot be claimed that this happened only under the Liberal Government after 1979. But obviously the incentives and encouragement given by people in the Liberal Government of that time brought about substantial investment in various areas in South Australia. One instance, of course, is the Roxby Downs project which has already been an enormous fillip for the potential development of the State. It has lead to 300-odd jobs being created at Olympic Dam.

Other uranium developments are also on the drawing board. I might mention the hapless Honeymoon project and the Beverley project in South Australia which are now under very considerable threat as a result of the decision of the State Labor Government in recent times. I draw to the Senate's attention the position in regard to the Honeymoon project. Most honourable senators would know that considerable development work has been undertaken by CSR Ltd and its partners in relation to the development of the Honeymoon project. With the advent of the Federal Labor Government on 5 March a new policy in relation to uranium development has been formulated, directly as a result of Federal decision making . I refer in particular to the announcements made by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) which have led to the very clear understanding that, in the event of any new project being got under way, no uranium export licences will be granted to the miners of uranium.

That has been the stated policy of the Australian Labor Party in the federal sphere. Of course, Senator Walsh, upon coming to office, has applied that policy . He has applied it to the detriment of my State of South Australia. He has deliberately caused people to be disemployed in the uranium industry. This lowers the potential for the development of other job opportunites in other parts of the State, not just those jobs which could be related to the mine itself. All honourable senators know that enormous spin-off opportunities arise from mining. Not merely those few people actually engaged in mining are the main beneficiaries of job opportunities. Those who can be engaged to provide facilities, services, engineering know-how and back-up are the main beneficiaries of this kind of development. South Australia badly needs that kind of support and development as it has the second highest percentage of unemployment of all the Australian States.

For that reason honourable senators on the Opposite side of the chamber take a very dim view of the deliberate implementation of policies by the present Hawke Government which have led to fewer job opportunites in South Australia, not more as the Government promised before the election on 5 March. There is very real concern about that matter in South Australia. It is not all the fault of the Federal Labor Government. In fact there have been very considerable disincentives and the destruction of confidence in South Australia as a result of the Bannon State Labor Government having made similar decisions about the Honeymoon and Beverley projects. There is very real widespread concern in the State about the potential for resource development.

The development of those resources is absolutely vital to the establishment of an alternative industrial base in South Australia. We do not require a total change from what exists at present but we need to complement it, to provide opportunities by which we can develop the State and create an inflow of people such as existed in the period preceding the advent of State Labor governments from 1970 onwards. The people of South Australia are seeking that kind of opportunity. I am sure that when they voted both in the State elections in November and in the Federal election in March they did not fully comprehend the results of their actions in supporting the election of Labor governments. I do not believe that they understood that so many jobs and potential jobs would be lost in South Australia as a result of the advent of a Federal Labor Government and of a State Labor Government. It is not to overstate the case too much to say that those opportunities which did exist before November last year do not exist now. As Liberal members on this side of the House we want to see the State go ahead. We are prepared to work for that. We will be working as hard as we can for that reason to see the election of Liberal governments both at State and Federal levels, governments which will be committed to the development of the States, which will be committed to the resource development of the State and which will be absolutely committed to job creation in South Australia to provide opportunities for the young people who are leaving school even at this time. It is those opportunities that we will be working to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could this be because Roxby Downs and the other resources are not being developed?

—Roxby Downs is one aspect of this whole problem. Of course, job opportunities have already been wasted at Beverley and at Honeymoon as a result of the Australian Labor Government's policies. It is a very sad thing to represent my State of South Australia in this Federal Senate and to see governments, both at State and Federal levels, so committed to the destruction of job opportunities for young people.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kilariff-Yet they have the resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they have the resources and yet they, for so long in the election campaigns at both State and Federal levels, argued that they were the only ones who were concerned about young people. They claimed that they would create 500,000 jobs in three years and yet the first thing they did in coming to power-particularly in regard to my State-was to destroy jobs. That is the reason why this Federal Government and the Bannon State Labor Government will not be in power very long and will not have the support of South Australians. I will move to one or two other points that were raised in the Governor-General's Speech. I would like to draw attention to one particular point because of my own personal interest over many years in small business. Specific reference has been made in the Governor-General's Speech to the small business area. I will read one part of that statement which points out the Labor Party's interest in this area. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government . . . to ease the tax burden as budgetary circumstances permit and to improve managerial skills.

I hope that the Government will start first by improving its own managerial skills, particularly those of the political government and the members who occupy the treasury benches both in this place and in others. In the last six or eight weeks that the Government has been in power we have seen no evidence at all of any managerial skills evolving. In fact, its only defence in trying to achieve anything at all is to blame everything upon the former Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is where the blame should be. It created it.

—Here we go again. In other words, the Government is not prepared to face up to its responsibilities. The first lesson that any small businessman learns is that he has to face facts straight in the face and make firm and hard decisions. This Government is not prepared to do that. That has been obvious from the events over the last eight weeks. It is clear that the Government is committed to making no decisions and is blaming us from here on for what it perceived to have been the problems which were created as a result of our period of government. It is totally false. We will demonstrate that fact in the course of this debate in the next few days.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just make this point about small business. The Labor Party campaigned before the Federal election on the basis that it was going to immediately lift the tax burden for small business. A specific promise was made which was that small private companies would have undistributed profits tax abolished. For years many of us have stood in this place and argued for that. It is a very important incentive for small business to have that profits tax abolished. But what is the first thing that the Government does when it comes into office? It reneges immediately in the Governor-General's Speech by saying that it-it is not even specific about it-will relieve the tax burden as budgetary circumstances permit. This is a pathetic performance. The Government conned people into believing that it was really interested in small business. For the first time in history, in living memory that I can recall, did a spokesman ever mention anything specific about the problems of small business-that came from the Labor Party-or even understand what undistributed profits tax was? As soon as the members of the Labor Party reached the Government benches they reneged on that promise.

Unfortunately the Governor-General's Speech is seeded with lots of these kinds of reversals. Where the people of Australia expected action they got review. The Speech is sprinkled with words like 'review' or 'will be considered' or 'is under consideration' or words to that effect. Clearly, as I mentioned to Senator McIntosh earlier, this Government is a non-decision making government. It is not prepared to face the hard decisions. It is not prepared to face up or ship out. It does not understand businessmen and in particular small businessmen who have to live with hard decisions every day and have to make them in the light of economic circumstances and get on with the job. We wait with interest to see what this Government will do as Senator Peter Rae so ably pointed out during the debate on the steel industry and the manufacturing industry generally. This was pointed out in the amendment to the motion for the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech which Senator Rae has moved in the course of this debate.

I will move to one other particular area of interest in which I have had involvement in recent times; that is, in connection with veterans' affairs. As the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs I instituted a total review of the repatriation legislation towards redrawing the whole legislation, set up the machinery for that and established committees of veterans' organisations to review the situation in conjunction with departmental sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which they obviously supported us in.

—They very obviously supported us in that endeavour. Clearly, this Government in its statement is going to proceed with that endeavour. I am very grateful that Senator Gietzelt has seen fit to continue that policy. I am surprised to see it in the Governor-General's Speech as something of an initiative which he has somehow proposed. The fact is that it is an ongoing event, having been established during our period of office. I am surprised that he is prepared to claim that as an initiative. It is one of the very few initiatives in the Governor-General's Speech.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter that I would particularly like to mention is the Darwin-Alice Springs railway. This is an act of faith in the future of Australia. The former Government committed itself to the building of a railway which would link Adelaide and of course the southern cities with the most northern capital, that is Darwin. It is an adventurous project. It is obviously an event for the future which will lead to great economic and other social and cultural benefits for the whole of Australia and not only for South Australia or for the Northern Territory. It is one which, I believe, has the full support of the Australian people. It is a costly project. As I understand it, the current estimate is for a cost of about $530m. But investment in such a project is worth while. We all understand what it means to commit that amount of money and faith to such a project from a standpoint of defence and economic development in the north and in other places. I am sure that my good colleague Senator Kilgariff, who represents the Northern Territory in this place, is as keen as I am to see that project proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of Australia.

—For the benefit of the whole country, as Senator Kilgariff points out so eloquently and well. The project has one specific advantage, of course, in relation by my State of South Australia. In recent times, as Senator Maguire, Senator Crowley and Senator Elstob know, a railway manufacturing steel plant has been developed at Whyalla, with an investment of $40m. Obviously, the plant needs this kind of work. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has committed considerable sums to that development, with the prospect of manufacturing rails for use in this railway project. Apart from that, of course, there are spin-offs in other directions, such as work opportunities in South Australia, apart from the future benefits, economic and otherwise, that will arise from the railway going ahead. I point out that the project will give South Australians job opportunities which will lead to future benefits for the whole country. This is really what federalism is all about. It is what this Senate stands for, and it is why we are here. It is a most significant project in terms of utilising at present unused resources for the benefit of South Australians. That should have the bipartisan support of all senators in this place-Liberal, Labor or Australian Democrat-who come from my State. I hope that a joint view will be put forward by both Labor and Liberal senators for the benefit of our State. I look forward to working with my Labor colleagues, particularly, on this matter in the months ahead. The project must proceed. It is an important project, as has been pointed out so well by Senator Kilgariff, for the whole country. I hope, too, that the opportunities that derive from that type of development will in future lead to other opportunities for co-operation between States at all levels.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by referring briefly to the National Economic Summit Conference. It is fairly clear that the Summit was a great success from the public relations point of view. We all understand that people can best solve their problems by getting together and talking. Essentially, that is what a parliament is all about. It is essentially what any conference or convention of people or similar interests is about. The Summit, in that sense, brought together people from different backgrounds, with different points of view, who worked together to obtain a better understanding of each others' points of view. My concern is that it did not have adequate representation from groups such as the unemployed and the poorer sections of our society or a broader representation from small business groups. One can perhaps pick nits about that. I do not intend to do so. But it needs to be observed that the Summit did not totally represent all views in this country. For that reason I believe that it has given us a serious reason to gain an understanding of what the Summit meant. The communique which has emerged from the Summit points out several matters which were discussed. This means only that they were discussed.

Considerable difficulties have emerged in gaining the agreement of the trade union movement to some statements in connection with wage and social welfare policies. It is clear that the document certainly did not contain any accord which somehow brings Australia together, to use a phrase that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spreads. For those reasons we need to be very careful about that document. We need to understand its limitations and what it really means. I believe that it gives us a base for further discussions in this place and for the development of further policies, particularly in wage areas. It gives us a springboard for a broader understanding of the economic problems which this Government and this Parliament face.

I return to my original point; that is, that this Government needs to make decisions, not try to obtain views which are consensual in the ways in which it apparently intends to do so. In the end, it is that decision which will make this country move ahead. The Opposition and the people of Australia are waiting for those decisions. I say, with the best will in the world, that all we are getting from the Government at the moment is confusion at just about every level of government activity. For the reasons which I have outlined in my remarks, I strongly support Senator Peter Rae's amendment to the motion for the Address-in- Reply to the Governor-General's Speech. It has the full support of all Opposition senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Crowley, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that this is her inaugural speech in the Senate. I ask all honourable senators to extend to her the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I welcome this opportunity to make my maiden speech in this Senate chamber. I am particularly pleased to be the first Australian Labor Party woman from South Australia to join the Federal Parliament in either the Senate or the House of Representatives . In 1894 South Australia was the first State in Australia to have the vote for women. I am appreciative of the honour and privilege of my election on behalf of the voters of South Australia. I thank them for their support at the recent election. I am delighted to be one of the 13 women in our Government-seven in this place-and I look forward to working with them, as well as with the other men and women in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to thank the Labor Party in South Australia not only for my pre-selection but also for the continuing support from my Labor colleagues and so many members of the branches and unions of the Labor Party in South Australia throughout last year and the recent campaign. As a long time member of the women's policy committee in the Labor Party in South Australia I am very aware of the special support of many women, not only for me personally but also for the general gain for women in the community which my election represents. I thank them, too, for their ability to celebrate. The election night was not only a great win and a great party; it was also a very joyous one.

Another group of special people whom I wish to thank are my previous work mates in the Clovelly Park Community Health Centre, in the Flinders Medical Centre, in the Department of Primary Care and Community Medicine, in the Mothers and Babies ' Health Association and on the Mental Health Review Tribunal. I thank the many people in the community which these various work situations enabled me to meet and help. My work mates practised a fine tolerance for me as a political candidate. I might add that they provided a wonderful training for this place as it gradually became clear that original roles were reversed and that I was required to practise quite some tolerance of their many views and ideas of what my party or I should do. However there was little tolerance for what the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, was doing which distressed so many of the people we all saw. Increasing unemployment, rising interest rates, rising inflation, and the rising human misery of parents, of children and of so many in our community were never matters for tolerance.

A very special thanks goes to my family, to my husband and my three sons, for their continuing support, care and enthusiasm about having a senator in their house. Their timely reminders about domestic realities, and their occasional achievements in making me a listener, again provide excellent grounding and practice for this place.

While I am not sure whether my colleague Senator Maguire or I have actually taken former Senator McLaren's place in this chamber, after hearing last night's speeches and knowing Geoff McLaren as I do, I know that neither Senator Maguire nor I could replace him. I wish him well in his retirement and hope not to contribute to the adjournment debates as I understand was his wont.

During my campaign I used the theme of bread and roses. This is the title of a song, the words and origins of which are in the International Workers of the World song book. I would like to read the words of that song to this Senate-I resist the temptation to sing it:
As we come marching, marching in the beauty of the day,
A million darkened kitchens, a thousand mill lofts gray,
Are touched with all the radiance that a sudden sun discloses,
For the people hear us singing: ''Bread and roses! Bread and roses!''
As we come marching, marching, we battle too for men,
For they are women's children, and we mother them again.
Our lives shall not be sweated from birth until life closes;
Hearts starve as well as bodies; give us bread, but give us roses!
As we come marching, marching, unnumbered women dead
Go crying through our singing their ancient cry for bread.
Small art and love and beauty their drudging spirts knew.
Yes, it is bread we fight for-but we fight for roses, too!
As we come marching, marching, we bring the greater days.
The rising of the women means the rising of the race.
No more the drudge and idler-ten that toil where one reposes,
But a sharing of life's glories: Bread and roses! Bread and roses!

Millworkers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, in 1912 went on strike when their campaign for shorter hours, from 60 hours per week, was agreed to but matched with a corresponding wage cut. The workers, mostly women, during their strike action carried placards saying: 'Give us bread but give us roses too'. The song I have read was written later to commemorate that strike action and the sentiments on those placards.

These words capture exactly what I want to offer as my contribution to politics . This is because the bread and roses must go together, not bread first and roses later. For me roses are an integral part of the bread. I can best illustrate this by an example of a political prisoner. A person may have adequate food, clothing, shelter, a bed to sleep in and even books and paper, but the loss of freedom means a starving heart. The bread does not compensate for the loss of roses.

When the Schools Commission was established it visited many schools to establish which places were of what standard and which had a claim on priority money. Sometimes the Commission visited in response to requests for visits; sometimes in response to curious requests. One school in inner suburban Sydney was quite awful: Red brick, high walls, barbed wire and broken glass on top; ashphalt ground; toilets too few, too ancient and too foul; surrounded by factories; tiny, dank and depressing. What that school particularly wanted was ' something beautiful in this place for the kids who come here, like a tree in the school yard' give us the roses while we are getting the bread.

Many people in our society need welfare assistance of one sort or another and have to go to various welfare offices or Commonwealth Employment Service offices or Social Security offices, or sometimes all of those. What often happens to people in this situation is quite appalling. They become numbers or card holders or are told: 'Just a minute, we will get your file'. They are confused, bewildered, often very anxious and even fearful; and the system is impersonal and dehumanising. People are encouraged to be grateful and dependent: They get the bread without the roses.

The Liberal Government under Mr Fraser certainly encouraged those attitudes, in particular by setting levels of payment that were so low that people survived rather than lived. Sometimes I think these people are like the political prisoner that I mentioned earlier. They are prisoners under a social welfare system and their hearts are starved of dignity, of independence, and of their right to be able to make choices or to exercise any power over their own lives.

The quality of people's lives is very much part of what bread and roses means. The rose as a symbol captures my imagination. To me the rose is a symbol of strength, of beauty and of passion. It is the symbol of the Socialist International. It represents vigour, depth, power and justice and it has its thorns as well as its flower. It says that what it represents must not be trivialised. One of the roles in our society which is constantly trivialised is mothering. To me mothering is very much about strength and passion, and about thorns as well as flowers. It is not the image often portrayed on television or the sentimentality of many Hollywood movies. It is the story of our parents and grandparents and of women down time who have born and bred the next generation. I want to stress that I am talking not about competition between men and women but about exactly the opposite; it is a coming together of the two, or many, different points of view. This Government offers the possibility of and the way for change in our society. It holds out promise, and that is why many young women now support this Government. One of our tasks is to make sure that women get a hearing and are equally represented so that our Party is a truly representative one. Our Government has always pressed for social justice and rights for all Australians. As a senator my main task is to represent that government policy to and for all South Australians. The bread and roses theme highlights the perspective and emphasis I will be giving it wherever and whenever I can.

These examples are taken from my experience of working in community health over the last eight years. The understanding of what community health represents is to me completely at one with the Party policy and the objectives of this Government. It is a program to provide information and education support and reassurance to the people in our community so that they can manage their own lives and get about the business of living, not independent of each other but independent of the restrictions of poor health, insufficient finances and inadequate education. The social justice policies of this Government for legislation to enable people to exercise their basic rights of full participation in this country, of good health and education of a claim to a fair share of the great wealth of Australia and of lives free of discrimination on the grounds of sex or race are spelt out in the Governor-General's Speech. Like the community health program, this Government's program aims to enable people to participate to their fullest in our community. It it a program empowering of people, our greatest resource. It is a program that provides for people to be involved in the decisions affecting their lives. It is a program of consultation as well as of conciliation and care. It is what I intend to work for as a member of this Government and as a member of this Senate.

One area of this Government's policy I would like to emphasise is that of occupational health and safety. It is part of the Government's health policy and industrial relations policy. Each policy area stresses the need for a national organisation of occupational health and safety to collect data and to establish standards and adequate education and training programs for people engaged in this area in either the health field or the industrial arena. The cost of industrial accidents is enormous and largely unknown. I was pleased to note that my colleague Senator Cook also used Mr Macphee's quote in this speech to the Senate this afternoon. In 1982, the then Federal Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Ian Macphee, admitted that work accidents and injuries cost Australia at least $4,000m a year. This year some 300 Australian workers will be killed and more than 125,000 injured in the work place. This will result in 300,000 hospital admissions and 2.5 million bed days. Six people will be hurt at work for every one person injured on the roads. But who hears of industrial accidents as we hear of road accidents?

The losses in production from injuries were estimated at nearly $470m in 1980- 81 while the value of production lost due to industrial disputes was $270m. In 1980 3.3 million work days were lost in Australia because of industrial disputes . By contrast, more than five million work days were lost because of industrial accidents. In South Australia, the State with the lowest rate of disputation, the difference is even more stark. For every day lost through industrial disputes in South Australia, more than four days are lost because of reported accidents. These figures are quite staggering. Yet they do not measure the most important cost of all, that is the cost to individual people from loss of limb, loss of hearing, loss of sight or loss of life. The social cost, while we can put no accurate figure of dollars on it, is undeniable and frighteningly large. That is why this Government unashamedly stresses the importance of the establishment of a national occupational health and safety institute and commission, firstly to collect proper, adequate and accurate statistics and secondly, to establish regulations that will enable workers, employers and government to co-operate to prevent such injuries and loss, rather than cost them after the event.

Occupational health and safety must be understood to cover much more than hard hat and steel boot areas of industry. It covers office hazards, where word processors and visual display units are causing new diseases and health problems . It covers the poor design of plant, furniture, tools et cetera. It includes chemical hazards, air and water hazards, environmental pollution and the hazards of radiation from the mining and processing of uranium. Finally, it is my view that, as in many other areas of our society, those people who are not in paid employment are not adequately covered by current planning and legislation. I feel strongly that occupational health and safety must be extended to include those people in unpaid work, in particular, housewives or householders and people in voluntary work. These two groups cover a great number of our citizens and their injury and illness is just as costly to our community and personally disastrous for those concerned as for people in the paid work force.

Another cost our society cannot, indeed must not, afford is the cost of war. I join with my colleagues on this side of the chamber in total opposition to the nuclear arms race and the threat to world peace-indeed, to the very existence of our world-that nuclear weapons creates. I do not believe that we can ask for optimism amongst Australians to work together for the benefit of our society when that very society is under the threat of nuclear destruction. Mr President, I thank you and I congratulate you on your election to your position. I trust my time in the Senate will allow me to continue the pursuit of the proposals I have mentioned on behalf of our Government and the people of South Australia who have put me here.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!
