SPEECH.PARA: I want to address two matters in this Address-in-Reply debate. The first concerns the recent National Economic Summit Conference and the second, relates to education policy. People on our side of politics, that is, the Opposition, those who are not now the Government, looked at the proposal for a national summit and the plans to put it in place with some hope and optimism. We shared the Australian Labor Party's hope that this event could be turned to the benefit of Australia. Indeed, we saw great bipartisan benefit. Mr Hawke had promised to put this in place. We looked to the potential benefit that might flow from it. First, there was a promise that it would be a forum representative of all Australans, 'at a time of Australia's gravest economic crisis in 50 years', to use Mr Hawke's words. What worries the Opposition in that Summit, when it actually occurred, was that it was not truly representative. It was, in fact, a place where those who are powerful, the 'haves' in the community, were able to accommodate their interests-corporate interests, the interests of unions, business and government-often at the expense of those who were crying out for help and for a chance. There is disappointment that what promised so much yielded so little when it came to the point. I remind honourable senators that Mr McKenzie from the Australian Council of Social Services, when he addressed the Summit, said:

The interest of all Australians cannot be represented by unions, business or government. We are concerned that ACOSS is the only voice here for the unemployed and the three million people receiving a pension or a benefit. Many other disadvantaged and alienated sections of the community feel locked out and unable to contribute to these discussions about their future.

Mr McKenzie was right. By the very way it was constructed, the Summit was a meeting of those who have power, position and privilege. The accommodation of their interests did not go very far at all to meeting the needs of many Australians who are distressed or disadvantaged. There were no Aboriginals at the Summit. There were no migrant representatives. With women representing more than 50 per cent of the population-

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Aboriginal Conference had an observer.

—I am delighted Senator Ryan was there, but she was one of the few women participants. Let us look at the kind of consensus that emerged because we were hoping that from this Summit would emerge a determination to take steps that would really help people, help employment, and help bring inflation down. What did emerge? The first thing that became apparent is that while the business representatives at the Summit were presenting their views the final communique was even then being polished up. What did these representatives say? They pointed to the fact that of the three scenarios presented by the Government to the Summit only one offered any hope of an improvement in employment, a drop in unemployment or a significant drop in inflation. That was a scenario which in the end was not supported by the Government or by the union representatives. Why not?
—It didn't suit big business. It didn't suit big government. It didn't suit big unions.

—My colleague senator Peter Rae emphasises the point I was making before. There was an accommodation of the powerful when what was called for was action to help those so desperately in need in Australia today. Scenario C-the one scenario of the three offered which did promise some drop in unemployment and the greatest fall in inflation-was not adopted. What did it involve? It involved only the continuation of the wage pause put in place a few months ago and agreed to by eight governments around Australia. That scenario would have meant a decrease in unemployment and an increase in jobs. For a party -a Labor Party-which promised so much during the election campaign for those out of work to have gone past that scenario is a betrayal of trust and a sign of failure at the Summit.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not just the Liberal Party that wanted to have scenario C looked at; so did prominent businessmen. Sir Arvi Parbo; the managing director of Simpson Ltd, Mr John Uhrig; the managing director of Dunlop Olympic Ltd, Mr John Gough; and the late Sir Keith Campbell, who died so tragically just after the Summit, all drew attention to what scenario C promised. The late Sir Keith Campbell went further. He believed there was a need for a scenario D-one that had not been presented-which really gave some hope for an improvement in employment and which really went some way towards taking the hard decisions that would bring inflation down. What was required was that those who have should share a little. What did not come out of the Summit was the kind of sharing, common sacrifice or concern for those who are powerless and disadvantaged that we all wanted to see. I am not attacking the idea of the Summit. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it was a positive initiative. I am not really worrying about the composition of the Summit, which I have criticized. What worries the Opposition particularly was that when the Treasurer, Mr Keating, presented the Summit with options the best option was not taken. The best option was cast aside to accommodate the interests of those who have and those who are selfish against those who need help. Australian's looked to the Summit for outcomes. Indeed, the Treasurer, in speaking to the Summit, made this one of the conditions. He said:
If this Summit is to succeed it will need to do more than put forward proposals that sound like programs for action but are really only statements of goals-not methods for attaining them.

Australians have every right to be disappointed with a Summit that produced nothing. There has been no real commitment to taking hard decisions. There have been no decisions that could result in jobs. There is total confusion in Government ranks about the future of the wages pause and the alternatives which are offered. This is what is wrong with consensus as a goal in itself rather than as a tool to lead to useful outcomes, as a process to achieve goals for a society. My State of New South Wales had a Labor Government for almost all the time that the Liberals were in power in Canberra. If Government senators want to draw attention to the record of the last seven years, they may care to reflect upon the fact that throughout that time New South Wales has fared worse under a Labor Government, in terms of employment and almost every other indicator, than any other State in Australia. With one Liberal government across Australia but a Labor Government in New South Wales, that State has had worse employment and fewer jobs. It is a bankrupt State. It has no money left. Mismanagement has occurred. I think we in New South Wales have been particularly disappointed that the opportunity presented by the Summit was not taken up to offer something to the young who want jobs, to the middle aged who need retraining, having been retrenched, and to many people whose hopes rested upon this Summit-hopes, of course, which were not realised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rugby league has been going well.

—My colleague refers to rugby league. We might take that matter up at another time. The change of government provides a good opportunity for us to pause and to take stock. Just once, at the beginning of our time in Opposition-once only-I intend to look back to examine what the previous Government offered and did in the area of my former portfolio and to set the record straight on some of the things which were misrepresented so consistently during and before the election campaign. Between the end of 1975 and 1983 Australia had Liberal-National Party governments and there were three Ministers for Education. During that time across Australia we saw great improvements in education. We saw smaller classes in our schools. We saw a broader curriculum offered. We saw a marked improvement in the salaries and conditions of teachers across Australia. We saw more teachers present in schools and more support staff . There were better facilities for students. There was a significant increase in resources applied to education. Indeed, Commonwealth funded programs for education, for schools, went up from $985m in 1976 to almost $1,200m in 1983. There were increases in student assistance. I will mention student assistance a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a school to work transition program. Over $50m was allocated for 1983 . New programs were introduced to assist school leavers. I refer to the school to work transition program and the educational program for unemployed youth. There were programs to help the handicapped such as the integration of handicapped children into regular schools program and the residential institutions program. All those programs were introduced during those seven years. For migrants we introduced the Commonwealth multicultural education program, the ethnic schools program, the English language program, the new arrivals program and large amounts of support for English as a second language. For students in country areas we introduced the disadvantaged country area program and the loan video program. In the area of Aboriginal education the National Aboriginal Education Commission was established and teacher education programs were introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially for Aboriginals.

—Especially for Aboriginals, as my colleague Senator Teague said. I will come back in a moment to point out the offer we made in the election campaign to improve significantly the opportunities for Aboriginals. We made a number of commitments in the 1980 election. We promised a new places program and that was implemented. We promised a change in the number of levels for non-government schools from six to three an that was implemented. We promised an increase in the per capita grant for the most needy non-government schools and that was implemented. We promised $2m a year in special programs for the severely handicapped and that was implemented. We promised a $4m loan video program and we implemented it. We promised that the boarding allowance for isolated children would be increased and that was done. We promised a per capita grant to certain non-profit ethnic part time schools and that was implemented. We promised to establish research centres of excellence and that was implemented . We promised to fund the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in order to continue language courses at universities and colleges of advanced education and that was done as well. We reaffirmed our commitment and carried on with the school to work transition program. We maintained the link between the cost of educating children in government schools and the grants we gave to support non- government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: We were pursuing-and I hope the new Government pursues them-liberal goals in education. We were pursuing freedom of choice for those wanting the best education for their children. We were pursuing the goal of improved access to education. I point out that any move to make any non-government school more expensive to parents will have the effect of limiting access to that school, whereas we have been at work to try to improve and broaden access. We believe that our goals in education have to include special programs to overcome disadvantage. I have enumerated some of those already. We sought a greater retention in education. I will deal with retention for a moment. At the end of last year we were able to mount a program to try to bring to the attention of Australian families a benefit that was available to help children of needy families to complete years 11 and 12. That program, which cost very little and was non-political-it was just a matter of benefit identification-led to a doubling of the applications for the particular benefit and a doubling of the uptake. That publicity, combined with economic factors, has helped lead to a marked increase this year in retention in the senior levels of high schools in several States and, I think, across Australia.

In the election campaign we promised to do certain things. I hope that the Labor Government will pick up those things and join us in seeing them put in place. We promised to foster greater attention in secondary schools and I am glad that the new Government has the same goal. But we identified an amount of money that would be provided to try to make that goal a reality. I hope that the Government will provide money so that there can be identification and counselling of those at risk at lower levels of education to make sure that they know the options available, to make sure that teachers who need extra skills to make themselves better can get them and that curriculum reform can occur in schools.

We promised to assist young people cope with modern technology. The program we outlined in the election campaign is very similar to the program contained in a report of the Schools Commission tabled yesterday in this place by the new Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). That is a comprehensive program. We promised to provide computer hardware. We promised to provide and see developed computer software. We sought to provide in-service training for teachers. We sought to provide extra pre-vocational teacher training. That program was a very ambitious and expensive one. We promised to put in a large amount of money-$20m from the Commonwealth each year for five years.

The Labor Party has promised to buy computers. But unless it will go the next step and help to develop the software programs, to produce and distribute the software, to train the teachers and to make teachers feel comfortable in using computers, its program of putting computers in schools could result in computers gathering dust in some corners of the classrooms. I hope and trust that when the Minister has a chance to read the recommendations of the Schools Commission contained in its report which was tabled in this chamber yesterday she will want to extend Labor's program to make it as comprehensive and as potentially valuable as the program we promised to introduce. If she does that there will be bipartisan support and encouragement as indeed there should be in any matter affecting the education of our young.

The other thing we promised was to introduce 100 special new awards for five years to help mature aged Aboriginal people train as teachers. We all know that the report of the national inquiry into teacher education-the Auchmuty report- recommended that there should be special programs to provide more Aboriginal teachers in Australia. This proposal we put forward was one way to help make that a reality. Many people from within the Aboriginal community who would become Aboriginal teachers have family responsibilities. They require special scholarships, more generous than those generally available under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme or under other forms of student support.

If the honourable senator who is now the Minister thought it reasonable to examine that election promise of ours and if in the spirit of bipartisanship she wanted to pick up that suggestion and put it in place, again we would support and encourage her. The only result would be to have more Aboriginal teachers trained and to be one step closer to our goal of having a thousand Aboriginal teachers by the end of the decade. That is a perfectly reasonable kind of proposition which could attract support from everyone and could lead-I think at fairly low cost-to some extra benefits. It is appropriate to ask what the Labor Party has done so far to help people through education and in the area of student assistance because it has been in government now for a little while. The Governor-General's Speech has been delivered and we have had the Government's program outlined. I must say that so far people have been long on rhetoric but short on performance. Mr Hawke, in his policy speech, said:
I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

But that is just what he has done. In the education area the policy promise was quite explicit. The promise was an immediate-I emphasise the word immediate- subvention of $15m for the upgrading and expansion of the technical and further education sector. Where is that immediate subvention? Perhaps it was only immediate during the election campaign. That is an immediate subvention of $15m which has not occurred. I hope it does occur. I hope Senator Ryan can fight in Cabinet and can win because if she does not deliver it it will mean that she has failed to keep a promise of an immediate subvention needed by the TAFE sector. That subvention again would be welcomed and supported. To this date it has not been made. We can only wonder what interpretation is placed by the Government on the word immediate when it appears in its policy. I hope it is not the same interpretation or fate that was placed upon the promise of immediate tax reductions. The immediate tax reductions promised before the election have not been delivered after the election.

The Government has promised to increase student assistance. We increased student assistance in the last Budget. In my only Budget as Minister for Education I was able to deliver a 20 per cent increase in the rates of TEAS, a relaxation of the means test and a 48 per cent increase in post-graduate awards- extra awards for the benefit of Australian post-graduate students. I was also able to establish a student loans scheme which attracted considerable criticism. But as a result of the increased benefits student enrolments have gone up. Against that we have a promise in the Governor-General's Speech simply to improve the assistance schemes progressively when budgetary circumstances permit . Every student in Australia should understand that that could mean never. We may have a situation in which Senator Ryan may be unable to convince her colleagues that the time is ever right to keep that election promise.

I remind her that we hope she can do as she promised in her policy speech and increase the level of benefits to the unemployment rate. It is interesting that the Government was able to increase the unemployment benefit for some people but that it did not extend the benefit, as it promised it would move to do, to students. The honourable senator also promised in her election policy speech to repeal the student loans scheme and to replace it with an emergency loan scheme to be administered by tertiary institutions. All that has happened so far is that a student loans scheme has been disbanded. So all that has happened so far is that the one option available to Australian students has been taken away. All that has happened so far under the Labor Government is that the support available in February is less in May.

TALK.START.PARA: —And those students are worse off.

—And those students are worse off, as my colleague says. Students have suffered because Senator Ryan has abolished a benefit and has not established the extra money in the emergency loans scheme. She has not increased student assistance. I say to the honourable senator that there would have been some sense in maintaining the benefits that existed until she was ready to put something else in place. All she has done is to make less support available for Australian students. All she has done is fail to deliver on what she promised. We will be watching. If she starts delivering we will applaud that move and if she does not we will not be surprised.

SPEECH.PARA: I would encourage people to read the education section in the Governor-General' s Speech. An important area like education attracts two-thirds of a page. It is written in generality. There are no specific proposals at all in the Governor- General's Speech. The Labor Party so far has sacked the man who was the permanent head of the Department for 10 years in the most humiliating way possible. Let us consider what it could have done. The Labor Party decided to move an officer who served me very well, who served many Ministers well, and who was appointed by the Labor party.

TALK.START.PARA: —He served the country.

—He served the country as a permanent head very well for 10 years. What the Government could have done was to announce his new appointment as permanent head of the Department of Administrative Services. Then it could have proceeded to announce the appointment of a new permanent head for the Department of Education and Youth Affairs. It did not do that; it announced prematurely, before the Governor-General had approved the appointment, that another person would take over the chair as head of the Department of Education and Youth Affairs. It left a decent officer dangling, humiliated, for more than a week before it found a post for him. It was unnecessary; it was ungenerous. Is that the kind of administration we are going to see? I hope not.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish the new Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) well in putting into place the program which she has promised. As an Opposition our job will be to examine closely the extent to which those promises are kept, to examine closely what is done and what is not done. We will be seeking good outcomes in education-good for people, good for society, good for students and good for schools. As an Opposition we will apply to the programs and actions of the Government a most critical view, as is our duty and as is expected of us. We are, however, focusing now on the task ahead of us. We are reassessing our policies to ensure that they are forward looking and that they are appropriate to the next 10 years, the 10 years after that and the new century which will emerge. We are undertaking policy review and new policy development. We are looking at contemporary social realities. We are looking at the needs and aspirations of all Australians in the policies which we are developing. We are doing this in the light of liberal principles, our belief in individuals-in their rights, in their capacity and in what they want and need.

The Governor-General's Speech was a disappointment for many of us. It was, however, the first declaration of the Australian Labor Party in government. It is our hope that when it makes its next major declaration at the time of the Budget we will see more substance and more promises kept and fewer promises of immediate action set aside. If the new Government can deliver less inflation, more jobs and greater stability we will applaud it. However, because of the way it has started we do not have great confidence that this will be the course it will follow or that those will be the outcomes.

It was the only time that I have been called to order since I have been in this place. I look forward to serving under Senator Douglas McClelland as the President of the Senate and under you as Deputy President. Mr Deputy President, I wish you and the President well during your terms in office.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to take the opportunity of congratulating those honourable senators who have delivered their first speeches to the chamber this evening. The first was my colleague from Queensland, Senator Reynolds. She was followed by Senator Cook, Senator Jack Evans and Senator Crowley. I am sure that they are all relieved that their first speech to this chamber has been delivered. Each one of them should not only be relieved but also pleased because they all delivered excellent speeches. If the speeches that were delivered tonight are a harbinger of what is to come we certainly are going to enjoy their speeches in the future.

This is my first speech to the Senate since the election of 5 March. I have, of course, asked a few questions prior to this debate but this is the first opportunity I have had to make a speech of any length. After 5 March, of course, I took my place on the Government benches. This is a new experience for me because I entered the Parliament in 1975. At that time very few Australian Labor Party members entered the Parliament. In fact there were only six new members- four in this chamber and two in the House of Representatives. The two members of the House of Representatives are no longer there but the four senators who entered this chamber at that time are still here. In 1975, which was a time of great drama in Australian politics, I entered the Parliament on the Opposition benches. I was due to stay on them for seven years. In fact my role, until 5 March, had always been that of an Opposition senator. But now I am looking forward to serving in government, serving the party I represent and serving the Queensland residents I represent as well. In addition to that, I am looking forward to seeing the Australian Labor Party's policies implemented.

I must make some mention of the recent election. The election of 5 March was held early. It should not have been held until later this year. In fact the election of 5 March in my estimation should not have been held at all. That election was called because of blatant political expediency. The then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, thought he could win an election at that time and thought it would be much more difficult to win one later. Thus, he called an early election. The election itself was contrived. The double dissolution also, to some extent, was contrived. The basic conditions for a double dissolution as laid down in section 57 of the Constitution-had certainly been fulfilled. Those conditions were there to provide a trigger only. The word 'trigger' became almost an in word in this Parliament. The trigger was there for a double dissolution.

I would like to examine the issues over which this election was called. On 4 February this year a special Gazette was issued. This Gazette carried a proclamation by the Governor-General outlining that the conditions of section 57 of the Constitution had been fulfilled for a double dissolution. In the Gazette a number of Bills were listed which had been twice rejected by the Senate and on which the then Prime Minister had asked for, and been granted, a double dissolution after some correspondence with the Governor-General. There were nine sales tax Bills, all of which had been introduced at the same time and defeated at the same time in this place. Whilst there were a number of them, they were all connected in some way. The special Gazette also stated that another Bill which had been twice rejected by the Senate was the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill 1981. Listed also were the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981, the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 and the Social Services Amendment Bill ( No. 3) 1981. The sales tax Bills which I first mentioned were Bills to increase the rate of sales tax on a wide variety of goods. The Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the other two Bills-the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3)-would have allowed fees to be charged for second and higher degrees.

When one first looks at the Social Security Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) one wonders why the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats at that time rejected a Social Services Amendment Bill. But it really was an industrial relations Bill dressed up in social service clothing. That Bill would have prevented spouses of workers-the workers themselves would have been unable to receive benefits-from receiving benefits, even if they might have been eligible under normal conditions. These Bills were outlined in the special Gazette of 4 February 1983. But did the Government really intend to reintroduce these Bills if it had been returned to government? Would it have gone as far as bringing them before a joint sitting of the Parliament, if that had been necessary had it been returned to government, to make sure that these Bills were passed? I sometimes doubt it. The then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, during the election campaign would not say for sure whether he would reintroduce the sales tax Bills. I have doubts whether the other Bills would have been introduced if that Government had been returned to power. In other words, the Bills were just a trigger. They hardly rated a mention during the election campaign because they were not what the then Prime Minister was interested in. He was just interested in getting back into government and he used those Bills as an excuse to dissolve the whole of the Parliament.

It is not as though these Bills were of recent origin when the double dissolution was announced. It is interesting to look at when they were last discussed in the Parliament. The Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) were last discussed in this place on 22 October 1981. Yet in February 1983, well over one year after these Bills were last discussed, Parliament was dissolved. The Bills were almost forgotten. The Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill was last discussed here on 19 May 1982. Admittedly, that was less -but it was not much less-than a year before the double dissolution. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) was last discussed in this place on 24 November 1981. So too was the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3).

The Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3)-the Bill I referred to a little while ago-was debated here on 25 November 1981. That was well over one year before the then Prime Minister went to the Governor-General and said that these were important Bills that had to be passed and asked for a double dissolution. It is incredible that Bills which had not been debated for over a year were used as an excuse for an early election. It is a prostitution of section 57 of the Australian Constitution to use Bills in this way: To request a double dissolution, to just have Bills pile up and not have any intention of doing anything with them if returned to government after a double dissolution.

The same people who stood by and watched this happen now argue against fixed- term parliaments. I have no doubt that a lot of Opposition members do not want fixed terms. What they want to be able to do is to call elections at a time of their choosing, at their whim, when they think that an election may be necessary . The people of Australia are sick and tired of early elections. They want to see governments get on with the job that they were elected to do. I first stood for the Senate in 1970 at a half-Senate election. Since then there have been Federal elections in 1972, 1974, 1977, 1980 and 1983. Whilst the last two-those in 1980 and 1983-may appear to have been after three-year terms they were not. The 1977 election was in December but that of 1980 was in October. The next election was in March 1983. So we have not had a full three-year term since I first stood for the Senate in 1970.

There has been some talk in this Parliament, and in the community as well, that we should have four-year terms. I am yet to be convinced that a four-year term is necessary. We should remember that three-year parliaments have not been given a fair trial. The average length of a parliament, since Federation, has been about two and a half years. In recent years it has been even less. We should look at giving the three-year term a fair trial before we look at a four-year term. Any proposal to fix the term of parliament will, I am sure, receive wide support.

A recent opinion poll showed that 70 per cent of Australians want Federal Parliament to run normally for a fixed term with the exact date of the election known years in advance. The Australian Public Opinion Polls conducted a poll in March this year, after the 5 March Federal election. In this poll 2,074 people throughout Australia were asked the questions, first:
Do you agree or disagree that terms of Federal Parliament should be extended from three to four years?

To that question 52 per cent of those asked said that they wanted the Federal Parliament to be extended from three to four years; 41 per cent opposed the proposition and 7 per cent were unsure. Therefore, a majority of people would like to see the term extended from three to four years. Of course if we just extended the term from three to four years but do not make it a fixed term there is no guarantee that we would have a four-year term or even a three-year term. The second question that people were asked in this opinion poll was:
Do you agree or disagree that Federal Parliament should normally run for a fixed term with the exact election date known years in advance?

In other words, that is the fixed term proposal. In answer to this question 70 per cent of those asked said that they wanted the Federal Parliament to run for a fixed term with the exact election date known years in advance, only 27 per cent opposed the proposition and 3 per cent were unsure. If we had a proposal before the Australian people to fix the term of the Parliament it would receive wide support. I think that it might even receive wider support if we first moved to a three-year term and gave that a fair go before we looked at the possibility of a four-year term.

I return to the election of 5 March. It turned out that in calling that election the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, made a gigantic mistake in thinking that he would win. The people understood the political expendiency that had been employed in calling that election and the inevitable result was that the Government was sacked by the people of Australia. It was not sacked by one person, as one government in Australia was sacked; it was sacked by the people of Australia. Labor was called upon and asked to restore the prosperity which had disappeared under the seven dark years of the Fraser Government.

The results in Queensland, the State that I represent, for the House of Representatives were particularly gratifying to us. When I became a member of this Parliament there were five Federal Labor representatives from Queensland- four senators and one member of the House of Representatives. Now, after the 5 March election, we have 14 Federal representatives from Queensland-four senators and 10 members of the House of Representatives. Before the 1983 election Queensland had five Labor members of the House of Representatives. We have now doubled that and have 10. I will mention the Queensland seats which were gained by Labor in the recent Federal election. I will start at the north of the State and move southward. The northern-most electorate of Queensland is Leichhardt. It stretches from below Cairns to the Papua-New Guinea border. Geographically it is a large electorate. This electorate was held by the National Party but was won by Mr John Gayler, a well-respected lawyer from Cairns.

The next seat south is Herbert, which centres on Townsville. This was held by the Liberal Party of Australia but was won for Labor by Mr Lindsay, who is also of the legal world. Mr Lindsay is a well-known and respected solicitor in Townsville. Further south, just on the outskirts of Brisbane and moving into the Redcliffe area, is the seat of Petrie, which was held by a Minister, as was the seat of Leichhardt. That Minister was defeated and the seat ws taken by Mr Dean Wells, a well-respected and well-known academic from the University of Queensland. Bowman, a seat on the southern side of Brisbane, was regained by Mr Len Keogh. Mr Keogh previously held the seat from 1969-1975. The electorate of Fadden which has, I think, the largest enrolment in Australia was won by Mr David Beddall, a man experienced in small business. It was no mean feat for Mr Beddall to win this electorate. It is large in terms of population and it had been held by a long time survivor Mr Don Cameron. But Mr Cameron was defeated on this occasion.

As I said, these gains took Labor's total number of seats in Queensland to 10 and we now have over half of the Federal seats in Queensland. Those of us in the Labor Party in Queensland are now looking forward to the State election later this year. Despite the terribly malapportioned electorates in Queensland there is every possibility that a Labor Government can once again be installed in that State. If we hold half of the Federal seats there is no reason why we should not hold half of the State seats as well. If the calling of the double dissolution and the 5 March election were unnecessary and a cynical abuse of the system, as I have pointed out, they were certainly a forewarning of Mr Fraser's later performance. I refer to his resignation only 26 days after he was re-elected by the voters of Wannon to represent them in the Federal Parliament. Electors have a right to expect that their wishes, expressed through the ballot box, will be honoured. In fact, the Commonwealth Electoral Act specifically states:
No nomination shall be valid unless-
. . . the person nominated consents to act if elected . . .

Mr Fraser, however, exhibited a total disregard for the choice of his electorate and for his obligations as a successful candidate in a Commonwealth election. Before the election of the Labor Government he should have made it clear to his constituents that if he were to serve them it would be contingent upon his Government being re-elected. Instead they found less than a month after they endorsed him that he had opted out. Now they are forced to return to the polls- they will return to the polls this week-end-for the fourth time in six years to select another representative. As well, the country will be forced to bear the cost of yet another totally unnecessary election. Sir Billy Snedden was almost as unconcerned for the opinion of his electorate, announcing his retirement merely 46 days after being elected as the member for Bruce. The expense of both of these by-elections is unwarranted and one would not blame voters in Wannon and Bruce for being totally disaffected with the so-called democratic process.

Finally, Mr Acting Deputy President, I take the opportunity to touch on one other matter of concern to me. It is far different from the matters that I have so far mentioned. I refer to the entrance fee at the Australian National Gallery . As the Senate will no doubt recall, when in Opposition we opposed the introduction of a $2 entrance fee to the Gallery and promised to remove it when we came to government. Whilst the money raised by the admission fee was to be strictly allocated to fund new art purchases, we in the Labor Party held to the view that the Gallery had been constructed at taxpayer's expense and belonged to the Australian public. We stated that we would compensate the art acquisition fund for the amount lost through the removal of the admission fee. There is some concern at the moment that the Government might not in fact go ahead with its plans to abolish the fee. I understand that it is currently the subject of a Gallery report and no firm decision has yet been made. However, I urge the Government to honour its commitment to abolish the fee. It is inconsistent with the procedures adopted in all other public buildings in the national capital. There is no admission fee to the Australian War Memorial, to the National Library of Australia, to Parliament House or to the Royal Australian Mint.

Another aspect of some concern to me about the Gallery is the fact that for several hours each week-end it is open only to members. I have now heard of several incidents in which visitors have been turned away from the Gallery between 10 a.m. and 12 noon on a Sunday when it is for the use of members only. This has been a source of some annoyance to visitors to Canberra who may have only a limited time available to see the Gallery or those who have made a special trip only to be told to come back later. It seems to me that Sunday would be a most popular time for visitors and members of the general public to view the collection, and perhaps the Gallery should reconsider these arrangements, especially in the light of the difficulty that it may be creating to visitors to the National capital. Mr Acting Deputy President, it has been my pleasure to support the motion for the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General' s Speech which has been moved by my Queensland colleague, Senator Margaret Reynolds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that you pass on my congratulations to the President of the Senate and the Deputy President of the Senate, Senator Hamer, on their elections. Earlier this afternoon and this evening we heard four maiden speeches by new senators. I congratulate Senator Reynolds, Senator Cook, Senator Jack Evans and Senator Crowley on their speeches. Senator Crowley and Senator Maguire are new South Australian senators. At the declaration of the poll, as you will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, I welcomed them for being among the 10 of us chosen by the South Australian people and I wish them well. I also wish them, as members of the Australian Labor Party, not too long a stay in this place, as I think that the Liberal Party should return to a majority.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make, as did Senator Colston before me, some brief remarks about the recent election. I join with all of those who earlier remarked upon former Senator Sir Harold Young as being an excellent President of the Senate and whose non-return to this place we much regret. He was a friend to me; he was a wise and good senator for South Australia; he knew our State very well; and we certainly wish him well in his retirement. But the youthful Liberal politician from South Australia, whose role in the Parliament was foreshortened by the election-we all understand the mechanisms of democracy-is my very close friend, Grant Chapman, the member-the former member-for Kingston. I slip so easily to say 'the member for Kingston' because he served Kingston, comprising the southern suburbs of Adelaide, so well since the 1975 election. Against all predictions he was re-elected in 1977, again in 1980, and he missed by a small swing in the recent election. He missed coming back to Parliament by a whisker. I can say only that we very much regret that he is not in the other place, the House of Representatives, to work hard for the people of the southern suburbs of Adelaide. I make this reflection: I grew up in the electorate of Kingston. I was born at Glenelg, and I spent my teenage years in Somerton. I know Kingston very well-the beaches, the sand hills and the schools. I attended Glenelg primary schools and Paringa Park primary school. I rode about on my bicycle and I met with so many people. I have been directly involved in campaigning for the Liberal Party and have campaigned in each of the Kingston election campaigns throughout the 1970s. Never before have I, as a Liberal senator, had such a positive response in the southern suburbs of Adelaide. People in those areas recognise Grant Chapman as a hard working, conscientious member. It was not on his account that they voted against him again becoming the member for Kingston. Rather it was because of national factors about which all of us can speculate- the high rate of unemployment, the high expectations that the Liberals had given to the people of Australia, which we were not eventually able to maintain, the recession, the drought, the downturn internationally in all our economies, and I think also, to be honest, the calling of an early election despite, I believe, the best intentions of the former Prime Minister. As I have said, these general factors acted against us in Kingston. We had a small swing of only 2 1/2 per cent-nothing like the national average-but it was enough for this marginal seat to be lost.

I have moved my Senate electorate office from the city of Adelaide to the southern suburbs of Adelaide in order to be in the heart of the electorates of Kingston and Hawker. I have returned to the place I love and to the people whom I want to serve most specifically. Although as a Liberal senator I represent the whole State of South Australia and will go to every part of it to serve the people, I will especially be available to the people in the electorates of Kingston and Hawker. If it is their wish at the next election, I hope to see Grant Chapman and a Liberal candidate for Hawker in the other place. I certainly want to hold out that prospect to the people of Kingston who have such a fond and close relationship with Grant Chapman. He was an excellent member of the House of Representatives.

I turn now to the Address-in-Reply debate. I support the motion before the chamber that was moved this afternoon. I wish to speak about the economy and the Governor-General's remarks on education, youth affairs, foreign affairs and defence. I have before me the Governor-General's Speech-some six or seven pages- which was prepared for him by the new Government. This debate is about that gracious speech at the opening of the Parliament. It will form the Address-in- Reply which will eventually be taken personally by us to him. In those six or seven pages the Governor-General touches upon the various areas about which the Government made promises to the people during the election campaign. There have been a few changes since the election. The program we have before us is the program that the Parliament should expect in the coming three years-or will it be only a year and a half before we see a general election? Despite all the statements that have been made about elections being too frequent I still fear that the people of Australia will have thrust upon them a general election for both Houses as early as November next year.

The Governor-General's Speech outlines the program that this Parliament should expect from the Government for whatever time it may be in government. The crucial and introductory part of that speech relates to the economy and quickly moves to the outcome of the National Economic Summit Conference which was held some few weeks ago. Earlier today, in a debate on a matter of public importance, a number of honourable senators on the Opposition side took the opportunity to try to urge the Government to give a much higher priority to wage restraint. Wage restraint was the most overlooked aspect of all the speeches at that Summit Conference. When the report to Parliament of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was tabled in this chamber by Senator Button yesterday-it was about 15 pages in length and it outlined the achievements of the Summit Conference-there was not one reference to wage restraint having been achieved. Yet the Opposition believes that wage restraint is the single measure most available to the Australian Government to get unemployment reduced and thus attain a more healthy economy in this country. So we took the opportunity this afternoon and earlier, during Question Time in the Senate-our colleagues in the Opposition in the other House yesterday took the opportunity in a similar debate-to press upon the Government the view that wage restraint needs to be given a higher priority. It is shameful that in the Prime Minister's report to the Parliament there is not a full-bodied presentation of speeches during the Economic Summit Conference which urged wage restraint. I will refer to that matter later.

I am not in this Senate to make slick points. I am in this Senate, as a Liberal representative for the people of South Australia, to speak constructively and to urge the Government of the day to take account of what I, after conversations, thoughts and representations from the people of South Australia, see as being the best solution to the pressing problem of unemployment and the problems of our economy. I was not represented at the National Economic Summit Conference; the Opposition was not there. The unemployed were not there and small business people were not there. I know that journalists at large have said that the Summit Conference achieved a great deal. I do not entirely want to be critical of what was an achievement-that the facts about the economy were brought before the people of Australia in a very clear way. It was a debate in which people were able to put some points of view. All the journalists of Australia-not just the Opposition-said that this was a summit conference of the three bigs-big government, big business and big unions. Where was the Opposition? Where were the small people? Where was the community interest? Where were the unemployed represented? The Opposition takes the opportunity today in the Senate-we have only been sitting a few days-to press home to the Government, in as constructive a way as we can, the fact that there has been a singular oversight in the report about the Summit Conference to this Parliament; that is that the most available single remedy, wage restraint, has been avoided.

I will outline the three scenarios which the Treasurer, Mr Keating, brought to the Summit Conference. Very helpfully the Treasurer outlined in a summay speech, with papers appended, a whole series of economic facts, statistics and expectations according to three different sets of assumptions. He called these scenario A, scenario B and scenario C. Scenario B was what one could call the gung ho unionists' great ambit claim, even if it is still of a somewhat moderate character. Scenario B assumed an immediate end to the wages pause that the Liberal Government had set up in November and an immediate full catch-up to compensate for all the consumer price index increases then outstanding. There would then be an immediate return to full indexation with quarterly adjustments, the first such adjustment occurring in August and September 1983 with a return to productivity increases early in 1984. In other words, we go back to the big wage increase as soon as possible with some small degree of moderation. That was called scenario B.

In all of the graphs and extrapolations that are based on those assumptions one gets the worst outcome for inflation and the worst outcome for unemployment. On that basis the unemployment prediction in 1986 would be more than 12 per cent. At the moment unemployment in Australia is tragically high at 10.4 per cent of the work force. This involves some 731,000 people. If we had all the wage increases in scenerio B we would see unemployment rise to more than 12 per cent by 1986. That was put up as something of a straw man for the National Economic Summit Conference to reject. Certainly the Opposition rejects it. The representatives of big business rejected it very quickly. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, to its credit, seemed to reject it also. Let us hope it has the discipline and authority to win that with the individual unions in the coming 12 months. So that was the straw man which was one extreme. The other extreme-it was put as an extreme-was that which showed the greatest restraint in wages. It is the one to which, quite frankly, the Opposition is most attracted, although we could still want to see modifications to scenario C which would take those advantages even further. According to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) scenario C states:

. . . assumes the continuation of the current wages pause until April 1984 followed by a return to half-yearly, partial indexation with compensation for CPI increases in the September and December quarters of 1983.
An 80 per cent partial indexation is assumed with a return to productivity increases commencing only in April 1985.

This scenario has the best outcomes for inflation, for the lowest level of unemployment, and sees the economy coming back to the most stable and healthy state. Paradoxically it happens to have, in the short term only, a slightly higher deficit. This was referred to by Senator Walsh earlier today. He tried to damn this approach on that ground alone, but we do not. We note that point but see the other advantages. The Australian Labor Party appears to have chosen the so-called middle scenario, which is scenario A and which is the first scenario set out in the Treasurer's paper. It states:

Scenario A assumes no catch-up for CPI increases prior to the current wages pause, a 3 per cent wage increase during the latter half of 1983, followed by a return to full quarterly wage indexation and early in 1985 a return to annual productivity cases.

This is a moderate way. In brief, it is a 3 per cent wage rise towards the end of 1983 and a fully indexed rise in 1984. This has moderately good outcomes in unemployment and inflation and a moderate deficit in comparison with the other two scenarios. But none of them actually are moderate. Do the people of Australia realise that that choice, which appears to be favoured by the Labor Government, would still have unemployment in 1986 at 10 per cent, the same as it is now? that is why I feel the urgency as I do. As constructively as I can I urge the Government not to accept this so-called middle way but to tighten wages and salaries and other incomes for all of us, not just for those who are receiving the average weekly wage or less but for all incomes. The Government should tighten all wages so that there is a restraint in this area which will most help the unemployed and bring recovery to the economy. I know this is an old analogy; that is, we have one cake which is to be divided into pieces. At the moment the Australian economy-this Australian cake-is not growing. If we cut it into bigger pieces for those who have already got a piece-the employed-it can only be at the expense of the unemployed. It will deny some, who are presently employed, gaining a piece at all. I believe that there is justice and fairness in such a wage restraint. This will allow a fairer division of that national economy, that one cake, so that more people can have a piece and so that unemployment does decrease. This would most be achieved with maximum wage, salary and other incomes restraint.

The Labor Party has been quite clever in setting up these three scenarios. It is like a three pea trick. One puts up a scenario which will obviously lead to the worst outcomes. That is to be rejected. One puts up another one which looks like it is really hard and responsible, and which is taking the direction that the former Government was taking. The Government says: 'Let us compromise and let us go along the middle way'. In fact, that is the wrong way of viewing it altogether. It is better to view these three scenarios as, firstly, the one that most helps the unemployed, secondly, the one that least helps the unemployed and , thirdly, the one that half helps the unemployed. When unemployment was the critical issue at the last election why cannot we, as a Parliament, and as citizens of this country, choose the scenario that will most help the unemployed and not the one that will half help them? Why cannot we choose the one that will most help the economy become sound again, rather than the one that will half help it become sound again?

As carefully and as genuinely as I can, as a person who was not represented at the Summit and in response to the Governor-General's Speech, I now urge the Government of the day to choose wage restraint and so help the unemployed and this economy. In my State of South Australia 68,000 people are unemployed. When we look at the young people, the school leavers aged between 15 years and 19 years, we see that a total of 17,000 are unemployed. In broad terms that is about 10 per cent of the adult work force of my State or 30 per cent of the young people of my State. All of us on both sides of this chamber regard those figures as too high. Yet if the Government chooses the scenario it is now inclined to choose, those figures will not improve-they can only get worse. If the unions push the Government towards scenario B, the one with least restraint, then it will get worse. According to the Treasurer's papers at the Conference we will see unemployment rise even to 12 per cent. Why cannot we all restrain ourselves? Not only politicians' salaries, professional salaries, businessmen's salaries and workers' salaries and wages, but all wage payments should be restrained. In this way we will have the best outcome as has been portrayed in the Treasurer's own papers.

I will give an example of what the ALP's present inclination would lead to. Average weekly earnings are currently $350 a week. A 3 per cent to 4 per cent increase later this year would increase this amount by $14 a week to $364 a week . If there were full indexation and, let us say, 10 per cent inflation during 1984, the amount would be increased by a further $36 to $400 a week. As average weekly earnings increase from the present $350 a week to $400 a week in the middle of next year, that increase in the piece of cake going to those who are currently employed can mean only a denial of those resources to the unemployed. I reject that. I urge the Government not to permit those wage, salary and other increases. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the introduction to his statement yesterday to the Parliament on the outcome of the Summit, stated:

It is now possible to reflect thoughtfully on the outcome of the Conference, to identify its key elements and to translate them into an action plan for all of us to follow in working towards recovery.

I hope it is not too late for these remarks, and the remarks of others in the Parliament, to have some impact upon that action plan. I have been somewhat repetitive, perhaps, given my speech this afternoon, because the Prime Minister' s statement about the Summit Conference does not pick up at all the significant speeches about wage restraint delivered at the Summit conference. I will refer briefly to four of them. The first speaker after the Prime Minister's opening remarks, was Mr Hughes, the President of the Confederation of Australian Industry. He said:

. . . the counterproductive role of wage indexation during the years 1975-81 must seriously raise the question as to whether wage indexation is a desirable and economically and socially justifiable policy at any time.
Full wage indexation leads to large wage increases. He continued:
In general, a most essential requirement-in which the Federal and State governments must play a leading role-is to ensure the continued restrain of wage and other labour costs increases.

An improvement in profitability of the private sector is an essential requirement for the achievement of a sustained, strong recovery of the Australian economy. By the same token, it is equally essential to continue wage restraint through an extension of the wage pause until at least the end of 1983 . . .

He was the first speaker on behalf of industry. But, in a most significant speech, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Kelty, along exactly the same lines and receiving the real applause of the people at the Summit-it was not reported by the Prime Minister when he presented his statement to this Parliament-said:

The ACTU believes unequivocally that the priority of this nation must be employment growth. We therefore reject the policy prescription of fighting inflation first through increased unemployment. Such a policy is a policy of despair and defeat. We accept that seeking the achievement of lower rates of inflation and higher levels of employment will involve moderation in wage demands.
Mr Dolan, the President of the ACTU, spoke before Mr Kelty in a similar way. He said:

In relation to wages, we believe that the principle of wage fixation should be such as to provide wage justice to employees whilst seeking to ensure that wage increases do not give added impetus to inflation or unemployment.

Representatives of both industry and unions urged this principle upon the Summit . But not a word of this can be seen in the Prime Minister's statement which was presented to the Senate. The person who summed up the matter most exactly was Sir Keith Campbell, who so tragically died in the week after the Summit Conference. In his final public speech he said:

The Treasurer presented, in his expose, three economic scenarios. He warned us correctly of the deficiency in econometric models and asked us to concentrate on the broad messages. The broad but very clear messages were: The longer the wage pause and the lower the wage adjustments, the lower the rate of inflation, the higher the rate of growth and the lower the rate of unemployment.

For the jobless and I suggest for the whole economy, scenario C offers the most hope. But it still predicts, its deficiencies accepted, an unemployment rate on average in 1985-86 little different to that in 1982-83. Surely that is not good enough. If we genuinely care about the jobless . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion for the Address -in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech. I say at the beginning that I will not support the amendment moved to the Address-in-Reply by the Opposition, for the reason that the first paragraph of the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) that the program outlined in the Governor-General's Speech will result in higher unemployment and represents a callous disregard of the needs of the Australian people;

The group who made this statement presided in government for seven years and created the largest level of unemployment ever seen in the history of this country and now has the gall about four weeks later to move that motion. That probably beats the hide of almost anybody. In the speech we have just heard the honourable senator proceeded to lecture the new Government about what it ought to be doing. He had the audacity, in relation to the National Economic Summit Conference, to make the comment that the unemployed were not represented. I suppose that members of the Liberal Party have a great concern about the unemployed; after all, they created them and therefore they want to look after them. They had their opportunity while in government to do the things about which we have heard pious lectures for the last week or so. I would be much more interested to hear what constructive comments they can make about solving the problems of this country. Until they do so, they will remain seated on the Opposition benches.

I wish to discuss, in relation to the Address-in-Reply, that part of the Governor-General's Speech which refers to constitutional and electoral reform. I raise this matter because Australia has just been through what can be described only as one of the most nauseating experiences that this country has ever seen in an attempt to reform the Constitution. I despair completely that a convention constituted entirely of politicans will ever reform the Constitution of this country. The petty party squabbles and the comments made by those sitting around me from the Liberal-National Party coalition that since they had the numbers they would use them illustate fairly well the attitude taken by most delegates at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide.

I propose what I believe is the only rational and reasonable alternative to what went on in Adelaide; that is, to hand back the Constitution to the people of Australia. Before this Federation was formed the conventions were of two kinds. The first kind consisted of appointed representatives from the various colonial parliaments. They made no progress; they faltered. It was only when finally the governments of those various colonies decided that they must allow popular representation that the conventions picked up speed and actually made any progress. If the conventions had continued to consist only of politicians from governments, I am quite sure that the Federation would never have occurred. Indeed, if the Convention which sat in Adelaide last week had been sitting before 1900 I am sure we would still be without a federation even in 1983.

I believe the courses open to us are to have either a popularly-elected convention or to have what I believe to be superior-a citizens' initiative. I believe the advantages of a citizens' initiative over a popularly-elected constitutional convention are many. Probably the dominant one to my mind is that a popularly-elected constitutional convention would be nothing more than a rerun of the party operations that we have seen to date; whereas a citizens' initiative is a totally different operation and, where it has been applied, it has always worked outside the party system. That is probably why, when one canvasses this idea around the country, one meets no opposition to it from the people. In fact only one identifiable group can be found to argue against it- politicians. It would remove part of the power that is currently vested in this Parliament and return it to the people for their use.

The citizens' initiative idea is a very simple one. It would involve the gathering together of sufficient signatures of citizens of the country on a petition. In most of the countries which have citizens' initiative such petitions are formally recognised by the highest legal representatives in those countries. In our Commonwealth that would be the Attorney-General. He would recognise the petition as a document and issue it from his office at the request of the citizens. If a sufficient number of signatures were gathered in a certain period-generally six months-the question on that petition would go to the people for their determination.

Probably the dominant argument against it comes from people who say either that they are conservatives or that they are reformers. If they are conservatives they say that it is an instrument of reform. If they are reformers they say that it is an instrument of the conservatives. I put to honourable senators that a detailed analysis of the history of the citizens' initiative as it has operated in America since it was first instituted there in 1898 shows it to be an ideologically neutral mechanism that can be used by people of all political philosophies to challenge the status quo, and to challenege it effectively, in that it puts to the people a question that the people can deliberate on. In this place and elsewhere after elections we have much discussion about whether a government has a mandate for this or that item. This happens because of the confusion about what was in the front of the electors' minds when they cast their votes.

I will put to the Senate some dominant questions which may be exercising the minds of the citizens of this country at the current time and which I believe would gain sufficient signatures to allow a citizens' initiative. They would be such questions as whether Australia wanted a nuclear industry or whether the Australian public wished a dam to be constructed in South West Tasmania. They are issues of high political concern upon which large numbers of people on both sides have strongly-held views. I believe they are appropriate questions to be decided by the people. I suggest that in a democracy our next step must be to give the people the ability to raise questions of these kinds and to decide them by their votes. Those votes may not correspond to the votes they cast for the group they wish to have in Parliament, governing the economy of the country. They may cut directly across those types of ideas. Whereas they may wish to vote into power a Labor Party government, at the same time the same electors may wish to vote against an item which the Labor Party holds as central to one of its main platforms. The same could happen with the conservative side of politics.

One question is whether such an initiative would be abused. I think that is a very interesting question. While I have heard many politicians argue against citizens' initiative, I have heard them argue that way only in this place. I have been to hundreds of meetings to discuss this particular proposition and I have not yet heard one politician say to a public meeting: 'I do not believe you ought to have the power to decide these types of issues'. That argument is kept solely for debate in parliaments. I believe most of the arguments against citizens' initiative are not of much substance. For example, there is a concern that people may use such a power in relation to the tax laws. This concern probably arises from the much-heralded Proposition 13 in California which halved the rate of land tax on the citizens of California. The same people gathered sufficient signatures two years later to have Proposition 11 put to the people. Proposition 11 in California proposed the halving of the rate of income tax. It was lost in a landslide. One immediately sees from that that that the arguments against the proposition are basically anti-democratic. Basically the underlying theme is: 'We really cannot trust the people with power in a democracy and we are not willing to take the next step in the evolution of democracy, which is citizens' initiative'.

If half a million signatures were necessary for such a petition to be presented , only issues which had really galvanised the community's attention and which caught its imagination would be put forward. Only such issues could get together people of sufficient strength and dedication to gather a petition of that magnitude. Such a question would be of importance to the Australian electorate. It would be one upon which people in the electorate would want to have, not a vote by representatives but a direct vote themselves. I believe that in this way if such an initiative were instituted all issues within this country would and could be faced up to. Many issues are never tackled by parliaments because they are too hot, too controversial. They are put to one side. They are put on the back burner simply because when parties look at the electorate they say, 'Well, this major group or the maor group would be upset'. If there were a citizens' initiative those issues would be raised. Highly controversial issues such as abortion would be raised and a vote would be taken. Those types of issues would find their way at long last on to the law-making agenda. The decisions would be brought closer to the people by the fact that they had a direct vote on these matters. Publicly arrived at decisions would lead to better and more open government in this House and in the other place.

I believe that the last major important reason, apart from many others about serving the public interest and the like, that is why the citizens' initiative should be welcomed is that in a democracy such as ours one hears time and again calls that the citizens are apathetic. They will not do this or they will not do that. Various solutions are proposed to overcome this apathy. I do not believe that the citizens of Australia are apathetic. I believe that they are powerless and that that powerlessness represents itself in an identical way to the way apathy identifies itself; that is, non-activity in the political area. The diagnosis has been wrong. The solutions proposed have therefore been incorrect. The solutions proposed are to take more and more government to representatives. If, in fact, we believe that the citizens are powerless the solution is obvious. More power must be given to the citizens. It is only when they have the power that they will seek information. When they seek information, the demands upon government for open government will be so overwhelming as to be irresistible.

Freedom of information Acts will be put up and possibly passed in this place and they will be a great advance on what has been suggested and legislated for previously. Nevertheless, I believe that they will not be used in any really effective way by the citizenry. I believe-one can see this in places where the initiative is exercised-that where the citizens have a deliberative vote on a particular issue they want to know everything, and they make inordinate demands on the bureaucracy and the representatives and they are not satisfied until they get that information. I believe that that is the way to continue a healthy growth within the democracy that we have. If we are not willing to go along that path, I believe we are not willing to grasp the next major nettle, and that is how we can actually involve the citizens much more in what goes on in this country. After all, the people's interest is the public interest and it is the public interest that we seek to serve.

I believe that if one looked at the reasons proposed against a citizens' initiative, imagined oneself standing in front of a hall of 2,000 citizens and thought how many of those particular arguments one would be willing to put to the citizens against their having that power, in front of such a gathering of the electors of Australia all of those objections would dissolve rapidly. That is the final crunch test. Unless one is villing to say to the citizens' faces, ' You cannot be trusted. You should not be trusted' any constitutional change in this country will take place, I am convinced, only through a citizens' initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity as one of the older senators, in service if not in years, to congratulate you, Mr President, on your appointment to the office of President of the Senate. Having served under three of your predecessors, I know that you will uphold the standards already established in this place and that both sides can expect a fair and just adjudication whenever the occasion arises.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not detain the Senate for any length of time but I want to speak very briefly about freedom because it is a very precious commodity to me, as I am sure it is to other honourable senators. As one who was twice incarcerated for a few short hours perhaps it is more in my mind than in the minds of other honorable senators. I want to speak briefly about those people throughout the world who have not committed any crime but who are, nevertheless, incarcerated. I think particularly of those people who live under military juntas, fascist regimes and dictatorships, whose only crime-if one can describe it as such-is the desire for freedom for themselves and their people. I think of the mothers of the lost who daily parade their grief in the streets of South American countries who really do not know whether their sons and husbands are alive or dead or even whether they are amongst the bodies that were found quite recently. I think of the people in Chile, Nicaragua, Paraguay, Uruguay, El Salvador, Lebanon-the list is endless-and I think particularly of the small contribution that we in Australia can make in regard to that freedom. We hear almost daily of atrocities being committed, of people disappearing and inadequate justice being provided for those who perhaps fortunately are brought to trial. I think of the people of the church, people like Father Gore whose so-called crime was that he wanted a reasonable standard for the people he loves and was not prepared to stay silent and watch the exploitation of human beings.

I think tonight particularly of people like Karl Gaspar. There may be some honourable senators in this place who are not aware of this lay preacher who is at present incarcerated in the Philippines. I recognise that there is not a great deal that Australia or Australians can do about people such as Karl Gaspar except perhaps to use this forum to bring to the attention of foreign governments the fact that we are not prepared to sit back idly and allow to arise situations in which human rights do not prevail.

That final sentence relates to the advice that I have since received. This afternoon I was informed that whilst legal counsel may have access to Mr Gospar, it is not the counsel of his selection but the counsel provided by the Philippine authorities who are also the prosecutors. I know that this is not an isolated case. We hear all the time about people not obtaining justice as we know it but I believe it is incumbent on people in this Senate and those who have the use of forums such as this to bring to the attention of the people throughout Australia and other free countries, and to foreign governments who have representatives in this country, the fact that we are not prepared to tolerate a system which denies the basic human right of access to justice. By ' access to justice' I mean justice of the individual's own choosing, justice that will at least enable a person to put forward a case in his or her own right and to have the case determined by a court of law which will determine whether any impropriety or crime was committed or was about to be committed. I have some doubts that the Mr Karl Gaspar that I know of, who has been charged with subversion and inciting to rebellion, has the capacity for that type of action. He is a law abiding lay worker with a church who in the past has demonstrated a great love of people. I doubt that he would do anything that would put in jeopardy those he serves in the Philippines.
