TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to set the record straight on the composition of the Tasmanian delegation to the Constitutional Convention in South Australia.
—The phantom, she never sleeps.

—Just wait until I have finished, Senator Evans. Up to date you, in your inevitable fashion, have told half truths. Indeed, you do not tell truths; you tell untruths and when caught out resort to half truths. In the course of the next couple of minutes-that is all it will take me-I will demonstrate to you how this has occurred.
—Order! The honourable senator will address her remarks through the Chair.
—I am sorry, Mr President. I will certainly do so. In Question Time yesterday, in answer to a question by Senator Sibraa, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the case that at least two of the delegations to last week's Constitutional Convention were blatantly and unashamedly stacked.
He said:
. . . the Tasmanian delegation contained only two members of the Labor Party out of 12.
Senator Peter Baume, by way of interjection, said:
How many Liberals? Come on.
Senator Evans answered:
It contained four paid-up and practising members of the Liberal Party.
In reply to my interjection that the whole thing was an untruth, Senator Evans said:

I am giving the full-I emphasise the word 'full'-and absolute truth of the matter, if the Senate will listen. There were 12 Tasmanian delegates. They were divided into seven from the lower House and five from the upper House. The five upper House delegates were all 'Independents' in the Tasmanian tradition and in every instance that I can recall voted with the conservative majority on the floor of the Conference.
According to Senator Evans, the fact that Independents might vote that way is something to be suspicious about. He continued:
Of the seven lower House delegate positions, which it was squarely within the capacity-
I would like honourable senators to mark that phrase-

of the Gray Government to command and to divide equally and appropriately between the parties, four were taken by the Gray Government for its own members, leaving two for the Labor Party and one for the Independent in the lower House, Doug Lowe.
Senator Evans, not satisfied that we may not have taken the meaning of his words accurately, said:
That is the truth of the matter. It would have been very easy indeed for Tasmania, given its peculiar position in the upper House, to do as the Western Australian Government honourably did . . .
He goes on to elaborate how the Western Australian Government overcame the situation that was peculiar to Western Australia and not peculiar to Tasmania at all. He also said:

Those were the conventions that, once again, were torn up by the people on the other side of this chamber and their colleagues in other States, particularly Queensland and Tasmania, who always demonstrate their utter inability to match their sentiments with their performance whenever they get the opportunity.

He really castigated the Premier of my State in no uncertain terms. Indeed, he said that the delegation was blatantly and unashamadly stacked. Now we can perhaps have the real and full truth of the matter. What I say applies to Senator Evans and, indeed, also to Senator Chipp who has on many occasions since the Convention in South Australia publicly berated our Party for stacking our delegation and who is not in the chamber tonight to listen to the adjournment debate. Perhaps we now can have the full truth. The Schedule of the Tasmanian Constitutional Convention Act No. 73 of 1972 states that there will be 12 delegates to the Constitutional Convention, five from the Legislative Council and seven from the House of Assembly.

This is the situation that neither Senator Evans nor Senator Chipp would acknowledge. I am quite sure that it would not take much research, particularly with the facilities at the disposal of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), to find out, if he so cared to, the full truth of the matter. It is stated in the Schedule of that Act that each appointed member continues to be a member of the delegation whilst he remains a member of the Parliament or until he has been appointed otherwise. That determines the membership of the delegation. So really Premier Gray had no option. He abided by a 1972 Act put through by the Labor Government of our State which stated that five men would be appointed by the Legislative Council and seven by the House of Assembly.

In 1973 the first Convention had these members: Mr Fenton, an independent; Mrs Benjamin, a Labor member; Mr Carines, an independent; Mr Dixon, an independent; and Mr Michael Hodgman, the member for Denison in the House at the moment and who was at that time an independent. From the Assembly we had Mr Everett, the Labor Attorney-General; Doug Lowe, who was at that time a Labor member; Mr Austin, a Labor member; Bob Baker, a Liberal member; Mr Bessell, a Liberal member; Andrew Laurie, a Labor member; and Bob Mather, a Liberal member. As you would know, Mr President, Doug Lowe has now resigned from the Labor Party in Tasmania. He is now an independent.

Mr President, you remember that Senator Evans said that there were two Labor members and one independent. It is not the Premier's fault that Mr Lowe decided that he could no longer tolerate the Labor Party, that he resigned and became an independent member. He must remain part of the delegation because that is what the Act states. It provides that he remains part of the delegation while he remains a member or until the Parliament decides that he is no longer worthy of holding a seat. I think it would be a completely wrong action to say that Doug Lowe should not be a delegate and that he should not take his place at that Convention.

We now have the situation where one Opposition member of that delegation is still Andrew Laurie and we now have Mr Barnard as the other Opposition member. We still retain Doug Lowe because the present Government sees nothing wrong with anything Mr Lowe has done which should debar him from remaining as a delegate. The four Government representatives-Mr Gray, Mr Bingham, Mr Pearsell and Mr Bushby-have taken the place of the former Government representatives who are no longer in the House. If Senator Evans had decided, before he came out so robustly yesterday in Question Time saying that he was telling us the full and absolute truth of the matter, to get one of his many staff to do a little research, perhaps the miscarriage of justice would not have been so clearly heaped on the head of the Premier of my State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coleman gave us an unhappy and moving recitation of the condition of liberty around the world and, indeed, in our own region. We are indebted to her for drawing the attention of the Senate to the very distressing state of affairs, as she did. She is correct in saying that this Government has made a very firm commitment to taking up a heightened interest in human rights issues. She is correct in identifying the Gaspar case as being very much one such issue, as, indeed, the intervention by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) already in this case clearly demonstrates. Cases of this kind ought not to be regarded as simply a matter for this Government however. This is an area in which we ought to be able to view the world through bipartisan eyes. Indeed, there is a strong tradition in this Parliament of doing just that through the organisation of Amnesty International of which many honourable senators and members from both sides of the chamber are active, committed members, including Senator Coleman. I think the kind of issue Senator Coleman raised tonight is a lesson to all of us to take seriously our obligations as individual parliamentarians by continuing to draw attention to these matters in the hope that, thereby, severe injustices can be remedied.

SPEECH.PARA: Moving from bipartisan consensus matters to matters of partisan strife and warfare we come-inevitably in that context-to the contribution tonight of Senator Walters. It is just as well that Senator Walters does not have to earn her living as an advocate because I am afraid she would be eking out a rather poverty-stricken existence in those circumstances. The situation is that she did not in any way challenge my description of the composition of the Tasmanian delegation as comprising five so-called independents in the upper House who voted to a man in all the instances I can recall-presumably those she can recall or identify as well-with the conservative Opposition on the floor of the chamber .

In that respect she behaved very differently from the way in which previous upper House components of Tasmanian delegations have behaved. I can recall that there have been some real statesmen among them. Charles Fenton, over the course of a number of conventions, has behaved in that way. There has been a clear sense of what was right, which has not in any sense toed a visible or discernable party line, in the way in which those independents have voted in past delegations. Even Mr Brian Miller, whose former pedigree is that of a Labor Party member, was rather overcome, it appears, on this occasion by his anxiety not to fall out of step with his colleagues, given the forthcoming presidential election for the Legislative Council. He, too, demonstrated no willingness that I could discern to behave other than as a disciplined member of a conservative majority. But the Legislative Council in Tasmania is a special case as we are all aware. Maybe not too much should be made of that. But what of the situation in the lower House in Tasmania where a great deal can be made-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us not cast aspersions on particular people.

—No, including those present in the Senate tonight. The situation was particularly acute and particularly scandalous, I believe, in the context of the composition of the lower House component of the Tasmanian delegation. The unchallenged fact remains that the four Liberals assumed their seats together with two current members of the Australian Labor Party and one former member of the Labor Party. That is still a four to three majority even if one regards Doug Lowe as a member of the Labor Party, which clearly is not the case these days. But he voted with the Labor Party to the extent that there were divisions of that kind in exactly the same way as the upper House members voted the other way in their capacity as independents. I readily acknowledge that state of affairs. Senator Walters says that this is all defensible and all understandable by reference to a state of affairs which I chose not to draw or neglected to draw to the Senate's attention yesterday; that is, the terms of the Tasmanian Constitutional Convention enabling legislation of 1973. Senator Walters very proudly read into the record the proposition-

—It was 1972 with a 1973 amendment, I thought I heard Senator Walters say. But in any event that is not the point. The substance of the provision as I understood Senator Walters was that each nominated or approved member of the Tasmanian delegation to the Constitutional Convention continues in that office or role while he or she remains a member of Parliament or until Parliament determines otherwise. Senator Walters read that particular proposition into the record tonight. Therein lies the manifest falsity of the allegations she then proceeded to make. The reality of the matter is that there is perfect flexibility vested in the Tasmanian Parliament to vary the composition of its delegation from one convention to the next in exactly the same way as there is perfect flexibility vested in this Parliament to vary the composition of its delegation from one convention to the next. There was no reason under the sun why it should have been perceived by anyone to be the case that there was any obligation to maintain a delegation which was stacked-I repeat the word advisedly-in the way that the Tasmanian delegation was stacked on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of the matter is that there were two Labor Party members out of twelve. There were three Labor Party delegates if one counts Doug Lowe in some surrogate capacity to which he himself would not admit. There were three out of twelve. Wherein lies the significant distinction between that and the situation which prevailed in relation to Queensland? Wherein lies the moral difference? There is certainly no technical difference in the powers available to respective governments and to the respective parliaments to adjust their delegations to produce the particular result that justice, comity and constitutional good sense would demand. I repeat finally that to the extent that there is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Take your bat and ball home.

—Senator Peter Rae may need to take something else home if he can manage to do so. To the extent that there was a situation that needed to be redressed and balanced by virtue of the idiosyncratic character of the Tasmanian Legislative Council, I repeat the example of such adjustment that was, I understand, the case in Western Australia.
